The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reid)

talk.start.para: â€”Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Freedom of Choice
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

petition.presenter.block:
by
Senator Jones
(from 189 citizens) and
Senator Woods
(from 198 citizens).

petition.title: Chemicals
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

para.tab: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

. . . their desire to respectively call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

petition.para: Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Uranium
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned and respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Sex Guide
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

petition.para: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

para.tab: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: French Nuclear Testing
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The Petition of the undersigned:
1. Condemns the President of France, Jacques Chirac, and the French Government for deciding to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll;
2. Joins in the world-wide anger over France's decision, which calls into question France's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty;
3. Urges the Federal Government to urgently inform France in the strongest possible terms of the anger felt by the people of Australia at the decision;
4. Calls on the Federal Government to consider all available diplomatic; economic and cultural measures which may force the French Government to cancel nuclear testing.

petition.para: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Landmines
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give high priority to support for efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.

petition.title: Landmines
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

speech.speaker: Murphy Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”Pursuant to standing order 190, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”Last night in the adjournment debate Senator Abetz came into the chamber and made some statements with regard to comments that he attributed to me. He implied that I had said the government was deliberately delaying a decision with regard to the AQIS draft risk analysis and decisions that would arise from it with regard to quarantine matters and restrictions relating to the importation of salmon meat.

para.tab: The fact of the matter is that nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, it is a total untruth on behalf of Senator Abetz to come in here and say that, because I in fact never said that. If he had been listening, he would have understoodâ€”he should not have come in here againâ€”that I said yesterday that, with regards to the consideration of the draft risk analysis and the submissions that have been received by way of public input to it, the assessment of those submissions would take some time. It could well mean that there is a need to do additional scientific work.

If Senator Abetz knew anything about the issue, he would also know that that additional scientific work could take a long period of time. In fact, in the view of some AQIS officers it could take up to 10 years. On that basis, I said in a brief to the press that you could not expect that it was likely that there would be a decision with regard to the AQIS draft risk analysis and recommendations arising from it before the federal election. That is the factual position.

talk.start.para: â€”That is exactly what I said yesterday. Repeat it.

â€”No, Senator Abetz. What you said was: Unfortunately, that sent out all the messages that the people in the industry and, in particular, the employees did not want to hear. They did not want the government to play politics with it.

speech.para: That is what you said. He went on further to say, as did Senator Calvert yesterday, that with regard to a public hearing of the rural and regional affairs committeeâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: we gave leave for Senator Murphy to make a personal explanation that he had been misquoted, but I think he is ranging too widely now, and it was an odd hour of the morning to give him leave. He is now debating the whole issue. I think it is time you finished up his explanation.

â€”There is no point of order. Senator Murphy knows that he may not debate the issue. He can only speak to the areas in which he believes he has been misrepresented and I shall intervene if he does not.

â€”With regards to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, which was conducting a public hearing in Hobart on 6 September on the administration of AQIS, Senator Abetz said that I did not turn up to the meeting. Well, that is true. I did not turn up to the meeting, becauseâ€”
â€”Well, you have not been misrepresented.
â€”If you shut up for a minute, I will tell you why.
â€”Senator Murphy, address your remarks through the chair and ignore any interjections.

â€”I was actually returning from Papeete, as Senator Calvert should have known. He paid $100 to have his name put on a banner that I actually took to Papeete, so he would not have wanted me not to carry out that task. He was the only Liberal in Tasmania, I might say, who did that. I congratulate you, Senator Calvert, for doing that because you were the only one who did it.

â€”Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: it is quite clear that he has strayed from the topic of AQIS and the Tasmanian salmon industry right over to Mururoa Atoll. Clearly, banners and who sponsored what are clearly irrelevant. The simple fact is: I made the allegation that Senator Murphy was not at the AQIS hearings in Tasmania. He has just confirmed that he was not because he considered it more important to be in Mururoa Atoll rather than to be looking after the salmon industry in Tasmania. I did not misrepresent him and he ought be sat down.
â€”Senator Murphy is entitled to give the explanation as to why he believes it is a misrepresentation. He certainly cannot debate the issue or go beyond that.

â€”Prior to going to Mururoa Atoll, I rang Tony Smithies of the salmon industry and informed him that I would be unable to attend that hearing. That is the reason I claim that it is unfair for another senator to come in here and say this and imply that I was lacking in concern for the industry by not being there. That simply was not the case.

para.tab: It is implied further in Senator Abetz's adjournment speech that I lack a concern for the industry. My response is to say that, on those issues, I have been invited to attend, and have attended, a significant number of annual general meetings of the Freshwater Anglers Council of Tasmania to speak to its members about salmon. I did not notice the presence of any Liberal senators there. I have also been invited to attend, and have attended, dinners of the Southern Tasmanian Licensed Anglers Association and various other dinners and angling association and branch association meetings. I have also been invited by the Northern Tasmanian Fisheries Association to represent it on the State Inland Fisheries Review oard.
The reality is that Senator Abetz has misrepresented me. But there is one important point I would like to make.

Senator Calvert interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Calvert, I know you have a genuine concern for the salmon industry, but you have only ever written to the minister on one occasion; Senator Abetz has never raised the issue with the federal minister.
â€”I think the explanation is probably straying further than it should.

debate.sub1.title: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

speech.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talker.name: Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para:
â€”I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee entitled
Impact of Assets Test on Farming Families
â€”Access to Social Security and Austudyâ€”Second Reportâ€”Social Security Assets Test
, together with the transcript of evidence.

para.tab: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: This matter was referred to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee in August last year. In March this year, the committee presented the first report, which dealt with the Austudy assets tests and farming families.

This report, which deals with the assets tests that apply to social security payments, is the second and final report on this reference. I should note that this is a majority report and that Senator John Woodley, while agreeing with most of the committee's findings, has exercised his right to attach a dissenting report.

para.tab: The complexity of the rules and regulations which govern access to social security payments rival those associated with the taxation system. This inquiry has been one of the most technically difficult I have been associated with, as it was essential that members of the committee came to terms with how these rules are applied.

There is a common misconception amongst some people that the social security system is designed to provide a minimum income for all Australians. However, the social security system is no longer a minimum income support system. The system is based on the philosophy that those who can look after themselves should do so. However, those in genuine hardship should be given help, and there are hardship provisions which should assist people in these circumstances. It is important also to note that the system is made up of a number of separate programs, each with its own tightly defined objectives, target groups and rules of access.

The three major programs examined by the committee were jobsearch and newstart allowances, family payments and the age pension. Most submissions and evidence concentrated on these programs. The committee investigated farming families' access to these payments and the impact of the assets test. In relation to jobsearch, the committee found that few farmers access the jobsearch allowanceâ€”and this is not surprising, because they have an ongoing commitment to the farm and therefore cannot satisfy the activity test.

The committee found that the jobsearch allowance hardship provisions, designed to assist farmers who were ineligible for basic JSA because of assets, misses the mark and needs to be changed. In particular, the committee recommends that the requirement to offer the property for sale should be dropped.

In relation to family payments, the committee received evidence from the National Farmers Federation suggesting that farmers are disadvantaged and in fact only 45 per cent have access, whereas 90 per cent of families receive payment. The committee found that this evidence was based on incomplete information. The likely situation is that farmers have about the same access to these payments as other sections of the community. I say `likely' because the DSS does not collate these statistics. We have recommended that it do so.

I was astounded that the department was unable to supply the committee with such basic information. I appreciate the Department of Social Security's main role is to ensure that payments are made to those people entitled to them. However, I fail to understand how policy makers can be expected to assess how well programs are reaching their targets unless accurate data is available.

In relation to the family payments program, again the committee was not impressed with the hardship provisions and has recommended changes to make access for farming families more equitable. In relation to pensions, the committee found that the assets test does have a significant impact on farming families access to social security. There is however a more fundamental issue that I believe will become increasingly more important in rural Australiaâ€”the need for orderly intergenerational transfer of the farm.

The committee concluded that this issue needs more attention and that there needs to be a better integration of government policiesâ€”including pensions in relation to retirement, managerial succession and assets transfer on farms. Specifically, the committee expressed concern about the deemed income and gifting provisions for pensions and recommended that they need to be changed if farming families are being disadvantaged.

The final matter the committee looked at was whether the assets test should be scrapped altogether. Given the changes the committee recommended to each program to make them more equitable for farming families, existing concessions that recognise the special circumstances of farmers and the need to maintain incentive for people to self-support, the committee did not consider it could support such a proposal.

The committee's views on whether the assets test should be retained or scrapped were not determined by the likely cost. However, the committee did on a number of occasions seek information about how much exempting the farm assets from the assets test would cost. DSS advised that it had done some `very rough figuring' and estimated that the cost could be in the region of $1 billion. However, the department was either unwilling or unable to supply any more accurate information than this, and I personally consider that the accuracy of their estimate is highly questionable.

The committee has also recommended several administrative reformsâ€”for example, specific information and better dissemination of farming families entitlements to social security and the upgrading of training for DSS regional staff to ensure they understand the special circumstances of farm families. The committee considers that these reforms are necessary because many farmers are unaware of their entitlements and do not apply. For example, the committee received a number of first-hand accounts of aged farmers being unaware that hardship provisions even existed. I believe that the Department of Social Security should do everything possible to ensure people receive the assistance to which they are entitled. This is particularly important in the case of aged farmers, who are often isolated and unfamiliar with how the social security system works.

Before I conclude, I wish to emphasise that there is an urgent need to review the application of the hardship provisions associated with each of the social security programs examined by the committee. In times past when the rural sector was prosperous, access of farmers to social security payments was not an issue. Farms could generally produce enough income to support farmers and their families as well. However, this is no longer always the case. There are a number of well understood reasons for this. One of the most significant has been the exceptionally severe drought which deprived many otherwise highly efficient and viable farmers of their livelihood.

As a result, there is a real hardship in the bush. I believe that there is evidence that the hardship provisions have failed to alleviate the very difficult circumstance faced by many farming families who are left to depend on charity in some cases. I consider this is intolerable, and I reiterate that it is most important that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) have another look at the hardship provisions for all programs. I commend the report to the Senate.

â€”I present the report of the Economics References Committee entitled
Taxation of financial arrangements
, together with submissions.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: I intend to speak only very briefly just to explain that this is a reference passed on to our committee that had originally been referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. At the time the structure of the committees was changed in October last year, this reference was then referred to the Economics References Committee.

para.tab: This term of reference, I understand, was initiated by Senator Watson. The committee received eight submissions to this reference and has submitted this report. I understand that Senator Watson is going to speak briefly to the report. I really have nothing further to add to the tabling of the report.

talk.start.para: â€”The matter of the taxation of financial arrangements was originally referred to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Committee, as mentioned by Senator Ferguson. Following the restructuring of the committee system, the reference was subsequently taken up by the Senate Economics References Committee, which my colleague Senator Ferguson chairs. I initiated this initial action due to a real lack of government consultation and also a lack of government awareness of some of the complex issues that were involved and the difficulties that I foresaw as a result of what was in train at that time.

para.tab: The process of the referral to a Senate committee, therefore, allowed industry bodies to put their concerns and recommendations directly to the committee and, through the committee, to the government. In 1.6 the committee acknowledges that much attention has been given to the ATO's new consultative process, and the committee believes the process has been thorough and has offered the opportunity for all views to be considered.

While it is true that all people who have had views have had an opportunity to put them on the table, perhaps the best process would have been the establishment of a steering committee, because in a sense it has been a one-off consultation. Despite the initial submissions by some people, the tax office has not responded.

I understand it is going to be a fairly long process. Given the issues involved and the fact that there is no indemnity right across all sectors which are affected by this issue, I think time is essential. I am pleased that the tax office will be preparing what I term an issues paper preparatory to the presentation of an exposure bill. That will allow further mechanisms for input from those affected.

The difficulty is that, essentially, the banking sector requires a type of ongoing market operation, whereas the institutional groups who use these sorts of securities prefer a more traditional approach. In a sense there is, therefore, a recognition of the need for the legislation to fit the two types of requirements, because these institutional groups will not necessarily have the software that the banks and others have in terms of their ability to handle it.

Honourable senators may recall some questioning of government ministers where on one proposal I pointed out that on a discounted type of security over something like 10 years the paper chase could involve 14 pages of calculation just for one transaction. I indicated at the time that it did seem somewhat excessive to impose this on all these types of transactions. I am pleased that the committee has taken this up. I am pleased generally at the manner in which the Taxation Office has instituted the opportunity for interested organisations to make their views known and therefore able to participate in the policy formulation process.

I would also like to remind the Senate that, as Australia is moving to make its tax laws much more complicated and therefore divorced from the understanding of ordinary taxpayers, friends across the water, New Zealand, are moving to make theirs simpler, less complicated and more friendly to investors. In a sense we, in Australia, are missing the main game and in the process imposing tremendous additional costs on taxpayers, which is not assisting the development of this country.

If we are going to make Australia the regional headquarters, amongst other things, and make infrastructure development attractive, then we have to look very closely at the cost of compliance of the legislation and also the volume of legislation that we are putting through this parliament because it is certainly hindering economic development which is moving elsewhere. I think this is to the detriment of Australia and Australian living standards. I thank the Senate.

talk.start.para: â€”On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the 58th general report of the committee. I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para:
The committee's 58th general report covers the period January to December 1994. As in previous years, 1994 was extremely busy. The committee tabled 13 reports regarding projects which cost more than $320 million. This outcome followed the committee meeting on 77 occasions during the year. Nineteen public hearings and 29 inspections were held in centres as far afield as Port Wakefield, South Australia, and HMAS
Stirling
on Garden Island, Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland.

para.tab: The projects examined were equally diverse, ranging from the upgrading of a transonic wind tunnel for the Defence Science and Technology Organisation to overseas works in Hanoi and Port Moresby, to a new housing development for defence personnel and their families in Sydney. I might add we do not travel to Port Moresby and Hanoi, as much as we would like to. Most of those overseas projects are considered by video.

Recommendations made in the reports, similarly, are wide-ranging and the vast majority of them were accepted by the government and will be implemented. A number of common themes are canvassed in many reports. These include the need for project designers and constructors to provide: measures designed to conserve energy and water; measures designed to facilitate ease of access to people with disabilities; measures to protect the environment and heritage; fire safety measures; the involvement of local construction industry in projects, especially outside major capital cities; and the need for more rigorous analysis of sites selected for construction projects to ensure that they are not contaminated.

During the year, the committee was briefed by officials from a variety of departments and agencies. The briefings covered such matters as: private funding of a proposed car park at Melbourne Airport; the future of the army's base at Puckapunyal and RAAF base Williams; the Christmas Island rebuilding program; concurrent documentation; value management; new directions for Australian Estate Management, which is responsible for managing the Commonwealth estate, estimated to be worth $2.5 billion; and the activities of the Construction Industry Development Agency.

The committee also spent time inspecting projects previously examined during their construction or upon completion. A number of inspections were undertaken during the year in Perth, Sydney, Singleton, Myambat and in northern Australia.

In October last year, committee members attended the third conference of Commonwealth and state public works committees in Hobart. Representatives of the ACT, Queensland, South Australian and Tasmanian public works committees attendedâ€”and enjoyed some very fine Tasmanian hospitality too, Senator Denman, I can assure you. The committee believes that the conference provided an excellent forum for legislators to discuss issues and themes materially relevant to the examination of public works proposals.

As the committee's work for the year concluded and as the year of commemorations of the end of the Second World War was about to begin, it was coincidental that the last report tabled involved the redevelopment of a defence establishment, HMAS
Watson
, an establishment of exceptional historical significance in the defence of Australia. All over Australia, the work of enhancing, redeveloping or reshaping the infrastructure necessary for the defence of the country continued.

The committee can also reflect on the deeds of past committees, the reports of which on defence facilities were used for the conduct of the Second World War. As well, the committee in the past has played a major role in attending to the needs of returned servicemen and servicewomen. The report lists the many repatriation hospitals which were examined and reported on.

I can honestly say that the committee operates in a bipartisan way. The value that the Australian taxpayer is getting for their dollar is the overriding concern to committee members. Finally, I want to thank the staff: Peter Roberts, the secretary; Michael Fetter and Denise Denahy, the assistant secretaries; and Sue Whalen and Mahesh Wijeratne, secretarial support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
â€”Order! The committee is considering the revised amendment moved by Senator Vanstone.

speech.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Chairman, yesterday the chamber was kind enough to give me leave to withdraw the amendment circulated in my name and replace it with another. That was as a consequence of the minister having said earlier in the discussion that he believed our amendment did not cover what we thought it did. There was no agreement that that was the case but, nonetheless, we changed it to, in our eyes, further clarify what it was we were getting at.

para.tab: I understand there is now circulated a further revision of that amendment dated 28 September, and it is the only revision dated 28 September. We have tried as hard as we can to see what it is the government is getting at but, frankly, we cannot see that we could amend it any more and make it any clearer.

The point that was at issue was whether the amendment covered new large exempt companies coming onto the pile or only those existing ones. For the benefit of the ministerâ€”and he may already be familiar with thisâ€”the point we got to yesterday, just before the standing orders prevented us completing this bill, was that we had made this case out as being ours. Yes, we agree with moving to a small/large distinction; yes, we agree with lessening the burden on small companies. And we, nonetheless, believe that it is not appropriate to put an additional burden onto large exempt proprietary companies, under the guise of simplification, and that they should be able to continue with their existing reporting requirements; that is, they should be able to choose whether to have an auditor or to file key financial statements.

Adopting our amendment would enable all large exempt proprietary companies to be treated the same, whereas under the government's proposal some of them will be quarantined with their original choice; that is, they will be able to have an auditor and not file any statements. The others will have completely different arrangements; that is, they will have to have an auditor and they will have to file full financial statements. We do not see the appropriateness of that distinction that the government seeks to maintain. We think it is much more appropriate to have all large exempt proprietary companies treated the same and treated as they are now treatedâ€”either they have an auditor or key financial statements.

I do not think there is any point in repeating that any more. I make the point that where we got to was an invitation basically to the government to spell out why it is they think this amendment does not cover new companies going onto the pile, as we think it does. Also, if the Greens are not going to support the amendment anyway, we may simply be taking up debating time that could better be spent on another bill.

Just before we finished yesterday, there seemed to be an indication from the Greens that they were not completely enamoured with our proposal, but I did not hear a definite no. That is where I think we are now. I seek leave to withdraw yesterday's amendment and move the new one.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

(b)but for the amendments (other than this subsection) made by subsection 4(2), and set out in Schedule 4, to the

speech.para: I make it clear that our view is this amendment applies to all exempt proprietary companies, those now in the pile and those which are to come onto the pile. I am happy to have this amendment moved first and then move to the government amendments, which I think is the course the minister and I agreed to some days ago, when we were dealing with this.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: â€”I do not think I need to speak at length on this. I give Senator Vanstone points for trying again, but the government's position is that this does not meet the objective that we have tried to meet in terms of greater transparency and greater disclosure of information. So we oppose the amendment, though recognising that Senator Vanstone has tried to get consistency. In trying to apply that consistency, I think she defeats the purpose of the government's proposals here. I think the best thing we can do now is probably put it to the vote and see how we go.

â€”I have not spoken in the committee stage yet, so, with the Senate's indulgence, I will add my contribution as I was a member of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, which well and truly considered this matter. It is true to say that consultations were good and most groups within the corporate community were well and truly represented before the committee. This matter has been thrashed out from top to bottom. Therefore, it is important that the government maintain the consensus value of this law simplification process so as when we move on to the next stage that consensus that we have had to date, except for this one sticking point, is maintained, otherwise progress simply will not be made in this area.

para.tab: It should be pointed out that, whilst the simplification task force recommended this small/large test, none of its approaches in corporate law simplification related to the matter of accountability or disclosure. That is not their brief and that is not their aim. Their aim is to simplify corporate law. So this new argument that the small/large test is going to bring about greater accountability or disclosure is not correct. It never was the brief of the simplification task force. It is a new argument they have latched onto to justify the small/large test. The task force suggested the small/large test originally simply because they thought it was simpler. They have erred in that thought.

It can just as properly be debated that the existing system is simpler or, for that matter, more accountable and with equal disclosure. Really, the simplification task force was not at all concerned about disclosure or accountability. It was not even in its particular brief. This is just a new argument brought in to defend to the death this small/large test.

The task force erred in that it is attempting to treat private companies in the same way as they treat public companies. They are getting their brief mixed. They are not understanding that there is a difference in the corporate world between private and public. You cannot place the same onerous responsibilities on the private company as you do on the public company, for good reason.

Public companies have a greater responsibility for disclosure, and so they should. They go out into the marketplace where they trade their shares, where they raise equity, and it is right and fitting that greater responsibility for accountability and disclosure be required of public companies. But you cannot fit that same requirement to the private companies. That is where the task force has erred. It is trying to treat small private companies in the same way as it treats public companies, as you would on the stock exchange. Therein lies the new extra layers of cost.

It is very costly. Every piece of disclosure you place on a company is going to be an extra cost. Transferring private companies into the public arena and giving them similar responsibilities of course is going to mean new and burdensome costs.

In corporate law we are forever trying to find that magic formula between accountability and disclosure, and overregulating and bringing the wheels of business to a grinding halt. We are forever balancing those two, which is not dissimilar to the tax arenaâ€”with fringe benefits tax, for example. In your pursuit to collect greater revenue, you can get yourself very tangled up in extra regulations and burdens upon business in reporting their tax.

There is no doubt that since the 1980s we have stepped up our requirement for disclosure and accountability, and rightly so. Obviously in the 1980s there was too little, but we have stepped it up. The Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities, of which I am a member, has had much to do with stepping up the responsibilities of directors. We are looking at the moment at the area of derivatives, following the Barings Bank collapse. We do not want something like that in this country. That requires new regulationâ€”a new look at the regulations so that we do not get troubles in our futures markets or, as we did in the 1980s, directors totally devoid of responsibility. They have a new set of responsibilities. In fact, as you would expect, they are complaining about overregulating the area of directors, that we may have gone too far. But that is part of the balance we are trying to get, and this is not dissimilar.

If we rely too heavily on regulation, we are going to be bringing business to a grinding halt, so we rely on a great deal in the corporate area on self-regulation. The Australian Stock Exchange corporate governance guidelines are a self-regulatory process. It is a first step. If those guidelines do not work, if they are seen to have failed, then we may have to regulate, but self-regulation is always the first step.

The Australian Stock Exchange corporate governance guidelines, I think, are standing up quite well, as can be seen in the Coles Myer case. In the name of corporate governance, the institutions seem to be taking a great interest in that particular case. There, corporate governance guidelines are on the line, they are to be tested; the self-regulation process is now being tested in the Coles Myer case.

You cannot lay everything at the door of the Australian Securities Commission either. It simply does not have the time or the resources as it stands now. Of course, if the government wished to double the ASC's resources, then it could do double the work. But, as always with these matters, that would be an extra public cost: the more you regulate, the greater the public cost.

Even at present the Australian Securities Commission is under great criticism for its inability to check the prospectus process. That is a far more important issue than the one we are dealing with. One of the great faults of the 1980s in the public arena was shoddy prospectuses. The Australian Securities Commission has the very important responsibility of getting the checking of the prospectus process under control. That is a problem the ASC is greatly burdened with at the moment. If you listen to its critics, it simply does not have it under controlâ€”and that should be one of its primary sources. The ASC needs more resources for that problem than for the suggestion we are making here.

As it stands today, you cannot rely on the Australian Securities Commission to be the monitor of who should and who should not be in the small large arena. I really do wonder how the ASC will cope with this extra burden. Anyone who saw the ASC's representatives before the committee will know that they are a bit googly-eyed when it was suggested that the ASC take up the new responsibility of declaring who should and who should not have exemptions. In fact, the chairman asked us to set down the criteria. We had not done it, he does not know what it is and, as yet, we have not seen it. So we are to pass the principle of the legislation here without any of the regulation or criteria to follow.

Senator Dee Margetts would well know that that is a very doubtful process when legislating. Too often we see the legislation go through and then we await the legislationâ€”if, indeed, we are to regulate. It may just be a set of guidelines for the Australian Securities Commission, and it will not even come through this parliament. So there is the black hole in the argument for the small/large test.

With this background, it is worthwhile to compare the two competing processes: the small/large test, and the existing system. Our particular amendment goes a long way to returning us to the best of the existing system and it certainly would abolish the worst of the proposed system.

The existing system has this going for it: no-one has ever complained about it. There has been no ground swell for its change at all. This is a classic case of a task force and a parliament tinkering for no reason at all. The present system does force accountability in two particular ways. One of your choices is to audit your books and then not disclose your accounts. That secures the integrity of the books and the businessâ€”and, of course, that is assuming auditors do secure the integrity of the books and the business, although to what degree they do is another argument for another day.

The other choice is to submit your accounts to the Australian Securities Commission. If you do not want to go through the very expensive process of auditingâ€”and expense would be the only reason you would not want to because auditing can be greatly beneficialâ€”be it that you are a very small business, then you are required to submit minimal accounts to the Australian Securities Commission.

It is as simple as that. There is no extra cost; no discrimination, such as the discrimination that the grandfather clause will set up. There is no objection to it. We are upholding the concept of private companies, their privacy. And of course this is supported by the accounting bodies: the Australian Society of Accountantsâ€”of which, I should add, I am a memberâ€”and the Institute of Chartered Accountants.

Moreover, the existing system has had a check and balance element since about 1990; it is found in the corporations law and in the accounting standards. Basically that is, as has been reported in our committee report, in a nutshellâ€”and this is a complicated areaâ€”if there is a public interest to declare your reports, if it is reasonable to expect the existence of users dependent on general purpose financial accounts, then you should publicly disclose; or if a certain number of shareholders require auditing and disclosure. That is a fair check and balance on the existing system.

In comparison the small/large test is unpopular and not supported by the accountants, be it that they will benefit the most from all this. I appeal to Senator Margetts that, ironically, it is less accountable, or it can be argued to be less accountable. That is how arbitrary this whole debate is. Many of the small companies that will fall into the small category will not be disclosing; but who is to say they should not? In many of those small companies there is a public interest for them to disclose. They will indeed escape any form of disclosureâ€”not just auditing, but even the most minimal accounts that the existing system requires. There could be, for example, a public interest in a director disclosing his interest or his accounts of his own private company against his directorship in a major company. That is just one example of a public interest.

Even political parties may have company offshoots. They will fall into the small area and they will not disclose. So you are totally abolishing the public interest factor in the need for some companies to disclose, no matter how small they are. If the grandfather clause does not divide and rule, I do not know what does in the corporate world. We have already been informed that those companies advantaged by the grandfathering will not have to change their existing system. There will be enormous trade in those companies. They are going to become very valuable. That places those companies which will have to adhere to the small large test at great commercial disadvantage. Those companies that fall into the grandfather section will have a commercial advantage. It seems incredibly unfair.

I could go on and talk about the absolute ability to rort this system. I think the Senate has heard about the ability to rort the asset valuations. This small/large test has been approached from the wrong angle. It was meant to simplify the corporate law, not to be a matter of disclosureâ€”which is just a new argument the task force has latched on to. If it is not broken, we should not fix it. We should support the coalition's amendment, which really does return us to some equity in the system.

talk.start.para: â€”This has been a fine balancing act for us. I can see the merits of the arguments on both sides. The good intentions of various parties might not become apparent, if they are good intentions, until after they are put into practice. On the balance, we do not believe any problems that exist will necessarily be solved by the opposition's amendments. However, I am not yet convinced that there are clear enough guidelines on the discretionary principle. I am pleased to see there is an amendment which the government is proposing which generally deals with this issue.

para.tab: But the government should feel an obligation to clearly provide some explanation behind those guidelines, make them available to companies and, at the same time, provide clear advice in advance about how you can keep accounts in such a way as to minimise the cost of compliance in audits. That is the thing I am asking: that the government sees an obligation to produce clear information to the companies involved to make sure that they know exactly how they can minimise their compliance costs by the way they present their books, to make it as cost effective and as easy as possible for those audits to take place and to make as clear as possible the guidelines about how this cost and benefit judgment takes place regarding the government's discretionary powers.

It is a pity that this kind of debate has not taken place more in respect of competition policy and even the Uruguay Round of GATT. Some of the issues are much greater than that which we are talking about today. It is not that this is not important, but we really ought to be talking about these kinds of issues when major policy decisions are taking place.

Small businesses often lose out as unsecured creditors. That is why on the balance we are prepared to support the implementation at this stage. But, at the same time, I am flagging that Senator Baume's amendment at the third reading stage has a level of appeal. I would flag that on the balance it is not possible for to us support the opposition's amendment. On the balance, in this instance, we are going with the government's proposal. It has not been an easy decision, but I am flagging that there is a certain attraction to supporting an amendment which means that we will have a chance to look at how the system is working. I will expect the government to voluntarily provide clear guidelinesâ€”not just wait until somebody is in trouble and has a huge billâ€”about discretionary provisions and about ways to minimise the audit costs to those businesses which may be subject to these audits.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: â€”Could I just respond to the three points raised by Senator Margetts. In respect of the first point about application of discretion of the ASC, I am informed that the ASC will make guidelines available. We will take on board your second point about accounting practices and whatever to reduce the cost of the process. We will see what can be done there. Your third point dealt with Senator Baume's amendment at the third reading stage. We can live with that as well. If that gives you an extra degree of satisfaction, we do not even have to argue about that amendment at the third reading stage.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

(2)Schedule 3, page 39, paragraph 9.3, omit "Large proprietary companies must prepare accounts, have them audited and send them to shareholders. They must also lodge the accounts with the ASC unless exempted.".

51A. After Subsection 313(11)
