tab.tab: (a)the expected costs of complying with the audit requirements; and
(b)the expected benefits of having the company or companies comply with the audit requirements; and

(c)any practical difficulties that the company or companies face in complying effectively with the audit requirements (in particular, any difficulties that arise because a financial year is the first one for which the audit requirements apply or because the company or companies are likely to move frequently between the small and large proprietary company categories from one financial year to another); and
(d)any unusual aspects of the operation of the company or companies during the financial year concerned; and
(e)any other matters that the Commission considers relevant.

para.tab: (11B)In assessing expected benefits under subsection (11A), the Commission is to take account of:

tab.tab: (a)the number of creditors and potential creditors; and
(b)the position of creditors and potential creditors (in particular, their ability to independently obtain financial information about the company or companies); and
(c)the nature and extent of the liabilities of the company or companies.".

speech.para: (4)Schedule 4, page 68, item 83, after proposed section 1408 insert the following sections:

"
1409Application of audit requirements for large proprietary companies

tab.tab: Despite section 1408, the first financial year for which a large proprietary company that was an exempt proprietary company immediately before the commencement of this section must have its accounts audited under section 296 (as amended by the Amending Act) is the first financial year that starts after the commencement of this section.

para.tab:
"
1410First annual return for proprietary companies under new provisions

(1)
To avoid any doubt, the first calendar year for which subsection 335(1A) applies is the one that ends on the first 31 December after the commencement of this section.

(2)
The first calendar year for which subsection 335(1A) applies to a company that is registered after the commencement of this section is the calendar year that ends on the first 31 December after its registration.".

tab.tab: Note: Subsection 335(1A) was inserted by item 66 of Schedule 4 to the Amending Act.

speech.para: I will place on the record a number of items which have arisen during discussions. People anticipate that these sorts of statements will be made to clarify aspects of the amendments. The first amendment omits clause 7 from the bill. Clause 7 would have amended the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1994 to alter the commencement of schedule 6 to that act, which deals with the use of penalty units in the Corporations Law. The provision was inserted in anticipation of the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1995 being enacted and commencing earlier this year. At that stage we were waiting for all the states and the Northern Territory to enact legislation which would have enabled the penalty unit provisions to commence. However, due to the unexpected delays in the passage of the bill, schedule 6 will now be commenced by way of a separate proclamation in accordance with the existing provisions of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1994.

para.tab: The second amendment will remove from the small business guide a paragraph indicating that large proprietary companies must have their accounts audited. This change is consequential upon the fourth amendment which I will mention in a moment.

The third amendment inserts proposed new subsections 313(11A) and (11B). These proposed new subsections relate to the exercise by the ASC of its discretion under section 313 of the Corporations Law to relieve a large proprietary company of its obligations to comply with the law's audit requirements on the basis that those requirements would impose unreasonable burdens on the company.

The government considers that in exercising this discretion the ASC should be required to take into account the matters referred to by the committee in its reports. The ASC presently engages in public consultations in drawing up class orders. The Chairman of the ASC has indicated to the Attorney-General that the ASC would be happy to continue its existing policy of consultation in preparing class orders to give relief from the new audit obligations. This is entirely consistent with the current policy of the ASC in carrying out its functions.

The fourth amendment inserts proposed new sections 1409 and 1410 into the Corporations Law. Proposed section 1409 relates to the timing of the application of these new audit requirements for large proprietary companies. It is designed to avoid difficulties that could arise if the audit requirements were to commence some time after the start of a company's financial year. The amendment provides that the first financial year for which large proprietary companies must have their accounts audited under section 296 of the law is the first financial year that starts after the commencement of proposed section 1409. Proposed section 1410 ensures that proprietary companies will be required to provide an annual return for the calendar year in which the bill commences and the year in which the proprietary company is registered.
As I said, these points have been made at this stage because they were expected, having been raised in discussions and debate during the process.
Clause 7 not agreed to.
Amendments Nos 2, 3 and 4 agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments.
That the report be adopted.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: At the end of the motion, add:

"and the Senate resolves that not later than two years and six months after the commencement of the amendments set out in items 1 to 6 of Schedule 4 of the bill, the Australian Securities Commission is to cause to be laid on the table a review of the first two years of the operation of those amendments".

speech.para: The amendment calls for a review after two years. I thank the Senate for its indication of support. Because the opposition amendment was defeated, there is certainly now a much greater need for this amendment than would have existed had the opposition amendment been carried. That was an amendment which would have made equally fair the obligations of all large proprietary companies to report. The situation now, in this bill, is that some will be given a special privilege, for no good reason; others will not have that privilege, for no good reason.

para.tab: My only regret is that this review is to take place not later than two years. I would hope that, in the event of a change of government, the review will take place a lot sooner than that because I believe there will be a need to restore fairness in terms of obligation to report. At present that is being destroyed by this bill. It sets up a special category of companies which, because of either historical accident or choice, or whatever reason may have existed, may have chosen to tick the box saying their accounts are audited and therefore do not have to reveal financial statistics publicly. They will continue to do so while companies that are newcomers, coming into the area, building themselves up from small companies, will have to face an additional unfair discriminatory burden that does not exist for existing companies.

They will be obliged not only to go to the expense of being audited, but also of revealing their full financial details to the public and to competitors who do not have to reveal anything. They will have to reveal these figures to competitors who, under this legislation, will reveal absolutely nothing. That is the unfair and discriminatory consequence of the defeat of the opposition's amendment and the passing of the government's amendment.

As Senator Margetts properly pointed out, it does, however, allow a discretion to the Securities Commission to permit some not to reveal their information. But it is only a few. In other words, there is an added discrimination. There are those who, by historical accident, will reveal nothing. There are some who, as a result of the decisions of the ASC using its capacity to single out a few for this kind of special treatment, will get special treatment, and then there are the rest who have to reveal all and will face an unfair and discriminatory burden that is not faced by their competitors.

That underlines the need for this review. I must say that, while I am glad that this is here as a sort of failsafe in the sense that this discrimination hopefully will only continue for a little while, I do regret that it is going to exist at all. I think this legislation will bring mixed blessings. It will bring blessings to the small end of the small business sector, the small proprietary companies, because they will have their reporting burden significantly alleviated. I am very grateful for that, on behalf of all the people in small business I have talked to about this legislation.

That is the good news. The bad news for those small businesses that succeed, that have worked hard and built themselves up to having more than 50 employees or having assets of more than $5 million or a turnover of more than $10 million, is that they are the ones who are going to be discriminated against unfairly. That is one of the reasons I would hope that in this review it will be recognised that, firstly, the high jump level anyway is an unreasonable oneâ€”because two out of those three criteria mean that you would qualify as a large businessâ€”but, secondly, I would hope that the unfair discrimination against a section of these people will be seen after two years of operation to be unfair. Of course, by then we will have a government in place which will be concerned with fairness, equity and decency in this area. I have every confidence that the government which will be in place in two years time will correct this anomalous and discriminatory situation.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Report adopted.

debate.title:
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) BILL 1994
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) CARE CHARGES BILL 1994
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) ADMINISTRATION FEE BILL 1994
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 1 February, on motion by
Senator Crowley
:
That these bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to voice the coalition's concerns about four bills: the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill, the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Care Charges Bill, the Health and Other Services (Compensation) (Consequential Amendments) Bill, and the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill.

para.tab: Usually, when we debate bills originating in the other place, speeches at the second reading stage are perfunctory affairs reflecting what has already been said by ministers and shadow ministers in that house. But today it is rather different because of the tortuous process that this legislation has had to undergo in order to get to this stage. That this has happened is fully the responsibility and fault of the government.

Unlike the process leading to their debate here, I will attempt to be brief and concise. I will sum up our views about the bills, the way they evolved and our position in relation to them. But perhaps to focus your understanding of what is occurring in relation to these bills, I will read a letter that I received recently from a Mrs Joan Neowhouse, who has given me permission to use her name, of Forbes in New South Wales. It is entitled `First an accident victimâ€”now a hospital victim':

speech.para: Would you please be prepared to help a widow in a lot of pain, victim of a bus injury which hospitalised me, but for which the compensation covered hospital fees, but not interest on them up until the GIO paid the claim.

ACT Health Service now wants me to pay $3439.82 interest because the hospital bill of $15,929 for my two admissions in 1990 & 1991 is to be paid late. The hospital actually admitted me as a Medicare patient, so if I had not made the claim on GIO & pursued it, the hospital would have got nothing, and there would be no interest on that.
Can you do anything to help me. It is all I can do to survive, without being victimised by the hospital just because I got them $15,929 in fees instead of nothing.
Any assistance you can give me to get the hospital administration to leave me alone would be most welcome.
I look forward to hearing from you in due course.
Joan Neowhouse
That illustrates the whole problem in the debate which we are about to enjoin.

para.tab: At the outset, let me put the coalition's position on double dipping on the record. Double dipping in the context of this legislation is the receipt of Medicare and/or nursing home benefits in respect of what the legislation prosaically calls compensable conditions, usually injuries or diseases which arise from an episode of personal injury and for which the injured person seeks compensation through common law remedies, workers compensation, or third party or general insurance.

Let me make it perfectly clear the coalition has absolutely no difficulty with this principle. If a person receives Medicare or nursing home benefits in respect of a compensable condition and then receives a compensation award covering the cost of treatment, then it is only right that the Commonwealth be repaid the taxpayer funded benefits already paid out. What the coalition and, to their credit, the Australian Democrats have argued ever since this legislation was foreshadowed is that the mechanisms it proposes for recovering these double dipped benefits are cumbersome and costly, and spread the burden unfairly on compensation payers as well as the claimant.

Because it is at the centre of our concerns, I will pay particular attention to the administration fee proposed in this package and its inequities. The coalition has stated its opposition to this legislation on the fundamental point that the cure for the double dipping problem first proposed by the government is in fact worse than the disease, and that the $40 million or so per year that the government estimates will be saved for the taxpayer will actually be almost totally swallowed up by the cost of the administrative machinery operated by the Health Insurance Commission, insurance companies and other compensation payers.

I would like to talk about the evolution of these bills. As we know, these bills emerged from the findings of a review of the relationship between compensation and health and community services programs. This, in turn, was part of the major review of professional indemnity arrangements for health care professionals, conducted for the government by Fiona Tito of the Department of Human Services and Health, which is yet to be released. The report of the compensation review, however, was released as long ago as mid-1993, not very long after the last federal election. Yet here we are just before the next election discussing this legislation.

At the time there were informal consultations with interested parties about the finding of the review, particularly with insurers, work cover and third party authorities, medical defence organisations and the legal profession. Yet when this legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives in December last year all these parties were taken by surprise and some of them were only notified of the legislation after it had actually been introduced into the parliament. That hardly seems to be the mark of a conscientious, consulting government.

We had the same problem, you will recall, with the recent health legislation, which was a classic example of government being in power too long. There was no consultation and in fact the so-called contracts that were supposed to have been developed for introduction on 1 October in a few days time have not been signed by any of the providers, although some have been signed between the insurers and the hospitals. That is another classic example of government being in power too longâ€”it believes it knows everything and does not need to consult.

These bills passed through the House pretty quickly on the government's numbers but on reaching this place they were able to be scrutinised by the Community Affairs Legislation Committee. This occurred in March. After public hearings, the committee found in its report to the Senate, first, that there had been a serious lack of consultation between interested parties and the government in the development of the bills. Secondly, it noted the concerns of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills about the main bill's potential to erode the doctrines of legal professional privilege and self-incrimination.

Thirdly, the committee found there was evidence that the legislation may have involved breaches of privacy in respect of traditional doctor-patient relationships. Fourthly, it found that there were widespread concerns about the administrative costs of this legislation, particularly the proposed administration fee, and particularly noted the Insurance Council of Australia's concern that this fee would effectively be a `new tax' imposed on insurers and their policyholders. Finally, it raised the question of whether better mechanisms could be found to deal with the double dipping problem.

The legislation committee and its recommendation basically told the government to go away and start again, not least by consultation with the interested parties. It did not want to see a dog's breakfast of the legislation package debated in this place at that time. Consultation did take place, if you can call a series of meetings in March consultations, and more than two months later a raft of over 40 amendments to the bills emerged full grown from the department. They were not circulated as drafts for comment to interested parties either in this place or in the community.

These amendments, which we will discuss if these bills go to the consideration in detail stage, addressed the criticisms about legal professional privilege and offered a bulk payment arrangement for double dipped benefits to compensation payers but, if anything, made the overall package more rather than less cumbersome and more rather than less costly to administer. They certainly did not dispense with the administration fee.

In the dying days of the autumn session, the coalition and the Democrats arrived separately at the same conclusionâ€”if the legislation were debated, we would have no hesitation in voting it down. Yet, in announcing our position, the coalition made it clear that we were not opposed to the principle.

The shadow minister for health, Dr Wooldridge, wrote to the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, indicating this and suggesting that, should the government adopt either of two simpler models proposed by the Insurance Council and the Law Council of Australia, we would not hesitate to support the legislation. You would have thought that would have had a considered response, but Dr Lawrence's response was to play politics and misrepresent the coalition's position in a way that has become a hallmark of her political style.

Nothing happened until late August when discussions were held between the government and the Insurance Council on further modifications to these bills. Then, just a week ago, the government showed its complete contempt for consultation, bypassing further amendments through caucus so that the first the Insurance Council heard of them was when the shadow minister advised it of that fact. Such passes for consultation under the government. It is a combination of arrogance and fearâ€”arrogance, in that the government always presumes to know what is best for all concerned and then proceeds to impose its views on them; and yet fear that, in the final analysis, it will be rolled by those it perceives to be its opponents.

So we come to today. I want to say that while the government may believe that it insisted on resolving this legislation, it only got to the floor of this place because it had to be dragged kicking and screaming by the coalition and the Australian Democrats to a position where the contents of the bill had at least kernels of workability which can be refined in debate, yet where the major concerns of compensation payers are not fully resolved.

If any legislation emerges at the end of this debate it will be because the most unfair aspect of itâ€”the so-called administration feeâ€”will have been removed from this package by the Senate, and because other outstanding points of disagreement will be left unresolved and tolerated with the greatest of reluctance, by insurers in particular, with a spirit of compromise rather than acceptance as positive innovations in their own right.

Let me turn now to the most contentious feature of this package, the administration fee imposed on compensation payers to make these mechanisms, in the quaint phrase of the government, `self-funding'. Let us call this charge what it is, no less than an industry specific tax to impose a particular government policy agenda on compensation payers. The coalition believes that the tax is grossly unfair to insurers, be they general, third party, work cover or workers' compensation. It is shifting to these insurers the cost of what is effectively a function of governmentâ€”collecting the revenue.

The government says to us, `Well, it's fair. The insurers have the benefit of their clients having access to the Medicare system and up-front benefits while their compensation claims are pending. Why shouldn't they kick in to support a system that relates to their commercial activities for the private benefit enjoyed by their clients at public expense through Medicare and nursing home benefits? Why should the taxpayer pick up the tab for recovering what is rightly the taxpayer's?'

That does not make sense. Can't the government see that what we have here is a community benefit. Ultimately, it is not big, bad business that pays but Mr and Mrs Average Australian who want to be insured against personal injury or who have to contribute to compulsory third party insurance. Can't the government see that it will be the employer who pays through the worker's compensation system because, if these costs are passed on to insurers, they will be passed on to the consumers of insurance through higher premiums.

In New South Wales just now major battles are going on for the future direction of compulsory third party insurance in that state. There have been three rises in compulsory third party premiums in New South Wales already this year, and recently there were reports of a fourth rise on the way. The tax proposed under this legislation will be yet another cost burden which will find its way to the ordinary members of our community in the form of higher premiums, including for third party. The coalition finds this unacceptable and specious to argue, as the government does, that insurers can afford it.

We also oppose the administration tax on another principle: non-government bodies should pay for what is effectively the implementation of a given government policy. In the health portfolio, this is the second example this year of this cavalier approach to other people's money. Senators will recall the protracted consideration of Labor's health insurance reform package with its health insurance complaints mechanism funded by a levy on health insurers. This levy is to be calculated when it comes into operation by a membership-based formula. In other words, each health fund member pays some of his or her premium to support the government imposed complaints mechanism.

In the case of the present legislation, policy holders of injury related insurers will have to dig into their pockets to support the, I understand, nearly 100 public servantsâ€”although there is a debate about how manyâ€”and support infrastructure that the Health Insurance Commission wants to put in place. This is just unfair, and it is not just user pays like the government no doubt contends. User pays relates to the making of a financial contribution to the government revenue in return for the enjoyment of a given benefit such as a service.

This is unfettered bureaucracy. This precedent removes the responsibility from government to contain its own costs, as it will always be possible to identify some user-pays target which could be asked to pay for the extra bureaucracy. This is an important issue for taxpaying consumers, as the government is transferring the responsibility from the public sector to the private sector. This means the cost of the extra bureaucracy, anything between 100 and 160 public servants, is transferred from the transparent area of tax revenue, subject to scrutiny, and hidden by government as a private sector cost. Government is therefore not held accountable.

The current message from the federal government is that government spending will be restrained. This legislation indicates the opposite. In this case, the insurers are the ones providing the services, by doing the lion's share of the work of government and identifying what benefits have been double dipped and then, in accordance with the legislation, taking most of the steps to recover from the claimant. If anything, the government should be paying them.

But there is a third line of criticism of the government's proposed tax; that is, that the costs it covers should be seen as offset against revenue gains from the recovered benefits which would otherwise be lost to the Commonwealth. We believe that the cost of the tax to insurers will be higher than the just under $10 million estimated in the legislation documentation, but let's assume that the government's cost and revenue estimates are reliable.

In the government's own estimation, the benefits to be recovered will be around $40 million in a yearâ€”that is $40 million otherwise lost to the Treasury. The estimated cost of directly recovering these benefits is, as I have said, around $10 million. In other words, for every dollar spent in recovering the double-dipped benefits, the Commonwealth actually gains three. If the process were as simple as other interested parties have suggested, the proportion of dollars spent to dollars saved could be even greater. Surely this is not a bad profit margin which can be absorbed as an administrative cost of revenue raising, just as the operation of the Australian Taxation Office is seen as a justifiable cost in raising consolidated revenue.

To sum up, this administration fee, this tax, is unfair. It targets compensation payers, who would, in fact, be providing a significant service to the Commonwealth at no cost to it and who, I should add, have to absorb their own costs pending the determination of liability in compensation claims to which they are enjoined by way of their contracts of insurance.

We cannot, and we will not, support this tax for the reasons I have outlined. We will vote, therefore, against giving the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill a second reading, and I hope that the Democrats, Greens and Independents will join us in doing so.

As I indicated earlier, these are not the only concerns held by insurers, lawyers and other interested parties about these bills. The two other major outstanding points are, in the coalition's view, the obligation imposed on compensation payers to be responsible for repaying double-dipped benefits to the Health Insurance Commission rather than the claimant who in point of fact incurs the debt; and the failure of the legislation to give relief in the form of adjusted debts to the Commonwealth where the claim is compromised because of risks in litigation, as opposed to contributory negligence where responsibility for the injury is apportioned by the settlement or by the court. In those circumstances, the coalition believes that the amount repayable to the Commonwealth should be reduced by the same percentage that the claim was reduced.

In relation to the latter point, the coalition believes that this legislation can be made more palatable to those who have to implement it by making amendments to the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill to recognise risk of compromise settlements where the parties have agreed to a reduced settlement without apportionment of blame. Should this bill reach the consideration in detail stage, I will so move such amendments for the consideration of the Senate, but I stress that we will go no further unless the administration charge disappears from the package.

The coalition believes that this legislation has progressed very considerably from where it was in March this year, but not because of the government's good sense or willingness to compromise. We also believe that it still falls considerably short of an ideal solution to the problem of double dipping of benefits and compensation mattersâ€”a problem that not one party in this process disputes.

The government has undertaken to review the operation of this legislation after a period. Should something emerge from the Senate today, on behalf of the coalition I undertake that we, if in government after the very imminent election, will review this legislation in 12 months time and look carefully at its operation. In so doing, we reserve the right to amend it in whatever way we have to to make it as workable or as fair as we possibly can.

In the meantime, I say to the minister opposite that, if the administration fee bill and consequent provisions are deleted, the government will still get their double dip benefits and the coalition will consider the remainder of the package on its overall merits.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”This package of health bills is yet another example of this government's failure to do its homework before presenting us with legislation in this place. It is another example of the government's failure to carry out proper and adequate consultation.

para.tab: These bills came before the House of Representatives in December of last year. Following their introduction, the Australian Democrats were contacted by a number of organisations most concerned about the impact of the changes in this legislation. These organisations, which included the Insurance Council of Australia and the Law Council of Australia, also complained that they had not been consulted or involved in any way in the drawing up of this legislation. They informed me that, while they had been part of the discussions with government about the particular problem that this legislation is trying to addressâ€”and that is double dipping under Medicareâ€”they had never been involved in the drawing up of the legislation and in the deciding of what the solutions were going to be.

This is a pattern which we see time and again. I have to say that the Department of Human Services and Health certainly seems to be at the forefront of many of these problems. They do not seem to understand the basic principles of consultation and they do not understand that one of the benefits of consultation is that we do not end up with a piece of legislation that is fundamentally flawed, which nobody wants and which people will then fight tooth and nail to avoid.

Consultation does not mean, on the other hand, that the government then has to do what everybody else wants it to do. It does not mean at the end of the day that the government cannot proceed with its own agenda. All it means is that government should spell out its intentions to those people and organisations with a direct interest and involvement in the proposed changes, seek their opinions and at the very least try to establish whether or not what they are saying is workable.

In relation to these bills, the government could have saved itself a lot of troubleâ€”it has been close to a year nowâ€”by simply talking through the detail of the legislation with insurers and with lawyers prior to introducing it. Instead, the government has been forced time and again by the Senate back to the negotiating table, and now we are going to see something like 37 amendments to this legislation. Yes, this legislation certainly is now vastly improved but, as has already been said by Senator Herron, the government has had to be dragged kicking and screaming all the way. It certainly was not a smooth process.

After the bills were introduced into the Senate in February 1995, they were referred, at the instigation of the Democrats, to the Senate community affairs committee. That committee was unanimous in its view that the bills should proceed to the second reading stage only after the department had formally consulted with the relevant interest groups and taken what they were saying seriously. These consultations did take place, but the results were very disappointing. There was virtually no movement whatsoever from the government and a number of outstanding concerns remain unanswered.

As a consequence, when the government attempted to bring the bills back on for debate in June, the Democrats and the coalition indicated they would not be supporting them. At the time, I advised the government that I was entirely sympathetic to what they were trying to do, and we remain soâ€”we have been since it was first mooted back in 1993â€”but that I felt they still needed to do a lot more work to get the legislation to a stage where we could support it, where it would not disadvantage the very people whom we are trying to advantage, and that is those people who need to have support from Medicare until such time as they have a compensation claim decided upon.

We have now finally got to the stage where at least this legislation is workable. It is certainly not without continuing concerns and hassles. I believe we needâ€”during the committee stage I will seek assurance from the government on thisâ€”a review in 18 months time.

During the recess, the department sat down again with the relevant key organisations, and I think we at last saw a serious willingness to consult and listen to what these organisations were saying. I believe that once the data is in, there is likely to be a more simple way to solve the problems we have had before us. With the 37 amendments, the scheme is now at the point where I believe it is workable and acceptable, even though it is still a long way from being perfect. We have not accepted the government's arguments in support of imposing an administrative fee upon insurers. We will be opposing the introduction of that fee. I will discuss that in greater detail later on.

In relation to the actual scheme itself, the Democrats believe it is entirely appropriate for the Commonwealth to seek to recover Medicare and nursing home benefits when the person who has received the benefits is also entitled to compensation. This integration of compensation schemes with health and community services has long been a vexed issue in Australia. I think it is an issue which could be greatly simplified by moving to some sort of national, no-fault compensation system, but that is unlikely to occur in the near future and it is not something we have before us now.

I do accept that the Commonwealth has to look for some means by which it can recover its costs. The Commonwealth has opted for this scheme to recover the costs from the compensation payers and insurers. The scheme essentially revolves around insurers notifying the Health Insurance Commission of a claim, the commission then working out how much it is owed and, after settlement takes place, the insurer paying to the Commonwealth the amount owed before paying the remainder of the settlement to the claimant. This is a very simplified version of what is in this legislation.

Over the past 10 months there have been many concerns expressed about the process. Concerns have been expressed about legal confidentiality, privacy, the complexity of arrangements and so on. I am not going to go through these concerns in great detail, other than to say that virtually all of them have now been resolved. There is now provision in the legislation for insurers to make bulk payments after 18 months, there have been limits placed on the abrogation of privilege and changes have been made which avoid potential problems of delay in settlement. Overall, some 37 amendments deliver a much improved scheme and one that I think has demonstrated again the value of this Senate and its role in scrutinising and reviewing legislation.

I want now to turn in a little more detail to the question of the administrative fee. We will not support this fee because we believe it is inappropriate and unfair. It is basically a fee which seeks to have the industry bear the government's share of the costs of running the scheme. As the Insurance Council of Australia has pointed out, the insurance industry will already bear its own additional costs in complying with this scheme. That is appropriate, but we do not really see why the industry should also have to pay for the government's side of the process. I also accept the Insurance Council's argument that the scheme is only needed because the Commonwealth has made a policy decisionâ€”a correct decision in our view, as I have saidâ€”to pay all Medicare recipients up-front and then recover its costs once the state based compensation and legal system, et cetera, has established liability.

It is, I think, somewhat misleading of the government to suggest that the insurance industry benefits from not having to pay such costs up-front. As the Insurance Council points out, the insurance industry does not have that option. It cannot pay such costs up-front but must wait until liability is established. Indeed, if anybody benefits under the existing system, it is the patients who are seeing doctors and the doctors themselves because they are able to be seen under the cover of Medicare and not have to worry about paying money out of their own pockets until such time as they have had claims heard.

I believe that in all of these circumstances it is appropriate that the insurance industry and the Commonwealth each bear its own costs of operating this scheme. In any case, I note here that many insurers, I suspect, will eventually shift to the bulkbilling arrangements that we now have in this legislation and the issue of the fee will ultimately disappear. Therefore, I suspect that the government still expressing continuing concern over our not accepting the fee is really a bit of a red herring because, in terms of the overall success or failure of this scheme, it has very little part to play whatsoever now that those bulkbilling arrangements are there.

We still have before us quite a complex proposal. There have been quite a number of compromises on all sides. I call on the governmentâ€”whoever is in government at the timeâ€”to conduct in 18 months time, when the bulkbilling arrangements are ready to step in, a detailed examination of the proposal. After consultation with the industry, we may indeed be prepared again in this place to visit the possibility of further legislative action.

talk.start.para: â€”Today we are debating the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994 and related bills. I would just make some comments in relation to one particular area of these billsâ€”and that is the practice of double dipping, or the concurrent claiming of compensation and Medicare benefits. That, unfortunately, is a commonplace practice in Australia and one which needs to be resolved as a matter of considerable importance.

para.tab: But what has concerned me throughout all of this debate that has gone on since the original introduction of this legislation is, yet again, the lack of consultation the government has had with the industry concerned. We have seen this lack of consultation so many times. We have seen it in the attempts which have been made to ram the reform legislation through the parliament, without there having been any consultation with those concernedâ€”the doctors, the hospitals and the insurers. I believe that this example of lack of consultation is even more dangerous.

Double dipping is estimated to cost the Australian taxpayer about $40 million a year. So any attempts to overcome this problem are naturally welcomed by the coalition. But it is the way in which it will be done and whether the resolution of this problem is a practical one which concerns us. That is where we have difficulty in agreeing with the government.

Since the time this bill was first presented, the coalition has made the government aware of a number of concerns about the legislationâ€”just as we have been made aware by other parties of many of the concerns about the legislation. We are now especially concerned that the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill imposes a tax on insurance, and by the types of concerns that have been raised with our shadow minister for health and human resources, Dr Michael Wooldridge.

The history of this bill is that, after it passed in the House of Representatives, the coalition was approached by the Insurance Council of Australia, the Law Society and the Medical Defence Union, who wanted the bills referred to the Senate committee in order that they could express their reservations about certain aspects of the legislation. As I say, the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, as is typically the case, just refuses to consult with people in advance of what is happening with any of these pieces of legislation. So what we are confronted with every time and what appears to be the norm now is the concerned parties having to express their concern at Senate committee hearings. If we did not have that process, many of these concerns would not be aired because of the lack of consultation by the minister and her office.

Many of those industry and professional people have complained that they simply cannot even get an appointment with the minister. At times they have been told that they have to get on a plane and go to Perth to see Dr Lawrence. However, when they get on a plane and go to Perth to see Dr Lawrence, they find that they are then confronted with a meeting with her staff. They find that totally and utterly unacceptableâ€”and I do not blame them. They have a right to express their concern, and the country has a right to expect proper legislationâ€”and this government has a responsibility to the people of Australia to make sure that the legislation is right.

But the concern that there had been a lack of consultation was shared in the end by the Senate committee. Nevertheless, it recommended that the bills proceed but not before further consultation occurred. As a result of that extended period of consultation, a number of further amendments were made with the effect that insurers would be allowed to make a bulk payment to the federal government of an estimated quantum of Medicare and nursing home benefit recoveries based on previous returns, in return for which the levy in most cases would be waived.

Despite the amendments, however, there are still a number of concerns which are held by various groups in the medical, legal and insurance professions. The Law Council, for example, believes that the legislation's requirement for the Health Insurance Council to be notified of the various stages of the claims process will just wreak havoc in the areas of personal injury and workers compensation. It also sees complications arising from disputes about what benefit items are associated with the injury or condition for which compensation is being sought. This process will impose significant burdens upon insurers and claimants in terms of additional time, administration and cost burdens, which the Insurance Council of Australia estimates will be in the vicinity of $30 million annually.

The cost of double dipping at the moment is about $40 million annually. Therefore, the net gains that are going to be made in this are yet to really be seen and quantified to any real extent; yet the impact on the industry is going to be enormous. Once again, the responsibility is now taken away from government and put on to a third party. That will create more administration for and a greater burden on that third party.

This is all in addition to the industry levy, estimated to deliver the government $10 million in revenue per annum to finance the Health Insurance Commission's administration. This is effectively a tax on insurers to subsidise the burgeoning Health Insurance Commission bureaucracy, with little apparent benefit to the community and the high possibility that insurance premiums and legal costs will rise if the cost is passed on to consumers. My colleague Senator Herron mentioned that before in relation to the flow-on impact in terms of third party insurance and the net effect on prices, which will be that they will simply have to go up.

The industry players are also concerned that the legislation's requirement for the Health Insurance Commission interest to be identified and settled prior to compensation payment being made has not been removed. They believe this is a costly and time consuming process. They suggest that less time and cost intensive solutions are available to overcome the problem of double dipping. Many of those less time consuming and more cost-effective solutions have now been put to the committee and, therefore, have been put to the government. But they are still closing their eyes and ears to those suggestions.

Our argument is that the way in which the legislation is now drafted does not solve those problems and some of these suggestions should in fact be taken on board. The shortcomings of this current measure before us far outweigh any benefit that may have originally been thought to flow from the legislation. We would be far happier to give more in-depth consideration to proposals put forward by groups such as the Health Insurance Council of Australia and the Law Council of Australia. Those proposals are far more simple to administer.

The thing that really concerns me about this whole process of change to the Medicare legislation, to the health insurance legislation and to everything else is that there is so little consultation with anybody. When we look at the reform legislation we see that it is going to flounder. The reason it is going to flounder is the same reason this legislation will flounder. There is not a commitment from all parties that it will work and that it will be easy to work. In relation to the reform legislation, from today there are only three days before the legislation is to be implemented; yet the doctors are not prepared to sign the contracts.

As someone who has had a pretty close encounter with hospital bills in recent times, I have to say that the whole system needs reforming; yet the government cannot get it right. Here we are with the double dipping legislation, and they cannot get it right. I am the first one to admit that Dr Lawrence has been somewhat distracted with other matters of spending taxpayers' money on herself, as opposed to spending taxpayers' money in making sure that this legislation and previous legislation works.

But the fact of the matter is that we are not going to see this legislation take effect in any proper constructive way and that is why I draw the parallel between this piece of legislation and the reform legislation. Recently I had the opportunity of meeting with the board of directors of the St John of God Hospital in Perth. It is a very large private hospital. They expressed concern about the reform package, and understandably so.

When meetings like that come hot on the heels of reports which outline the shortfall of Dr Lawrence's reforms and which point to the fact that very few doctors, if any, have negotiated with service providers to decide upon a set fee for procedures, we know that we will see the same problems with this proposed legislation today that we have seen in the other legislation. Given the opposition to that bill by the Australian Medical Association, the Council of Procedural Specialists and so forth, we now have concern being expressed by organisations such as the Insurance Council of Australia and the Law Council of Australia which are experienced with the problem of double dipping but which are just simply being ignored.

It is about time this government started listening to those who are prepared to offer sound, constructive advice. The whole Medicare system needs to be totally revamped. We have more and more people dropping out of private health insurance day by day because of the inadequacies of this government to really resolve the problems that are surrounding it. Here we are with this type of legislation that is designed to solve a very important problem with respect to the double dipping of compensation. This government has a responsibility to the taxpayer to get it right, and we do not believe that this is the right way to do it.

Amendment 1 is a definition of bulk payment agreement. Amendment 2 clarifies the definition of a claim, noting that claims must be in writing and telephone calls do not count as claims. Amendment 3 defines a small amount. Very small settlements are exempt from ordinary notice provisions and a small amount is less than the administration fee of $150. That, in light of what we have just defeated, is a bit of a puzzle. I take the opportunity while I am on my feet to remind the committee of what the Senate has just done in defeating the other bill and what it has now done consequential to this amendment. The administration of each claim is estimated to cost about $137 and it is estimated there would be slightly in excess of 70,000 claims per year to which the legislation would apply. The administrative costs in total would therefore come to $10 million.

para.tab: The administrative costs of making Medicare available to insurance claimants should be borne by the industry, because it benefits from this availability. Without access to Medicare for claimants, the insurance industry would be forced to make other arrangements or pay up-front and then attempt to make recovery from unsuccessful claimants.

The opposition has argued that this administration charge is a taxâ€”they are stretching a very long bow indeed. The charge is simply thatâ€”a charge to pick up the costs of administration for actual claims which relate to a particular insurer's business. It is interesting to note that the application of the user-pays principleâ€”held so dearly by the oppositionâ€”seems not to hold in the case of this legislation. In this case, the opposition clearly feels that, when the insurance industry is the user, the industry should roll over and not worry about the user-pays principle. It is very clearly a piece of opposition expediency.

If this legislation had been implementedâ€”it has now been defeatedâ€”the industry would have continued to benefit from holding and using the taxpayers' Medicare dollars for long periods until claims were settled. The government is not proposing to recoup the interest charged on these funds, nor will we be trying to recoup the benefits that the industry has had from the funds over the last 10 years. We were simply seeking to ensure a fair contribution to prevent a greater impost on ordinary taxpayers. I noticed as I was coming down here and when I was listening to the proceedings in my room that Senator Knowles was hot to trot for ordinary taxpayers. She has just dudded them here.

talk.start.para: â€”Oh, you are the last one to talk about that.
â€”You have just dudded them, Senator Knowles. In fact, you have given the benefit to insurance companies and taken it away from ordinary taxpayers.
â€”Get it right.
â€”I have got it right. It should be remembered that the government budget estimates are premised on the recovery of these administrative costs.
â€”You're the last person to talk. You don't even know how many doctors have signed for a contract on Sunday, let alone this bill.

â€”Senator Knowles, abuse across the chamber is no grace and no help at all. I should also say that I have been asked in this place on other occasions what $10,000 would buy. Let me tell you what $10 million would buy. It would buy over 1,000 hip operations, over 808 kidney transplants, over 4,200 hernia repairs or over 2,500 gall bladder operations. Alternatively, it would buy over 1,000 heart bypasses or over 5,000 cataract operations. It would certainly buy nearly 24,000 neo-natal intensive care unit bed days. So I am glad that the opposition is profligate with the taxpayers' dollars and believes that those dollars are better off locked in the insurance funds than paid out on behalf of the cost of administering claims. This is not a tax that you have defeated, but a charge.

para.tab: Amendment 4 clarifies the date of injury in relation to disease cases. There is always confusion about definitions of an injury and a disease. What we want to make clear here is that, if a person is suffering from a compensable disease, it is said to have started on the day first medical treatment was rendered. The definition was in the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill, but will have been placed in the main bill with other definitions. Subclause 3(10) tells how to determine a period of bulk payment arrangement.

Amendment (6) adds two notes after the heading of part 2, division 1. They draw attention to other relevant legislation which might affect the operation of this divisionâ€”the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Care Charges Bill and the Social Security Act through the operation of section 27 of the bill.

talk.start.para: â€”I will see whether these words assist Senator Herron. This is a transition arrangement to assist insurance companies where they are moving from payments of claims on a one by one claim basis to a bulk payment basis. That is what we are trying to assist you with. The insurance companies may move to a bulk payment. Some of them at the moment would be doing that on a one by one basis, so these are transitional arrangements to cover the situation where they move from individual payments to a bulk payment.

â€”I thank the minister for the explanations. I requested them because I wanted to bring home to the minister the complexity of the arrangements that have been put forward by the government. What we have just been through is a classic example of the complexity of the legislation. It illustrates that, even with the explanatory memorandum, the government does not know what it is doing.

para.tab: It started out with a laudable aim, which was to recover the payments under Medicare. Now we have got into this gobbledegook which was in the explanatory memorandum. There needs to be a course in simple English for those who compose supplementary memoranda. I have illustrated this on many previous occasions. This is an explanatory memorandum to an explanatory memorandum. I know, when the government brings in 37 separate amendments, it needs to have a further explanation of them. What we have just gone through is another classic illustration.

The first of the five amendments I have circulated is to make provision for reduction of the double dipping effect in situations where parties reach a compromise to reduce their riskâ€”for example, a settlement for less than desired rather than nothing, which can happen in personal injury casesâ€”which leads to a reduced award without the admission of contributory negligence or apportioned blame. In other words, if an injured person seeks a compromise settlement, they can achieve that at a lower figure.

We believe that there are legitimate concerns about the fact that this bill ignores compromise settlements. It seems only fair that the interests of these parties be taken into account and that the parliament not compromise the abilities of these parties to reach a lower compromise settlement if that is their negotiated desire. You should not make the assumption that, if the lower payment is achieved, in some way the insurance companies are inhibiting the ability of the person to achieve adequate compensation.

We believe that there is a possibility that such compromises will be less attractive if the recovery of Medicare or nursing home benefits in compensated situations cannot be adjusted in the same way for these as it will be for apportioned settlements. There is an equity factor in relation to the injured parties. There is also the principle behind these amendments, as we see it, of minimising this legislation's interference with common law, third party and workers compensation processes.

Basically, we do not want to stop the parties doing anything that they would be doing to achieve a favourable outcome in the compensation system. That is why we have used the phrase `agreed compromise at the risk of the parties' in our proposed amendments, in the expectation that the benefits recovery phases reflect the negotiated compromise outcome.
I believe that what the coalition proposes is reasonable and in the spirit of this legislation. I call upon the committee to support this amendment and our related proposed amendments.

talker.name: Senator CROWLEY
talker.role: Minister for Family Services)

talk.start.para: â€”The bills deal with cases where the judgment or settlement fixes the amount of compensation on the basis that liability for the injury should be apportioned between the parties. Where there is some apportionment of liability and the amount of compensation is reduced because of it, the amount owing to the Commonwealth will be reduced by a similar proportion. This is fair because Medicare has some underlying obligation to pay benefits for eligible services which are not covered by a compensation payout.

para.tab: In effect, apportioning liability means that only a portion of the claims is the responsibility of the compensation payer; the remainder is the responsibility of the claimant and, hence, would be covered by Medicare benefits. It is on this basis that the Commonwealth is prepared to reduce the amount charged for Medicare and nursing home benefits in a similar proportion to the agreed apportionment of liability.

The opposition want the Commonwealth to also reduce its charge where settlements occur for reasons other than an apportionment of liabilityâ€”for example, where a claimant chooses to settle because of the perceived risks of litigation; perhaps their main witness has not turned up or is not very credible; or the judge is said to be tough on plaintiffs. Perhaps they just want their money quickly and are not prepared to wait for trial. Such factors are highly subjective and cannot be quantified, as the opposition suggest.

As the bill stands, in cases where an apportionment of liability is not involved, the claimant's debt to the Commonwealth is not reduced. These claimants must make their decisions about going to trial or settling knowing that they owe a debt to the Commonwealth for their Medicare and nursing home expenses. The opposition says that this is not fair as in these cases the other parties take a discount on what they might otherwise have got by going to court and the Commonwealth should share this reduction.

This is not precisely true. While one or other of the parties to the matter may settle for a greater or lesser amount than would have been the case had they proceeded to court, not everybody does. For example, neither the claimant's nor the insurer's lawyers take a discount on their fees in these cases; nor do the doctors who provided the medical care or the various experts who provided reports or evidence about the case. All of these people expect to receive full payment of their costs, irrespective of whether the claimant settles for a reduced amount.

In accepting a settlement offer, the claimant has to weigh up the pros and cons and take into account the extent of their total debts arising from the claim. Medicare and nursing home benefits paid by the Commonwealth are no different in this instance to other debts and should be paid irrespective of the risk of litigation.

The Commonwealth cannot allow its debtors to trade off that debt because of other subjective considerations. In effect, the opposition amendments invite the parties to manufacture a notion of risk in order to evade a legitimate debt to the Commonwealth. There is no accountability and no transparency in this arrangement.

`An agreed compromise of the risks' is totally arbitrary and totally unquantifiable. What does this concept mean? For a start, in order for the legislation to work based on a compromise of risks, this term would need to be defined. The opposition has not provided any such definition. The opposition amendments would turn the provisions into a lottery. The opposition amendments are so open ended that in practical terms the provisions would be dangerous. Who knows what the term `agreed compromise of the risks of the parties' actually means? Does even the opposition know what it means?

The very essence of a settlement is that it is a compromise on the basis of an assessed risk, so the effect of the opposition amendments would be to reduce the amount to be repaid to the taxpayer in every case which is settled. Rather than preventing double dipping, which is the intent of the legislation, the opposition amendments would actually encourage it. How can the parties sensibly agree about what their risks are?

The plaintiff will make a totally different assessment of his or her risks to that of the compensation payer. They are coming from totally different directions on this matter. How can they sensibly agree without some element of connivance? The larger the debt to Medicare, the greater the incentive there is for the parties to connive.

Let me paint a hypothetical picture to demonstrate how dangerous these opposition amendments can be. Take a hypothetical case where there is a debt to Medicare of $50,000. In this case, the medical components are a significant component of the claim. In part, because of this debt the claimant wants at least $100,000 to settle the claim; that is, he or she wants a net $50,000. The insurer is not prepared to go higher than $80,000.

Under the terms of the opposition amendment, it is quite legitimate for the insurer to agree to a much higher figure by using the taxpayers' money to make up the difference. That is how it works. The parties agree that based on an assessment of the risks the amount they settle on is only 50 per cent of what might have been achieved in a judgment; that is, they agree that the settlement amount would have been $160,000 instead of $80,000. This means that Medicare only gets 50 per cent or $25,000 of its debt, while the insurance company and the claimant give up nothing. The insurer only pays $80,000â€”the amount they were prepared to pay at the start of the negotiations. The claimant gets $80,000 but only has to pay Medicare $25,000, leaving the claimant a net $55,000â€”$5,000 more than her original starting point in this hypothetical case. The only losers are the taxpayers.

This would be the usual course of settlements under the opposition scheme. These arrangements would quickly become institutionalisedâ€”a set of entrenched gaming principles which govern the process of settlement in compensation cases. In addition, the amendments as moved do not even make sense. Opposition amendment No. 3 appears to change the wrong clause in the bill. Our best guess is that the opposition probably means to amend clause 23(4), relating to government amendment 24, not clause 21. We do think that that needs to be looked at.

Clause 21 deals with the notice of past benefits given by the Health Insurance Commission to the insurer. Subclause 4(b) specifies one of the things the notice has to say. Opposition amendment No. 3 would replace the subclause with a requirement on a totally different notice; that is, the notice of settlement or judgment given to the commission by the parties. Further, the opposition amendments return to an arrangement that the legal profession have told the government just will not work.

Government amendment No. 24 amended a previously circulated government amendment dealing with the arrangements for notifying the Health Insurance Commission about settlements or judgments which involve some apportionment of liability. The amendment was made on the basis of advice from the New South Wales Law Society that the previous amendment was not workable. Their advice was that, although it is usual for there to be some acknowledgment that some apportionment has taken place, it is not usual for that to be quantified in terms of the compensation amount.

The revised government amendment provides for the reduction due to apportionment of liability to be expressed in percentage terms only. While this would enable the Health Insurance Commission to deduce what the amount would have been, it would not require the parties to attest to a figure that did not really exist. Opposition amendment No. 3 requires the parties to state what the amount would have been if there was no apportionment or adjustment; that is, a return to an arrangement that the legal profession has told us will not work.

In all senses these amendments represent bad legislation. Technically, they are unworkable. In practice, they would hamper the ability of a government to administer and monitor the scheme but, more importantly, they provide an incentive for the parties to behave in an unprincipled manner. They give a legitimate debt to the taxpayers the same status as a wager at a casino. They virtually guarantee that every compensation case that goes to settlement will involve a reduction in the amount due to the taxpayer and this money will be pocketed by the insurance industry. This amounts to a sizeable ongoing subsidy from the taxpayer to the insurance industry.

The bill as it stands provides for some fair discounting of the Commonwealth's debt when there is some genuine sharing of liability. The government is not trying to evade that, but the opposition amendments create a dangerous and unworkable arrangement which encourages dishonesty and open manipulation of a genuine debt to the taxpayers. You have just given them at least $10 million by defeating the first bill. Think again, Senator.

She gabbled on through her briefing chart, which was given to her by her advisers. A lot of it was unrelated to the amendment I have moved. talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”I have great sympathy with what Senator Herron is trying to do. I understand that we still have some issues in this legislation that are certainly not clear cut. However, I am dealing with just Senator Herron's amendment No. 1â€”part (b) and the various interpretations that can be put on that.

para.tab: I saw these amendments yesterday for the first time. I would certainly have liked to have consulted further, particularly with the insurance industry, before moving to support them at this point. But I will say two things. The first relates to complexity. When the government indicated it really was serious about this problem and was about to do something about it, it set about collecting a lot of the details and the data we are now going to get as this proceeds. If we had had a decent database in the first place, we could now move directly to bulk-billing. We are 18 months down the track and we are going to have to wait another 18 months for the simpler solution to be put in place. Secondly, by now looking at these opposition amendments, I believe we are further muddying the waters and making this whole issue even more complex than I think it needs to be at this point.

I ask you, Minister: at this point, will you guarantee that we will have a review of where we are in 18 months time, as we get ready to move to the bulk-billing arrangements? In other words, if, when we have collected the data and we have had a look at what is happening and the problems, we do need any further legislative action, there will be a detailed consultation process with the industry, with all the players involved, so that we can come in here in the first instance, if necessary, with finished legislation in which we can have some confidence in?

talker.name: Senator CROWLEY
talker.role: Minister for Family Services)

talk.start.para: â€”I thank Senator Lees for her comments. As to your question at the end, I can very strongly give you the assurance that there will be that review and opportunity for extensive consultation.
â€”I would like to ask: when?
â€”Senator Lees did ask for in 18 months and 18 months is what I have given the assurance about.

â€”The assumptions made by the minister are that everybody is going to rort the system. She mentioned a hypothetical sum and then went forward and developed from that an argument that, somehow or another, the taxpayer was going to be affected by this and that this was a mechanism whereby the taxpayer would be affected because somebody was going to go in collusion. It is a classic example of not understanding what occurs out in the real world. It is all very well in this whoopeeland around here, but in reality, out there in the market, genuine arrangements are made between people to achieve a negotiated settlement. There is no collusion. It is a responsible attempt to achieve a compromise whereby compensation is achieved.

para.tab: It may be, of course, that people try to rort the system. That is reality too, but you cannot predicate legislation on the assumption that that is what will occur, and that is what you are doing. You are ignoring what occurs in civil law and occurs at present outside in the real world.

The principle is correct that the opportunity for negotiated settlement should occur, and it will occur. No matter what occurs in relation to this legislation, there will be people who accept lower compensation to avoid further legal costs. We were asking in this amendment that consideration be given to that to make it less onerous.

We do appreciate Senator Lees's request to you. As I said in my speech on the second reading debate, we in government would review it in 12 months time. I accept your assurance that in government it will be reviewed by you in 18 months time. I think that is a major step forward because of the absolute complexity of this.

Nobody knows at this stage, I suppose, what will occur in relation to the legislation. It is a leap in the dark, if you like, in terms of what is going to occur. We have had all these hypothetical figures produced in relation to the amount it will cost and the administration procedures. It is not, as you said, Minister, that we have degutted it by refusing to pass the levy. I thought it was adequately illustrated in the speeches of both me and Senator Lees that there were in fact gains to the Commonwealth by doing that because of the fact that the sum returned would be outweighed by the administrative costs. I still support my amendment.

talker.name: Senator CROWLEY
talker.role: Minister for Family Services)

talk.start.para: â€”I thank Senator Herron for his contribution. There is no intention to suggest that you are anything but honest in proposing these amendments and, indeed, there may be genuine and honest negotiations about settlements, but the Commonwealth is certainly not party to them, not present even at the part of the discussions. I think you would also have to allow that there is some understanding that some settlements in the insurance industry are not always honourable. There are plenty of examples of less than totally straightforward and direct compensation payouts.

para.tab: The main intention here is to make the legislation clear, and to make the obligations or responsibilities and liabilities of the insurance companies clear. That is why in the end the disagreement I would have with what you are proposing is that it is too open-ended, too vague, whereas the government's position is clearer. For those reasons, we will not be accepting the opposition's amendment.

talk.start.para: â€”I have listened to what the minister has said about this amendment. I acknowledge, of course, that there can be situations in which people may tend to enter into agreement, having in mind the effect that that might have on third parties. But I would inform the minister that I am just a bit worried that the fairly stringent opposition that the minister has to the proposal put forward by Senator Herron may, indeed, encourage persons not to settle.

para.tab: There is a problem in this particular area. I have known the area of compensation for years and years. As a trade union representative for many years, I have taken plenty of actions in these particular matters. It does occur to me that we should do everything possible to ensure that justice is done. We should also ensure that those who live by the system, including lawyers, are not encouraged to take matters to court where there can be a just and equitable settlement obtained by other peopleâ€”for example, union representatives on behalf of workers. I understand what the minister is saying, but I just raise that with her from a practical point of view.

talker.name: Senator CROWLEY
talker.role: Minister for Family Services)

talk.start.para: â€”Senator, the advice I have to provide to you is that there is very little reason to conclude, as you have done, that there would be a discouragement, under the government's legislation and amendments, to settlement. The important point to recognise is that the debt to the Commonwealth in the majority of cases is generally quite small, particularly as a percentage; therefore, it will not be a matter of discouragement of settlement.

para.tab: However, what we are concerned about is that a practice would be established so that, when there was a very significant debt to the Commonwealth, the same kind of arrangement might apply and that, therefore, there would be a significant loss. So, on the evidence we have, I do not think that the concern you have about an encouragement to not settle or a discouragement from settlement is likely to be the case.
Amendment negatived.

speech.speaker: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

talker.name: Senator CROWLEY
talker.role: Minister for Family Services)

debate.title: PUBLIC ORDER (PROTECTION OF PERSONS AND PROPERTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”The coalition does not oppose the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Amendment Bill. In fact, it supports the bill. There are just a couple of questions I would like to put in the committee stage. So I am happy, for the purposes of getting through these bills that are basically agreed on, to say no more than that. I will take the opportunity in the committee stage to ask the parliamentary secretary some questions.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you very much for your support. We will get into the committee stage as soon as we can.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

talk.start.para: â€”The question is quite a simple one. It relates to the delegation power of the authorisation power of the minister. I feel a sense of confidence that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would have raised this matter, although I have not had the opportunity to check the report. They usually do when someone has the power to appoint a person and there is no restriction on the categories of persons. I wonder whether you can confirm for me that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has done that and tell me what the government's response is to that.

para.tab: There is no disagreement on the policy of the bill. But if it is still in the form that it originally was, then I think that means the minister can appoint any Tom, Dick or Harry without any limitation at all. Minister, perhaps you could assist me in that respect. That is really the only question we want to tease out. We do not want to pursue it today. If it is a broad power to authorise, as I suspect it is, we just want to flag that we think it is inappropriate and that you should at some stageâ€”not that you will get the opportunity, because you will not be in government long enough to do itâ€”restrict the category of persons that the Attorney-General can authorise, or we will do it in a law and justice legislation amendment bill.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”It is, as you say, a broad power. The adviser is not aware that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has made any statement of concern. I am not sure whether you are still a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee but I, being a former member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, do understand the importance. We do not know whether it has been commented on or not. I can get you a response on that matter later.

â€”I thank the minister. Of course, that raises another point. I intend no disrespect to the adviser who is assisting you today, but the government should be aware of it. You might argue that I should also be aware of it, but at least I have thought, `What has the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said?' I am querying you, and you are a member of the government. Frankly, you ought to know. But there is no point having an argument about it, since we were not planning on moving an amendment to remedy the problem at this stage.

para.tab: Some might consider it a minor problem but if you believe, as I do, that one of the great protections of our system is that the processes are followed and through that, that checks and balances pick up the problems, you and I would be postponing this bill. The nature of the bill and the protection it seeks to provide to the community outweighs the concerns we might have about the importance of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I am happy to leave it at that and, if no-one has anything else to say, we might as well move to the third reading.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I agree with the comments about the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I will make sure those comments are passed on to the officer from the department and the minister.
