Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

debate.title: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT AND REPEAL BILL 1995

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: â€”Today we have before us the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment and Repeal Bill. This is a matter which, by way of good housekeeping, gives attention to administrative changes and anomalies. As the former shadow minister for veterans' affairs, it has been made very clear to me that it is an area in which one constantly finds anomalies. They can be of great importance to a handful of individuals. It is often quite a long time before the bureaucracy and the government recognise the importance of doing something about them.

para.tab: I am glad to see the removal of anomalies in this legislation. I am glad to see that they are being attended to. I would not want the Senate to think that this was the be-all and end-all. I visited an ex-servicemen's club only last week, and they presented me with a list of more anomalies that need attention. I have now handed that list to the shadow minister, Mr Tuckey. Mr Tuckey has consulted widely on this piece of legislation before us today. As a result, the opposition is pleased to support the bill.

This bill does a number of things by way of minor amendments to a large amount of legislation covering veterans' affairs. Although the changes are small, there are some which are welcome, including the extension of the remote area allowance to veterans living on Norfolk and Lord Howe islands. Other amendments relate to assessments of service pension and income support supplements. They include the calculation of child related payments andâ€”I think this is of particular importanceâ€”rent assistance for certain blind pensioners as well as for certain war widows and war widows in receipt of a frozen rate of service pension. Those arrangements that have been in place until now have long been inequitable. I am very glad to see that change.

There are also amendments covering participation in local exchange trading systems as well as allowing the carers of service pensioners accompanying veterans overseas to keep receiving their carers' pension for up to three months of their absence from Australia. The bill also sets a closing date of 30 November 1994 for Somalia as an operational area. That has been an operational area for veterans' entitlements purposes since 20 October 1992.

The bill repeals two actsâ€”the War Service Homes Agreement Act 1932 and the War Service Homes (South Australia) Agreement Act 1934, which have apparently both served their useful purpose and we do not object to their repeal. A feature of any debate on veterans' affairs in the Senate or in the other place during this year has been the unanimous support across political lines for the Australia Remembers program. I am obviously more than happy to endorse that program, especially as I am the wife of a veteran.

The 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War has been a special moment in the history of this country. It is an opportunity for the generation who fought the war to reflect on their experiences and to remember those who gave their lives for the country. It is also an opportunity for us to reflect on that service. It is very much an opportunity for later generations to gain an insight into something which we hope they never have to experienceâ€”the horrors of war.

I have been particularly pleased about the number of schools and schoolchildren who have been involved in the Australia Remembers project because I think that shows a recognition by schools that war service is an important area of Australian history for children to learn about. That has not been the case in past generations. It gives those Australians who have enjoyed the fruits of peace an appreciation of how peace was won and how it has not always been the natural state of affairs in this world of ours.

It is worth noting, as did the Yale historian Donald Kagan in his book
On the Origins of War
, that:

speech.para: Over the past two centuries the only thing more common than predictions about the end of war has been war itself.
Kagan said that in the last 3,421 years only 268 have been free of war and none of those years have been since 1968.

para.tab: Just as we have a duty to remember the sacrifice of a previous generation and to care for the veterans of those earlier wars, as this legislation is doing, we must also be conscious of what we can do to prevent another major conflict, as we had with the Second World War. The best way to ensure that another generation of Australians is never subjected to the horror and hardships of war which we have remembered this year is to make sure that we are seen as having a strong defence capability. Deterrent is very much the best way to maintain the peace. We must be able to send a signal to would-be aggressors that Australia is ready and willing to defend its territory and its citizens at home and abroad. Our message has to be that we can defend ourselves and defend ourselves well so that any attack on Australia would be a futile exercise.

I am concerned that the current government, while celebrating Australia Remembers, has actually forgotten what the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War is all about. It is very timely for a commemoration of what that brave generation achieved. We sent many of those men away ill-trained and ill-equipped. We must never do that to young Australians again. This should be a year for us all to declare never again to put young serving people in that position. We should focus in a practical way on what we can do now in making wise decisions to build on the hard won gains of earlier generations and to maintain the peace for us and for our region. I commend the bill to the Senate.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the opposition for its support on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment and Repeal Bill 1995. As Senator Newman has outlined and as contained in the second reading speech in reasonable detail, the bill rectifies anomalies in certain assessments of service pension and income support, matters relating to child related payments, rent assistance for certain blind pensioners, carers of service pensioners who accompany a veteran overseas, remote area allowances and a number of other matters such as the operational area closing date in Somalia. These are small but important and significant changes to those people who are affected by the legislation.

para.tab: I do not agree with Senator Newman that we have forgotten what the 50th anniversary is all about. I think all credit should go to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) for the Australia Remembers celebration of the end of the war in the Pacific. I notice that yesterday he received life membership of the RSL in recognition of the tremendous work he did in the Australia Remembers area. I was with Minister Sciacca on a number of occasions socially. In the middle of the occasions I was with him, his mobile phone would ring or a staff member would come up and start talking to him about arrangements for Australia Remembers. I have never seen a minister devote so much time and energy to a part of their portfolio responsibilities as Con Sciacca. The minister deserves recognition, as the RSL has done, for his tremendous efforts in this area.

Having said that, I endorse the remarks that Senator Newman made about reflecting on our experiences and what we learnt from World War IIâ€”and the other wars that have occurred in Australia's pastâ€”and, particularly, from the end of the war in the Pacific. It was also very pleasing to me to see many of our schools joining in the various remembrance activities with such enthusiasm. I think that is very important. War should not be remembered for war's sake, but we should certainly reflect on the causes and the outcomes of war. I think the Australia Remembers campaign gave very appropriate recognition to our various service personnel. My father served in the merchant navy from 1939 to, I think, the late 1940s and it certainly made me think a little more deeply about some of the experiences he has talked to me about. I thank the opposition for their support on the legislation.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”The purpose of the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1995 is to provide a late payment component of the superannuation levy calculated for months commencing in the period between the time the superannuation fund was due to lodge a return and when it was actually lodged. Superannuation fund trustees may be requested to pay two componentsâ€”a basic component and, if it is lodged late, a late lodgment penalty. Honourable senators may be aware that in 1992 the basic levy was increased very substantially to cover the enhanced prudential requirements. Also, this basic component of the levy has two elements itself, a lodgment fee and an amount based on the total of the funds.

para.tab: There is a lodgment fee of $300 for unit trusts. In addition, there is a levy of $200 per $500,000 of investments or part of $500,000 of assets held by the fund. This late lodgment fee is payable where the period of grace has expired and a return is due to be lodged. The period of grace currently provides that the late payment penalty will not apply where the return is made and the basic levy amount is paid within 14 days commencing on the day after the levy was payable.

The late payment levy is currently payable for each levy month that commences after the expiration of the period of grace until the return is lodged and the levy paid. The amendment contained in this bill before the Senate will remove the exception for any month that commences during the period of grace so that the late payment levy will be payable in respect of each month that commences after the date of lodgment rather than for months commencing after the end of the period of grace. So, according to the explanatory memorandum of the bill, the change is expected to have no impact on revenue.

I had a look at the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, the Hon. Paul Elliott, when this bill was introduced into the House of Representatives. I noticed that, in the very short two-page speech, there was only one paragraphâ€”and that was the final paragraphâ€”that actually related to the bill itself. The rest of the speech related to superannuation in general. That provides a precedent and the opportunity to range a bit more widely than the particular portion of the bill, which is effectively a very small component. My colleague the shadow minister responsible for the legislation, Mr Connolly, did exactly that.

It is significant that, this afternoon, the Commissioner of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is holding a function to say farewell to a very distinguished member of the commission, Mr Ron Dean, Deputy Commissioner of the Superannuation Group. Mr Dean is retiring after an illustrious career of some 47 years in the Public Service. He will retire on 29 September. It is appropriate that there is a function at the Canberra International Hotel this afternoon. I have been privileged to be invited to attend that particular function, which will farewell Ron and wish him a happy retirement. Indeed, 47 years is a long time and I must pay tribute to him. He has contributed significantly to the development of superannuation. He was at the commission from its inception. I place on the public record my appreciation of his contribution.

Mr Elliott also referred to some of the achievements of the government. One of those achievements was to embark on a public education campaign to promote the benefits of superannuation savings for retirement. The government actually set aside $12.5 million for this. While it is true that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation recommended that additional funds be set aside for the purpose of education, I am a little worried about the bias of this particular campaign. As I read it, it has an overly political flavour and I think this is unfortunate. I think what really was required was a proper educative campaign so that people are not only aware of the benefits of superannuation but are also aware of the responsibilities and other issues that are associated with superannuation. If there is to be a second or further addition, I would hope that the political flavour is somewhat more removed than what we have seen to date.

It would be unfortunate if the government used superannuation as an election tool in the next six months. Superannuation is certainly for the long term and during an election fever all sorts of promises are made. Superannuation must be examined more critically and more carefully than would the case in a lead-up to an election when rash promises are often made. I certainly hope that the gains that have been made in relation to superannuation for the benefit of the Australian taxpayer can be sustained and that superannuation is not turned into a political issue.

What has happened in superannuation is that this government has what I term privatised public pensions. In other words, it has largely been put across to the public sector. While there have undoubtedly been winners in the long term, there have certainly been losers, and one of the losers has been the low income earner. I think we are expecting a little too much from superannuation. Certainly, the Liberal side of politics is very keen to look at alternative savings vehicles and I think this is the right approach. While it is essential that there be very strong prudential controls in relation to superannuation, I think these other savings vehicles could suit the needs of low income earners and others. Perhaps a one size fits all approach may provide the sort of flexibility that is needed.

The opposition supports this legislation but it is very conscious of the need to extend the coverage of superannuation and, at the same time, keep costs down. In the process, I think it is necessary that there be mechanisms not only to ensure the prudential security of the funds which are being well established at the present time but also to ensure that people do not get locked in indefinitely to poorly performing funds. If this is to be the case, we have to have mechanisms which will encourage the merger of funds and provide easier opportunities at appropriate times for people to move from one fund to another.

I am a great supporter of the concept of portability of superannuation, something that tends to follow you round. While exit fees certainly are coming down in personal superannuation, they are, unfortunately, still a problem. Nevertheless, there are situations where it is difficult for certain people, when changing jobs, to exit from certain industry funds. I think this is unfortunate and certainly needs to be looked at.

I will not take any more of the Senate's time because we have other important legislation coming up which I would like to see quickly passed by the Senate. I refer to the necessary amendments to enable the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to hear medical evidence as from 1 November this year. I support the legislation.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I have a few concluding remarks in picking up some of the comments that Senator Watson has touched on, and I am cognisant of the time factor here today. Prior to Senator Watson obtaining the position as chair of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, I held the position. I have always acknowledged that Senator Watson has played a commendable, generally bipartisanâ€”as bipartisan as one can get in politicsâ€”role in this superannuation debate and in the various issues that have been discussed.

para.tab: On the issue of extending the coverage of superannuation, I am glad to hear the coalition is interested in doing this. This government has a commendable record of extending coverage from less than 40 per cent a decade ago when superannuation was generally the preserve of those with higher income, and generally excluded low income workers, women, part-timers and casuals in this country. We have seen the coverage grow, as a consequence of our policies, to over 90 per cent of Australian employees. I think the last area of coverage that has to be addressed is the sole business operator. Many of them have personal superannuation but many do not because they often regard their business as a form of superannuation.

In the area of costs, the industry funds generally have offered a very cost-effective and appropriate mechanism for efficient administration of superannuation savings. There have been criticisms of personal products, but there have been significant reforms in this area to keep pressures on costs.

Senator Watson's suggestion about the merger of funds is one I support. My personal view is that the government should be more pro-active in this area, particularly where we have illogical artificial funds, in the sense that we have a number of hospitality funds, and there is not a rationale for having separate funds. That does not necessarily lead to better returns; whether you have got one large fund or 10 small ones, it does not necessarily mean that the returns will be better. The critical issue is that the trustees are doing their job and, if the areas where they are investing the money are not showing an appropriate return, they should change the mix of investment. This is where the role of trustees is critical.

Senator Watson referred to the losers being people on lower incomes. I am not sure what Senator Watson means because our policy is very clear; we preserve the basic old age pension, as it is known. The pension is the minimum safety net and anything in addition that has contributed to the various superannuation funds is over and above, subject to means testing. It is not the government's intentionâ€”I say this on most occasions that I speak on this issueâ€”to do away with the basic pension. The issue of superannuation addresses a number of fundamental issues, including the ageing population and the issue of the savings of this country. This country's savings is a very important issue in relation to debt, but I am not going to go into that today.

I join you, Senator Watson, in recognising the service of Mr Ron Dean. I got to know him reasonably well in my role as chair of the superannuation committee and, like you, Senator Watson, he is a person who has made a very significant contribution over a number of years.

The public education campaign on superannuation is money well spent. Senator Watson points out that the members of our committeeâ€”the Senate Select Committee on Superannuationâ€”unanimously called for such a campaign. Consumer groups and the industry itself have all been asking for a public awareness campaign and this is what the government is undertaking.

talk.start.para: â€”There is just perhaps too much of a political bias, that's all.

â€”From where you sit it might have a political bias, but from where I sit it is a fair fact that has to be communicated to the public on such a critical public policy. I know, Senator Watson, that you have approached this subject in a bipartisan, reasonable and fair way. This government's superannuation changesâ€”even though there have been difficulties at times with the pace of the changeâ€”are one of the most fundamental, widespread and important reform measures that this government has undertaken. As I said earlier, it is a very important area not only because of the ageing population and the need to ensure we have sufficient savings to pay adequate retirement incomes but also because of the need to tackle the savings issue.

para.tab: Senator Watson, I hate to end on a slight discord, but we on this side look forward to seeing the opposition's policy. I know there has been a little bit of a fracas in your ranks over who has got responsibility, but we look forward to seeing this policy as we look forward to seeing your other policies. It is not reasonable or fair to the people of this country that all your policiesâ€”except for industrial relations and airport noiseâ€”are to be released in the four weeks in the lead-up to the campaignâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”What has this got to do with superannuation?
â€”I am looking forward to the superannuation; that is what it has got to do with. Policies need public scrutiny.
â€”We are looking forward to lunch if you are ever going to finish.
â€”There is another bill to go, as well. I am not speaking any longer than Senator Watson and I am addressing the issues he raised. With that, I conclude my remarks.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak on the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1995. The bill gives effect to the agreements which were made at the Premiers Conference on 11 April this year regarding the provision of general revenue assistance to the states and territories. It also allows for the adoption of the per capita relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission and amends the States Grants (General Purposes) Act l994 to ensure that the arterial road grant level will increase in line with the CPI and population growth in the same manner as financial assistance grants. The bill is part of the important link which exists between Commonwealth, state and territory governments. We are all aware that the Commonwealth has the greater share of taxation revenue.

para.tab: In formulating the outcome of the bill, a key role was played by the Commonwealth Grants Commission, which is required to deal with the issue of per capita relativities as a measure of the relative needs of the states and territories. In arriving at an outcome, the Commonwealth Grants Commission is charged with the responsibility of deciding on the level of expenditure required to provide a standard level of service. The general revenue assistance comes in three categories: financial assistance grants; special revenue assistance grants; and identified roads grants. Since 1991-92 Commonwealth funding of local roads, which was classified as special purpose payments, is now provided as general revenue assistance to be used as the states see fit.

In looking at the bill in the short time we have today, the opportunity should not be lost to bring home to the government a few home truths about their lopsided approach to providing financial assistance to states and territories. The level of general revenue assistance is estimated to be $15.074 billion in 1994-95 and $15.713 billion in l995-96. On the face of it, the government has claimed that this represents an increase of 4.21 per cent over the last year. As usual, they fail to say there will be no increase in real terms if inflation runs at three per cent and the population increase is around 1.2 per cent.

Of further concern is the fact that the government has chosen to raise its own expenditure from $81.988 billion in l993-94 to $88.092 billion in l994-95. This is an increase of $6.1 billion, or seven per cent. Overall the Commonwealth has increased its own expenditure by 2.5 per cent in real terms whilst continuing to squeeze the states and territories. History shows that under this Labor government there has been an ongoing decline in the level of payments by the Commonwealth to state and territory governments. In my own state, since this Labor government has been in power we are about $400 million worse off in real terms than we were when they came into power.

The government has chosen to increase its own outlays as a proportion of the total budget outlay by 11 per cent rising from 66.8 per cent in 1983-84 to 74.2 per cent in 1995-96. At the same time, there has been a contrasting 22 per cent fall in the total payments to states and territories from 33.1 per cent to 25.6 per cent for the same period. The fiscal imbalance is also of concern and it has been caused by this government through its blatant abuse of section 96 tied grants. The level of tied grants has increased by over 37 per cent since 1983-84, severely restricting the ability of the state and territory governments to deal with their financial commitments.

Another myth about the Labor government which this bill exposes is its horrendous record in relation to taxation. This bill projects an increase in the government's taxation revenue from $105.304 billion in 1994-95 to $119.261 billion in 1995-96, an increase of a massive $13.957 billion. Whilst the government is going to slug the long suffering Australian taxpayer almost $14 billion only 1.4 billion of those dollars will be passed on to the states. This leaves the states with a serious financial disadvantage in that their ability to raise taxation revenue is seriously limited by the $14 billion slug of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), yet the government continues to tighten restrictions which apply to the states in terms of how they may use their money.

Before I leave this bill, I want to draw the Senate's attention again to the greed of this government in relation to the long suffering motorist. Of the 33c which this government collects in fuel tax, only 7c is returned to the road network. In other words, 26c goes into the government's coffers. The rest is used to prop up the government and its lavish spending programs. Let there be no mistakeâ€”this is a high tax, big spending government bill which, in the long run, does little to provide meaningful assistance to the states and territories and even less to remove the terrible taxation burden which rests on the shoulders of the Australian community.

talk.start.para: â€”As Senator Calvert outlined, the purpose of the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1995 is to give effect to the arrangements that were agreed at the Premiers Conference on 11 April 1995. The areas that are being considered under general purposes are areas which were outlined quite accurately by Senator Calvert.

para.tab: I do not share Senator Calvert's expressed concern that the level of tied grants has risen over recent years. In fact, a number of people from my electorate have told me that they would actually prefer tied grants to come from the Commonwealth, because they can see the purpose for which the money is intended and they are able to monitor whether it is actually expended in that area. The general impression given to me is that people would rather see the Commonwealth government give money to an area where the state government is unable to hide it in some other hollow logs or, in the case of Tasmania, grant a 40 per cent pay increase to members of parliament in that state. This is a matter of great contention and resentment in my electorate in Tasmania.

In regard to the question of priorities, some would argue that matters that directly concern state governments are best left to the state governments. Of course, others argue that there is more opportunity for state governments to be influenced by vested interests, who take away the opportunity for real needs to be met.

I appreciate that this is a general purposes states grants amendment bill, but I am going to take this opportunity to suggest that the area of greatest need that has been brought to my attention in recent daysâ€”and is consistent with my concerns for many yearsâ€”is the area of education.

One of the expressions to me about tied grants came from my attendance at the Tasmanian State School Parents and Friends Association's annual meeting recently in Tasmania. The feeling that education was not being well funded and properly funded, from either a state or Commonwealth government perspective, was unanimous and the belief that it was the responsibility of government, no matter what sort, to recognise the obligation to properly fund education was also unanimous. To take this opportunity to speak during the passage of a general purposes states grants bill is not something that I think I should apologise for when I believe that most senators would have received communications such as the letter that I just opened as I came in.

It is a letter from the Tumby Bay Area School, Tumby Bay, South Australia. They wrote to me expressing their concern that the director of the education centre for the western area had informed the writer of the letter, who is the chairperson of the Tumby Bay Area School council, that Commonwealth funding to the centre would be discontinued from January 1997. The education centre is in Whyalla and is a leader of the professional development of teachers in the area. That is not an isolated letter.

Other senators would probably have received bundles similar to the one that I have with me, which is addressed variously to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) and others. We have been included in these correspondences because of the frustration of people who are concerned about the closure of such education centres.
To me, that is something that we should be taking notice of, rather than just passing glibly over.

I also have a letter from the Parents and Friends Association from Tasman District High School at Nubeena in Tasmania. They write expressing their concern about cutbacks in teacher numbers, the inequity between funding for primary and secondary schools, larger class sizes, reduced curriculum choice in high schools and colleges, loss of many state school sports programs, the closing of many community based libraries, the lack of specialist teachers and guidance officers, and education expenditure which is ranked low in the rating of OECD countries.

These people are not particularly concerned with the niceties of whether it is a state or a federal government obligation which is not being met. What they know is that the obligation is being avoided. They see that, because there was the opportunity to fund particular programsâ€”and there were eight programs listed from Nubeenaâ€”and all they see are the programs disappearing. Therefore, they would not be concerned if it was a tied grant from the Commonwealth which said, `This money must be spent on a school sport program,' or `This money must be spent on a library program.' That would not be their concern, but they would be pleased to see the obligation being met.

The trouble is, as I have said several times in this chamber, that, when these obligations are not met by governments, they have to be met by somebody and the temptation for many school councils is to accept the offer from private sponsors. I see a great deal of threat in those offerings because what we see is that sponsors who enter the education field are there, of course, to promote their corporate wellbeing and to eventually derive some benefit from it. Philanthropy is not very common in our modern society and it is very hard to find.

I am reminded of a cartoon which I saw in the
Herald-Sun
a couple of days ago. It had a blackboard, it had Einstein wandering off to the left and he had left behind, in his fairly recognisable scrawl, E=MC squared. The `M' in this case was the `golden arches' M and the `C' was in the form of a very small `c' as you would see in `Mc'. The punch line of the cartoon read `Education equals a Big Mac?' and underneath was written: `Sponsorship of education facilities by fast food outlets has been going on for years.' I think that is a very telling cartoon, as many cartoons are, and it gives us the message in a way that shows what we really need to be wary of. That is, that where governments do not recognise their responsibilities, they leave a gap which will be filled by those who would like to call the tune; by those who would like to determine what sort of education is provided and what sorts of values our schools inculcate in the students.

I use this opportunity to suggest that concern about tied grants is not a concern that is held by the people who talk to me. As a matter of fact, a lot of people would prefer to see Commonwealth money coming in to meet the needs which are not being met by state governments which, quite frankly, have agendas and priorities which do not serve education well. With that, I make no further comment on the bill. The Democrats will be supporting it.

speech.speaker: Ellison Sen C.M.

talk.start.para: â€”The purpose of this States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1995 is for general revenue assistance to the states and territories for 1995 and 1996. As such, it is one of the tools of our federation and it is used to return to the states some of the balance resulting from the government's continuing mismanagement of Commonwealth-state relations. I will refer to that shortly.

para.tab:
Suffice it to say that the bill gives effect to certain arrangements agreed to at the Premiers Conference held on 11 April this year. Those arrangements included the maintenance of the real per capita guarantee for financial assistance grants in 1995-96 and the adoption of the per capita relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in its
Report on general revenue grant relativities 1995: an update
to determine the 1995-96 distribution of the financial assistance grants and hospital funding grants. As such, as Senator Calvert mentioned, the bill deals with financial assistance grants, special revenue assistance grants and identified road grants.

An aspect which I wish to raise today is the more general question relating to the financial relations between the states and the Commonwealth. In this regard, it is worth while to look at some history. In 1901 specific powers were vested in the Commonwealth and they were set out in section 51 of the constitution. These involved such areas as overseas trade, currency, defence, external affairs, customs and excise and so on. In relation to the states, the reserve powers were left for the states and they numbered such matters as roads, law and order, health and matters of that sort. Since 1901 the Commonwealth powers have grown immensely, and normally at the expense of the responsibilities of the states. Such means as tied grants have been a useful mechanism for the Commonwealth to increase its powers. This is where such legislation as the bill before us has relevance.

I might just point to statistics from 1901-02 which reveal that the Commonwealth received 58 per cent of revenue at that time whilst the states received 42 per cent. That is, the states received nearly half the revenue in the country. Of that total amount, the Commonwealth government spent only 13 per cent compared to 87 per cent by the states. Basically, at federation the states provided most of the services to the people of Australia. By 1992-93, however, the Commonwealth received 75 per cent of revenue whilst the states received only 25 per cent. Of this, the Commonwealth spent 54 per cent compared to 46 per cent by the states. In other words, the Commonwealth, since federation, has increased its revenue by roughly 50 per cent but on the other hand has increased its share of spending by 300 per cent.

That is where you see an interesting figure in relation to this bill. You see that the revenue assistance here to the states has increased by 4.2 per cent since last year whilst the Commonwealth has increased its own purpose outlays seven per cent. That is, the increase the Commonwealth has afforded to itself over the last year exceeds inflation whilst the increase afforded to the states merely matches inflation or would be slightly in front. I would estimate that the increase that is given in the revenue assistance grants really counts for nought when measured against inflation.

The aspect of tied grants, which Senator Bell touched on, indicates just how dependent the states have become in relation to the Commonwealth government. In 1972-73, 26 per cent of the states' money from the Commonwealth came from tied grants. Twenty-one years later, in 1995-96, this had doubled to 54.8 per cent. That is, the tied grants had doubled in the space of some 20-odd years. These are grants which the Commonwealth gives to a state and says, `There is a condition attached. There are strings attached to this grant. You can have the money but you can't necessarily spend it on anything that we don't want you to spend it on.' That is the gist of tied grants.

A current example is the tied grant dealing with coastal care. The Commonwealth provided a national grant of $26 million over four years for coastal care around the various states. Attached to that grant was the requirement by the Commonwealth that the states not carry out capital works such as jetties or groynes. This is despite the states and local councils having to match Commonwealth expenditure with $2 for each Commonwealth dollar granted. I put it to the Senate that that is a vivid example of how tied grants have worked.

We have to ask ourselves, when we look at these states grants general purposes bills and legislation which we face each year, what is being done to rectify this federal imbalance. Are we to continue to face the coercive form of federalism that this government enjoys, or are we to operate under a cooperative system of federalism, where the states cooperate not only with each other but with the Commonwealth government? I would suggest that it is entirely in the interests of the Australian people that federation be based on cooperation and not coercion. In his headland speech in Canberra on 6 June 1995, John Howard stated:

speech.para: In government, the coalition will allocate a fixed percentage of the tax revenue to the states. We will revert to the practice of former coalition governments of winding back section 96 for specific grants to the states. That will mean the states themselves will have greater freedom of choice when deciding their progress and priority.

You could not be more detailed about policy than that. That is a clear statement to the people of Australia that the coalition will embark upon a principle of cooperative federalism; that is, that the coalition in government will wind back the system of tied grants, Senator Sherry, and that we will revert to a form of federation that our founding fathers foreshadowed and looked forward to in 1901.

talk.start.para: â€”Today we are debating the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1995. As Senator Ellison has just been saying, this bill highlights the importance of the financial relationship between the federal, state and territory governments. Grants are of great importance to the states and territories, which have limited means of raising their own incomeâ€”unlike the all-encompassing income tax regime which is the domain of the federal government.

para.tab: General revenue assistance to the states is estimated at $15.713 billion in this financial year, and the main form of this assistance is the financial assistance grants, or untied grants, which will amount to $14.857 billion in 1995-96. However, there are other forms of grants: namely, special revenue assistance grants which supplement basic general revenue assistance, and identified road grants. The last of these, the identified road grants, is one aspect that I wish to dwell on today.

I have been approached on many occasions over a long period of timeâ€”almost 11 years in this Senateâ€”by people in very remote parts of Western Australia, metropolitan Perth, and, more recently, the state Minister for Transport, Mr Eric Charlton. All of these people have been very concerned about the lack of road funding in real terms that is coming back to Western Australia. Mr Charlton has led a vigorous campaign to secure more road funding in Western Australia to help maintain and develop arterial roads in our state. The fact of the matter is, when it comes to this government, that campaign is hitting a brick wall. The funding has been going down all the time while the income for the federal government has been going up.

Of particular concern to me is section 15 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994 which ties road funding to compulsory student unionism. To the casual onlooker, anyone would say that the two have no relativity whatsoever. When it comes to this government, it is a nice little piece of blackmail that was brought in last year and we are paying the price in Western Australia day by day.

In short, if a person allows students the choice to join a student union or guild, then in return from the government they can expect road funding to be cut. That is a scandal. The extra money will go to help the guilds that have been turned into voluntary student guilds make up their shortfall in the membership dues following the departure of many of those students with the freedom of choice that the state Liberal government has provided.

I have spoken about this issue before. It is one which concerns not only me and my Western Australian colleagues but also many students and young people in Western Australia. It is more far reaching than that because the flow-on effect then affects the drivers and the quality of roads that they have to drive on.

A number of my colleagues in the lower House have also raised their concerns and those of Mr Charlton, the minister, in the course of debates in that chamber, but all to no avail. The government will not listen. They will not untie those grants. They will not stop robbing Peter to pay Paul. Nothing has changed. I certainly take the opportunity to repeat the concerns I have made about road funding in my state of Western Australia.

One of the electoral platforms of the Western Australian state government was its commitment to voluntary student unionism. It is something the majority of people in my state expect, but what no-one realised was that the price for that freedom of choice was a ransom note from the federal government stating that the price for that freedom was going to be a cutback in road funding, with the extra funds going to prop up the student guilds. They have long served as a nursery for the Labor Party and a training ground for the young Labor hacks.

talk.start.para: â€”A very good one, too.

â€”It is disgusting, Senator Sherry, that you are prepared to agree that it is a training ground for your Labor Party hacks. You are nodding away there. You have just acknowledged your agreement that that is the sole purpose of these guilds and yet you take away the road funding and give it to your little mates, the hacks. It is just like the ACTU, and Joan Kirner coming out today and admitting that the ACTU is an arm of the Labor Party. Yet the government gives them millions and millions of dollars in taxpayers' money so that it can then come back to it by way of a donation from the ACTU at election time. It is a very cute way of funding campaigns.

para.tab: Here we are with another example of the way in which taxpayers' money is being manipulated to the detriment of the general taxpayer in Western Australia. It is a very sly way of eroding the powers of the states, diminishing their power to raise revenue and robbing them of their ability to manage their own affairs in the true spirit of federalism. It constitutes a gross mismanagement of Commonwealth-state relations.

Western Australia has 25 per cent of the length of the national highway. You would imagine that a federal government would be concerned about thatâ€”but not this federal government. The state government estimates that $139 million will be needed each year over the next 10 years to maintain those highways, while an extra $145 million will be needed each year to meet the demands of new road networks. A firm commitment to road funding from the federal government is important, but it is one that we simply cannot expect.

Western Australia is, after all, a rapidly expanding state. Perth is one of the fastest growing state capitals, second only to Brisbane. Western Australia contains the fastest growing municipality in Australia: namely, the city of Wanneroo, in the northern corridor of the Perth metropolitan area. With the state's population continuing to grow and the number of road users increasing, the wear and tear on our roads will also increase. In the next 10 years, 30 per cent of Western Australian roads will be due for replacement.

It stands to reason that that is going to require a huge capital outlay. But it seems that the members of this government are more intent on spending the extra money on propping up student unionsâ€”now, while they canâ€”because they know that, come the next election, they will not be there to fund those student unions any longer. It will be up to a coalition government to ensure that there is a return to proper road funding throughout Australia and, particularly, in Western Australia.

Equally, this government is not interested in a more equitable return for fuel excises. I will just go through a few of the figures that are part of the alleged commitment to not increase taxes that was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in 1993. Prior to the last election, fuel exciseâ€”a taxâ€”was 26.2c a litre. By February 1994, less than 12 months later, it was 30.75c for unleaded fuel and 31.75c for leaded fuel. This is from a government that promised not to increase taxes. It went from 26.2c to 31.75c in less than 12 months. Of course, in February this year it climbed to 32.5c for unleaded and 34.57c per litre for leaded. This, once again, is from a government that promised not to increase taxes. That is a tax. Fuel excise it nothing but a tax.

But the return to the states' road funds has not reflected any of that increase at all. Who knows what this extra revenue will be spent on? It certainly will not be spent on the national highway system, and it certainly is not coming back to Western Australia. Of course, Western Australia deserves a fair share of that increase in fuel excise, because of the sheer distances that Western Australians have to travel. But, instead, the federal government tells the states they will have to be content with a 7c per litre return from the tax grab at the petrol bowsers.

Remember that it was this Labor Party that opposed the introduction of fuel excise in the first place. They said it was just another tax at the bowser. Well, they have had their snouts in the trough ever since. They have just been increasing it and making sure that the average motorist thinks that it is the fuel companies that have increased the price of petrol. The difference is made up by the people of the stateâ€”through other levies, excises, taxes and chargesâ€”but it is the federal government which erects the massive, green and gold `federally funded road project' signs.

Those signs absolutely make many people cringe. They see the quality of their roads deteriorating, they know they are paying more taxes and charges and they know they are paying more fuel tax every time they fill up their cars at the bowser. Yet this federal government has got the gall and audacity to erect huge green and gold signs saying that any road work is being federally funded.

I know I am not the only one who cringes at these, because of the number of complaints that I get from constituents who simply say, `If the federal government is not returning the money, why should it have the joy of erecting these signs?' It is offensive, it is misleading and it should be stopped. But the only way it will be stopped will be by this mob being thrown out at the next election.

At least they are a sign that roads are being repaired or created but who is paying the bill? That is the question. The fewer of these signs we see, the more obvious it will be that less and less money is being spent on road maintenance. Or perhaps we will be able to read into that that the student unions on Western Australian university campuses will be getting the spoils. It is encouraging that there has been a noticeable improvement in road safety in Western Australia in recent years but that is not thanks to the federal Labor government: that is because the Western Australian state government has been allocating more and more funds from the state budget. However, Western Australia cannot go on meeting the shortfall on its own.

Unfortunately, once our roads begin to get run down, a lot of related costs will blow out. Good roads provide economic development, employment, environmental protection and reduction in road trauma. If the roads fall into ruin then costs related to these areas will also be forced up. Road accidents already cost Western Australia $900 million per annum, despite improvements in road safety. And when so many Western Australian roads are in remote and desolate parts of the state, it is a major concern that the safety of outback road users may be compromised by a `couldn't care less' federal Labor government and its obstinacy and reluctance to come to the party in terms of providing Western Australia with its fair share of funds.

It is very symptomatic of a government which is acting deliberately to penalise the people who live in states where there is a Liberal government by making it almost impossible for the state government to deliver the best infrastructure and services to the people. It is grossly unfair. It is a deliberate ploy by this federal government to cut off the water to Liberal state governments. While the Labor government goes about investing in its own future, looking after its young mates and its young turks in universities, in student guild offices all around the country, road users will continue to suffer as they see less and less of their money invested in roads. Unless we fix the roads, we will be in a very dangerous situation, very quickly.

This matter does not concern this Labor government. It is absolutely and utterly blase about road safety. The fact that it would squander taxpayers' money on its mates in student unions is absolutely appalling. I think the people of Western Australia and the people in the other Liberal states deserve a better go. It is interesting that Senator Collins, who comes from the Northern Territoryâ€”a remote territoryâ€”does not agree with what I am saying. He does not seem to careâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”How do you know?
â€”He just shook his head in disagreement with what I was saying. That is how I know.
â€”I don't know what you are saying.

â€”You shook your head. You did not agree with what I was saying, that the more remote states should get more of the federal cake back that they have already contributed to in road funding. If Senator Collins does not agree with that, then he is not representing his territory. He is meant to be a senator for the Northern Territory. Why does he not represent its interests?
â€”You are just making things up.
â€”You should start putting that money back that the people of the states are putting in and send it back for road funding and not for your mates in student unions.
â€”Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise when it met in Sydney was advised by Air Services Australia that Simops, or cross-runway operations, `procedures are currently used on a regular basis at Adelaide, Darwin, Melbourne and Perth in accordance with established procedures'. Does this mean, to quote the minister's own words in the Senate yesterday, that the government, at Adelaide, Darwin, Melbourne and Perth, is being criminally irresponsible?

â€”No, all it demonstrates is that the coalition, and Mr Howard in particular, realises what a completely loopy proposition he put in his instant policy formation off the top of his head. To even compare the traffic movements at those airports with Sydney is a piece of nonsense.
â€”I wouldn't say that if I were you.

â€”Senator, the traffic movements at Tullamarineâ€”unless they have changed dramatically in the last 12 months, and I do not think they haveâ€”are about half, or less than half, those at Sydney airport. With regard to Darwin airport, yes, as I know full well, Simops are used at Darwin airport for Piper aircraft on the crossing runway, not for jets.
â€”The crashes are different, are they?
â€”I beg your pardon?
â€”He doesn't know the difference between a jet and a Piper.

â€”Senator Ian Macdonald asks me, by way of interjection, whether there is a difference between a 747 and a Piper aircraft. He is nodding agreement to that proposition. From memory, it requires about 3,000 metres, Senator, to stop a 747. This is an opposition frontbencher, a potential cabinet minister, who wants to knowâ€”
â€”Senator Collins, direct your remarks through the chair.
â€”I have a point of order, Madam Deputy President. Sit down. How can this possibly have anything to doâ€”
â€”I have not yet called you, Senator Alston.
â€”I apologise, Madam Deputy President.
â€”I call Senator Alston.
â€”How can an attack on Senator Macdonald have anything whatsoever to do with answering a question from Senator Woods?
â€”I was responding to what he said.
â€”You might think that is interesting to do, but it still has nothing to do with the question asked.
â€”There is no point of order.

â€”Madam Deputy President, I am delighted to have that helpful interjection from a senior coalition frontbencher: what is the difference between a 747 and a Piper aircraft in terms of safety and Simops? I will tell you: light aircraft need a much smaller amount of room to pull up in than 747s. If you want to know how crucial that difference is, have a look at the incident I referred to yesterday when it was a Cathay Pacific aircraft that did not pull up short of the intersecting runway.

para.tab: In terms of a demonstration to the electorate as to how effective this mob, this rabble, would be in running this country, we have just had it in spades. The interjection was: what is the difference in terms of safety at airports in simultaneous operations between a Piper aircraft and a 747? I do not think it can be said any better than it was said by the then Civil Aviation Authority in a press statement issued in November 1994.

talk.start.para: â€”On a point of order: the minister is not answering the question.
â€”He is getting right on to it.

â€”Just give us a chance, will you? You've got your front seat there. The question is: why is it criminally irresponsible to suggest the use of cross-runways at Sydney but not criminally irresponsible in relation to Adelaide, Darwin, Melbourne and Perth, where such operations exist? That is the question that was asked; it was simple and straightforward. Even this minister should be able to have a go at that one.

â€”On the point of order: Senator Hill was not in the chamber when the question was actually asked but I am glad that somebody has handed him a list showing what the question was. If he was in the chamber he would have known that, for the first part of the answer, many of the points that he has raised were in fact answered by Senator Collins.
â€”I think the problem was that Senator Collins got diverted by an interjection. Perhaps if you just address your remarks through the chair, Senator Collins.
â€”It was a really dopey interjection.

â€”I think Senator Faulkner said it better than I could have. I will just give the Senate the comparisons. There are 240,000 movements at KSA and 134,000 movements at Tullamarine. You should ask an air traffic controller what difference that makes when running simultaneous operations. I might add that Tullamarine does not have two parallel runways on top of that.
