To use Darwin airport as an example, when I know that only light aircraft are permitted to use the crossing runway at Darwin airport, just indicates how far out on a limb John Howard knows he has put himself with this completely loopy proposition.

question.speaker: Woods Sen R.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Minister, since you said just a few seconds ago that cross-runway operations at Sydney airport are so dangerous, do you recall that on 13 August 1991 in the Senate it was said:

question.para: There is absolutely no reason whatever why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be usedâ€”as they are used in Adelaide, as well as Sydneyâ€”with perfect safety.
Were they your own words, Minister? Were you being criminally irresponsible in 1991, or are you being criminally irresponsible now?

talk.start.para: â€”I must say that the opposition does not need much stimulation. Not only were they my words but I repeated them in here yesterday. You know and your leader knowsâ€”and it is why I used the words `criminally irresponsible' very advisedlyâ€”that that is a fact. As Senator Ray pointed out, 1991 was years before the parallel runway was even opened at Sydney airport.
â€”He is not talking about the parallel runway. He is talking about the cross-runway.

â€”Well, we are talking about it now, Senator Hill. It is a fact, supported not only here but internationally, that parallel runway operations are inherently safer than crossing runway operations. That is a fact and, as much as you twist, squirm and dive on the issue, you cannot avoid it.
â€”Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order in terms of the relevance to the question.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Woods, I cannot hear a word you are saying for the volume of noise on your side of the chamber.
â€”The minister has just said that it is inherently safer to have parallel runways, but how can anything be safer than what he described as `perfect safety'?
â€”There is no point of order.
â€”It is a disgrace to allow that point of order. It was nothing to do with the procedures of this chamber. He was asking a second supplementary question.
â€”I have ruled on the matter. I said that there was no point of order, but I think the time for the minister's supplementary answer has expired.
â€”I think it has.
â€”I call Senator Jones.

para.tab:
Honourable senators interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Just a moment, Senator Jones. If I am going to rule on points of order, it is necessary for me to hear what is being said by those who have the call.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer the minister to Australian businessman James Peng, arrested in Macau in 1993 and tried in China last year on two charges of corruption. I understand the verdict on Mr Peng's charges was handed down today. Will the minister advise the Senate on the outcome of the trial and the Australian government's attitude to the verdict?

â€”The case of Mr James Peng, who has been imprisoned in China over the last two years awaiting trial, has been the subject of some interest to senators and was the subject of a resolution of the Senate. As the senator has indicated, a verdict and sentence in this case has now been handed down.

para.tab: I can advise the Senate that the Shenzhen Intermediate People's Court has found Mr Peng guilty under company and criminal law on charges of embezzlement, and he has been sentenced to a total of 18 years in gaol, of which he will need to serve a minimum of 16 years followed by deportation. We are still awaiting full details of the judgment and sentence. The Australian ambassador and our consul in Guangzhou attended the trial as observers, in line with the government's consular obligations and concerns for an Australian citizen.

I must say the Australian government is extremely disappointed at the severity of the sentence, and the Australian government will be making strong representations to the Chinese authorities. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, who is in New York for the UN General Assembly, has written to his counterpart, Mr Qian Qichen, urging the Chinese authorities to approach Mr Peng's case with the utmost clemency on compassionate grounds.

Senator Evans has emphasised Mr Peng's detention of nearly two years awaiting finalisation of his case, the state of his health and the fact that he has a young family, and urged that he be sent home as soon as possible. He is also urgently seeking to meet foreign minister Qian in New York to press the appeal for clemency. I will be speaking to the Chinese ambassador in Canberra along similar lines.

The government understands that Mr Peng now has the right to appeal the court's verdict to a higher court and that it is up to Mr Peng's lawyers to advise him on this matter. The government's concerns all along have remained clearly that Mr Peng's case be handled strictly in accordance with due process under Chinese law and that Mr Peng not be denied any rights to which he was entitled under that law. These concerns have been assiduously pursued by the government from the outset and through available consular, diplomatic and political channels.

We have taken every appropriate opportunity to reinforce with Chinese leaders at every level the government's concerns that Mr Peng's case be handled in accordance with due process, that Mr Peng be not denied any rights to which he is entitled, and aspects of Mr Peng's treatment in detention. These concerns have included Mr Peng's access to legal advice, to family visits and to adequate medical treatment.

We have made about 100 separate actions to promote a resolution in Mr Peng's case, of which some 30 have been ministerial level representations at senior levels of the Chinese government. Our embassy in Beijing and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra have actively pursued with the Chinese government concerns in Mr Peng's case. Our Consulate-General in Guangzhou has maintained regular contact with Mr Peng, with 21 consular visits to him in Shenzhen, as well as raising with local officials concerns about Mr Peng's health, family and legal access, and conditions of detention.
I know this is a matter of real concern to many senators. I sought this opportunity to give the information as immediately as possible to all senators.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The Prime Minister yesterday suggested that `while ever we had intersecting runways, we were always in the cart for a major collision'. Why then did you tell the Senate on 13 August 1991 that `the facts are that simultaneous operations are in operation at many, many major airports around the world'? If some of the biggest and busiest airports in the world, such as La Guardia in New York, O'Hare in Chicago, Logan in Boston, LAX in Los Angeles, Schiphol in Amsterdam, as well as Frankfurt, can all have cross-runway operations, are their airport authorities being criminally irresponsible? Is Sydney somehow unique, or is the Prime Minister simply doing what he does bestâ€”fabricating the facts for his own political purposes?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: â€”As I said before, it does not matter how much you twist and squirm on this, you cannot escape the inescapable. The utter irrelevance to the current operations at Sydney airport of a statement made in 1991, when there were only two runways at Sydney airportâ€”it is nonsense.
â€”We are talking about cross-runways.

â€”Have a listen to why, Senator. Air Services Australia, who are responsible for air traffic controlâ€”these are the professionals who run air traffic control at Sydney airportâ€”in a statement issued this year answered your question, Senator Alston. They said this, and I have said it before:

answer.para: Air Services Australia today reaffirm that while parallel runways were available at Sydney airportâ€”
which they weren't, Senator, in 1991â€”
it would not be prepared to restore simultaneous independent runway operations using the east-west runway and intersecting operations with the parallel north runway system.
Air Services said there were significant safety, operational and environmental reasons for this position. These includedâ€”have a listen, Senator Alston:
international acceptance that parallel runway operations are inherently safer than any arrangement involving intersecting runways.
There were no parallel runways in 1991, Senator Alston, at Sydney airport. To continue:
the significant reduction in the number of people seriously or moderately affected by aircraft noise as a result of parallel runway operations.
And, Senator Alston:

parallel runways provide significantly higher capacity than intersecting runways and are the most effective means of meeting the growing demand for access to Australia's major international destination.

para.tab: That is what the organisation that runs air traffic control at Sydney says about it. Let us have a look at what the President of the Air Traffic Controllers Association said about it to Senator Parer in giving evidence to the Senate committee. Senator Parer knows what the truth of this is. I will bet Mr Howard did not consult him before he made that loopy statement. This is an extract from evidence to the Senate committee from the President of the Air Traffic Controllers Association. Senator Parer asked:

answer.para: Are you suggesting that cross-runway operations are not safe or just less safe?
Mr Lorschy responded:
They are less safe.

talk.start.para: â€”That's right.
â€”`That's right,' said Senator Parer. So you have acknowledged that your leader wishes to instituteâ€”
â€”Noâ€”`less safe', not unsafe.

â€”Yes, you agreed, Senator Parer. It will be in the
Hansard
. You have acknowledged that your leader wishes to institute a set of air traffic control arrangements at Sydney airport that are less safe than the existing arrangements at Sydney airport with the parallel runways. The parallel runways were not there in 1991. They are there now and it would be criminally irresponsible not to use them, Senator Parer. Mr Lorschy said to youâ€”and I will say it again:

answer.para: They are less safe.
Listen to this Senator Parerâ€”it is commonsenseâ€”Mr Lorschy said:

They rely more heavily upon the skill of the aerodrome controller in judging the point of conflict between two aircraft operating on the crossing runway set up. At the moment, with parallel runway operations, any conflict is removed from the precinct of the airport itself.

You want the parliament, this Senate, to substitute the air traffic controllers for those professional decisions taken at Sydney airport. It does not matter how much you twist and squirm, Senator Parer. You know that is irresponsible. I will guarantee that Mr Howard did not consult you before he made that statement.

talk.start.para: â€”Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I note with great interest, Minister, that you did not in any shape or form suggest that it would be unsafe to have cross-intersection. Is this the logic of your argument: if you had no runways at all, it would be perfectly safe and anything less than that is somehow `unsafer'? Would you just like to confirm for me that your argument is that none of those international runways that I have mentionedâ€”none of those very busy and very big airportsâ€”have any sorts of intersecting cross-runways or parallel runways with an intersecting cross-runway? Is that what you are telling us?
â€”No, Senator Alston.
â€”If it is not that, what is different about Sydney? Why has Sydney suddenly become a place that is unsafe when you have not got any evidence at all to support the proposition?
â€”It is because parallel runway operations are inherently safer than intersecting runways.
â€”Safer; not unsafe.

â€”The nonsense at the base of your proposition, Senator Alston, is this: there is such a thing as absolute safety in respect of travel. Yes, simultaneous operations can be made safe, if you want to do things like we did, such as banning all international carriers from using simultaneous operations. I might add that ban existed right up until the parallel runway was open at Sydney airport. The only international carrier allowed to used simultaneous operations was Qantas.
â€”On a point of order: the crux of my question was: do you argue that it is currently unsafe? Are you saying that or not?
â€”What's the point of order?
â€”I don't want him to talk about it relatively or comparatively. I'm asking him whether he says it is unsafe. That is the question he has to answer. That is what relevance is about.
â€”Order! There is no point of order.

â€”This is not a matter of debating points; this is a matter of people's lives. The opposition wants to play `pacman' with people's lives at Sydney airport. The air traffic controllers, in evidence to you, Senator Parer, saidâ€”and everyone knows itâ€”that it is safer not to do it.
(Time expired)

â€”Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Papua New Guinea, led by the Speaker, the Rt Hon. Rabbie Namaliu. On behalf of all honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

para.tab:
Honourable senators
â€”Hear, hear!

emphasis.tab: Rt Hon. Rabbie Namaliu was thereupon seated accordingly.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Is the minister aware of the document released by the opposition yesterday which makes various claims about Australian families and government programs? Can the minister inform the Senate whether these claims are correct?

answer.speaker: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

talk.start.para: â€”I have seen the little book and I can understand why the opposition has been very loath to release it. Let me read just one quote from the report without comment:

answer.para: Families make positive contributions to society. Such positive contributions include raising children to taxpayer status, contributing to the community economy, and building houses.

Hardly the language of care. Firstly, the booklet says the family has been undervalued in this country. I remind the opposition of research during the International Year of the Familyâ€”thank you for waving that booklet around, Senator Herronâ€”which showed that 91 per cent agreed that the family was the most important thing in their lives. So, clobber the first claim.

para.tab: Another constant theme of the opposition document is that women should stay at home full timeâ€”which makes me suspect that Mr Katter must be a memberâ€”and quotes the negative consequences of children whose parents are employed, running the old furphy that if women stayed out of the work force, more men would get jobs.

talk.start.para: â€”You haven't read it.

â€”I have read it, Senator. I have read it, and they are not lies. The contribution made by the skills and talents of women in the work force are very much welcomed by this government, just as much as we welcome the skills and contribution of women at home. There is research that cites very clearly that a lot of women might want to stay at home when their children are little. Let's get the figures right.
â€”Very generous of you!

â€”Indeed. Recent research released the other day by the Australian Institute of Family Studies, in a report called
Work and family life
, states that four in 10 mothers not working would prefer not to be working; however, 52 per cent would like part-time work and eight per cent would prefer a full-time job. So you had better put those figures in if you want to be accurate and full and comprehensive.

para.tab: As for the suggestion that women in the work force are not able to care for their children, or care for their children less, because they are in the work force, I would like to know whether the opposition suggest that it applies to their own women in parliament. This booklet suggests there should be more part-time work, but the facts are that something likeâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”What is the book?
â€”It is the Lyons Forum book, `Empowerment of Families'.
â€”That's not coalition policy. You are being totally misleading.
â€”I am not being totally misleading at all. I am suggesting, Senator, that you are loath to split it. Another very important point made in the book is that there are no subsidies for child careâ€”

â€”On a point of order: the minister is here to answer questions relating to the administration of her portfolio. She picks out a booklet, at the invitation of her colleague, to talk about and tries to translate that into a form of coalition policy when she knows that it is not. It is an expression of view of a number of parliamentarians which, presumably, you would want to be read and considered by policy makers. Why won't she state the truthâ€”the nature of the document to which she is referringâ€”rather than deliberately using question time to mislead in relation to coalition policy? Better still, why doesn't she answer questions relating to her failures of administration in her own area?

â€”On the point of order: Senator Hill did not take the specific point of order but it has been ruled that we are not allowed to use question time to comment on opposition policy. We would like to subscribe to thatâ€”they do not have anyâ€”but the point is that Senator Crowley is able to give an evaluation to this chamber of alternative views about social policy. I think you should rule, Madam Deputy President, that she is entitled to do that but not to comment on opposition policy per seâ€”because we know it does not exist.

â€”On the same point of order: to support my leader's comments and Senator Ray's comments, if Senator Crowley believes that the document she is referring to is opposition policy, she clearly should be ruled out of order on the basis of the ruling made by former President Sibraa, who said that commentary on opposition policy does not fall within the portfolio responsibilities of a minister. If the question had been framed differently it may well have been allowed but, given its framework, the question is not in order and should have been ruled out of order, and the answer should not be allowed to continue.
â€”Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: isn't the phrase `opposition policy' an oxymoron?

â€”Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: it is quite clear, as the opposition have said often, that they do not have policy, or they are not prepared to release it or it is hypothetical. What we are doing here, and what I am doing here, is properly and responsibly looking at a document that canvasses alternative policy proposals relevant to my portfolio. I would have thought it was entirely proper for me to be looking at it.

â€”I must say I thought that Senator Denman's question identified the document other than as opposition policy. It is some time ago, of course, since it was asked, but it was my impression that it had been presented as alternative social policy on which Senator Crowley would be able to comment.
â€”Thank you, Madam Deputy President. There are a couple more points that need to beâ€”
â€”Madam Deputy Presidentâ€”

para.tab:
Government senators interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”Get out your violin and your tissues. Madam Deputy President, you may well be correct in what you say with respect to Senator Denman's introduction. I was not able to hear that, due to the people on her own side who did not give her the courtesy of being able to speak without interruption, but I do believe that Senator Crowley made a direct reference to this being in some way coalition policy. That is the deception, that is the lie, that the points of order have sought to clarify, and that is what she should now admit herself. Tell everybody how deceptive you have been.
â€”Senator Crowley is able to comment on social policy but not on opposition policy.

â€”I made the point that Senator Vanstone is being ticky about when speaking to the point of order. There are a couple of points in this document that certainly do have grave concern for me. The first is the Lyons Forum suggestion that there are no child-care subsidies paid by this government to families where one parent is at home. That is an absolute outrage, because 25 per cent of child-care assistance dollars goes to families with one parent at home. Under the proposals that are now on hold in this place because the opposition prefers to oppose that legislation, we would have shared that child-care assistance to many more families with one parent at home. So you over there are proposing this document to dismantle it.

para.tab: This document contains cold contradiction of John Howard's claims that he and the opposition would soften their hard right line. The document favours slashing the social wage. It would destroy the child-care system. It has very big cuts to welfare and regressive income splitting, and it is an attack on single mothers. In no way is this government prepared to endorse any of those points.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The minister will recall that in his reply to a question of mine in March of this year he said that the government was undertaking studies into the regulatory controls which would be needed if Australian airports were to be privatised. I ask the minister: have those studies been completed and, if so, what were the conclusions, in particular as they apply to increased hourly movements into and out of Kingsford Smith airport and maximum air movements of capacity at Badgerys Creek? Does the minister agree that increased air movements per hour create increased noise to residents underneath the flight path? Is it envisaged that a privatised Kingsford Smith airport would ever operate at less than total maximum capacity?

â€”The government has, in fact, this week introduced legislation into the House that sets out a comprehensive leasing and regulatory strategy for federal airports. Consultation drafts of the bill, I am advised, were circulated for comments to interested parties and, following consideration of the comments, the bills have been finalised and now introduced into the House of Representatives.

para.tab: The bills establish an airport regulatory regime covering pricing and service levels; limits on ownership and control, including, I might say, majority Australian control; environmental planning; and other measures to apply to post-leasing. The leasing and regulatory bills provide for Sydney and Sydney West airports to be structured as separate companies and leased together.

The high level of demand growth at Sydney airport requires that Sydney West airport be available as soon as possible. The EIS for the parallel runway development at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport indicated that the ultimate capacity of the airport with parallel runway operations is approximately 353,000 movements per year.

Sydney West airport is being developed as an international and domestic airport in time for the Sydney Olympics to meet the rapidly growing demand for aviation infrastructure in the Sydney region. As a first stage, it will have a 2,900-metre runway; a 10,000 square metre terminal, with aero-bridges and capacity for more than a million passengers per year; parking spaces for four 747s and four 737s; provision for freight handling, charter, commuter and general aviation facilities; and international air traffic control, rescue and firefighting services.

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you, Minister, for that answer. It was good as far as it went, but you did not mention whether the scoping studies mentioned what the maximum hourly movements into and out of Kingsford Smith airport would be.
â€”Yes, I did: 353,000 a year.
â€”I missed it if you did, and I apologise. I would appreciate it if you could tell me again. I understood you said 353,000 to Badgerys Creek would be the maximum.
â€”No, Kingsford Smith.
â€”Okay; to Kingsford Smith. Can you tell me what the maximum to Badgerys Creek would be? Also, do you expect that total maximum capacity at Kingsford Smith ever to go down after it is privatised?

â€”I did know at one stage the figure for maximum movements in terms of the ultimate development at Badgerys Creek, but I cannot recall now the figure. As Senator Bourne knows, it is being developed in stages. What the ultimate capacity will be, I am not sure. In fact, I do not think it would be possible to answer the question in the sense that there is a large area of land available, as Senator Bourne knows, at the new Sydney West airport which would be able to be expanded enormously should the traffic grow to that extent in future years. I think Senator Bourne's question relates to the movements on the existing stage. I do not know the answer to that question. I will refer it to the minister.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask the minister whether his attention has been drawn to comments in the media by the member for Warringah, Tony Abbott, regarding the future of Defence land at Middle Head.

â€”It has been known for some time that Defence plans to vacate Middle Head and North Head. These important areas are on the foreshore of Sydney Harbour. They are areas that retain a lot of their natural attraction because of Defence's long-term presence and management. Defence is currently looking at options for future use of the properties. In identifying those options, Defence has adopted a consultative approach, involving local and state governments as well as community representatives. A management study is already in place in Middle Head, and similar arrangements are about to commence at North Head.

para.tab: In June of this year I met with the mayors of Mosman and Manly and also Mr Abbott. I outlined the government's approach and some commitments we were prepared to make at the outset. These included the preservation of the present bushland areas, to be incorporated in the Sydney Harbour National Park, and the protection of areas of national heritage significance. Whilst the mayors were obviously disappointed that Defence was leaving some of these areas, they were quite happy with the proposed arrangements.

I also mention Mr Abbott was present at those meetings; therefore, he is fully aware of the government's intentions. Throughout the whole process, Mr Abbott has been given every chance to participate. He is a member of the steering committee oversighting the management study for Middle Head, and he is part of the process that he condemns. He therefore has absolutely no excuse for the misrepresentations that he has managed to put around on these issues in the last few weeks.

Yesterday, on the Alan Jones program, Mr Abbott continued to spread that misinformation. He claims that Defence will get $25 million from property sales to pay for the relocation of 10 Terminal Regiment from Middle Head to Townsville. Of course, that is wrong. The money is already provided in the 1995-96 Defence budget. Whether we ever get any money from these two sites is irrelevant to the removal of 10 Terminal Regiment. I know Mr Abbott is unhappy about that, and I am inviting him to go to Townsville to explain to them that they should not relocate to Townsville.

I stress here in this chamber that Defence will not take an arrogant or a stupid attitude to any land disposals. If you look at our track record in Sydney, you will see that we always try to leave the community something behind. I will cite some examples. It was only earlier this year that we opened the Nirimba educational precinct, when navy moved out and left a magnificent community facility behind. And we did not screw the New South Wales Liberal government for money over this site, over and above what was a fair price. In the case of the now Labor government, we were able to negotiate a reasonable settlement to the Newington land to give the New South Wales government access for the Olympic site. Further, at areas like St Marys, this year we were able to remove the nuclear waste and free up 1,500 hectares for development to help house various people in Sydney.

Defence, throughout all these processes, was committed to a consultative approach. Here we have Mr Abbott. I would not deny a junior woodchuck of the opposition a means to make his way in lifeâ€”and he has made this his big issueâ€”if only he would tell the truth about the subject. If only he would resist putting falsehoods around, on radio and through the local media, when he knows the true situation. He describes the consultative process as a sham. He is part of it. If he does not want to be part of a `sham', he should resign and let us get some of the more decent citizens of that particular area to participate in the consultative process and bring about a good result.

There is no excuse for this sort of carpetbaggery that Mr Abbott is going on with. He knows the truth of this situation, yet he deliberately goes out there and distorts the situation. He has very much, I think, now aggrieved all the local councils in the area who know the true situation and who know that he is just endeavouring to support a bit of place seeking.
(Time expired)

question.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Mr Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, stated in a letter of 31 January this yearâ€”you might listen to this, Senator Collinsâ€”to a resident in Haberfield:

question.para: I have repeatedly said I favour reopening the east-west runway.
Is the Premier of New South Wales, to use your own words of yesterday, `criminally irresponsible'?

talk.start.para: â€”Deeper and deeper, Bob.

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Hardly. I know Bob Carr extremely well. I have known him over a long number of years. As high a regard as I have for Bob Carr, I would defer to the air traffic controllers in respect of their relative knowledge about air traffic control at Sydney airport. It is constantly being said by the opposition that we should not be talking about our concerns about danger at Sydney airportâ€”
â€”Who said that?

â€”Mr Howard yesterday, in fact, Senator Parer. Mr Howard said that we are simply scaremongering about the operations that you want to go back to at Sydney airport. This is what John Howard himself said in February 1989â€”
â€”Point of orderâ€”
â€”Point of order, Senator Collins
â€”He said:

answer.para: The current situation is a serious threat to both travellers and local residents.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Collins!
â€”I think Senator Collins knows as well as we all do that quoting John Howard when he is asked a highly specific questionâ€”
â€”What is the point of order?

â€”Relevance. He was asked a question whether Bob Carr is being criminally irresponsible and he goes on and talks about something John Howard said. How can that possibly be relevant to the question? Senator Collins knows as well as we do that it is entirely out of order, and I ask you to rule accordingly.

â€”On the point of order: the question asked Senator Collins to express a point of view about an issue and he is providing evidence directly relating to that issue. He was asked whether a person had behaved in a certain manner. That requires an assessment of the nature of that behaviour, whether the recommendation was appropriate, and he is bringing evidence from a senior Australian who said that it was not an appropriate course of action. It is entirely relevant. The evidence directly points to the fact that the action taken was inappropriate and he is pointing to a senior Australian citizen who made just that advocacy recently.

â€”Madam Deputy President, on the same point of order: I think the relevant point to make also is that yesterday Senator Collins quite clearly attached the label `criminally irresponsible' to John Howard. The comparison that Senator Parer wants to make or adduce is that Bob Carr and John Howard are in the same category. That is a point that Senator Collins is addressing, I think quite convincingly, to prove that they are not. He cannot do that without making reference to the person who is criminally responsible in this matterâ€”and that is John Howard. There is a connection, and I think Senator Collins is entitled to answer on it.
â€”Order! There is no point of order at this stage. We are one minute into a four-minute answer, and I think Senator Collins has further to go.
â€”Madam Deputy President, I understand full well, as a politician, the political pressures onâ€”
â€”Bob Carr.

â€”politicians in Sydneyâ€”or any politicians, Senator Alston, Bob Carr or any other. Playing politics is one thing, but playing with people's lives is quite another. Bob Carr, to the best of my knowledge, did not suggest in that letterâ€”unless you can correct me on this, Senator Parerâ€”that we should use the Australian parliament and the numbers in the Senate to direct air traffic control at Sydney airport. That is what you are doing, Senator Parer.

para.tab: I might add that there are a couple of complete pieces of nonsense that have been floating around in the last 48 hours from the Howard camp as to why these concerns are not real. The two that I have heard are, `When I supported the third runway at Sydney airport'â€”this is quoting John Howardâ€”`I didn't support it thinking that the east-west runway would be taken out of operation.'

talk.start.para: â€”Why did you call it a third runway?

â€”`That's right,' says Senator Parer. Have a listen to what your frontbencher said. `Mr Howard didn't know about this'â€”that we were actually proposing to take out the east-west runwayâ€”and Senator Parer has confirmed it, saying, `That's right.' This is what Charles Blunt, the opposition spokesperson for transport, the frontbencher responsible for transport, said when he was advocating the third runway construction.

â€”Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I certainly deferred to your earlier ruling because I think you made it clear that you were prepared to give Senator Collins the benefit of the doubt as he had only been going for one minute. He has now had three minutes of talking about everything except what this question is about. We have moved from John Howard to Charles Blunt. Maybe we are going to move back to Senator Collins's six-year-old son, who might be able to answer a little better. But the fact is, there is a question before the chamber which he has not even attempted to answer. I therefore suggest that now is the time to ask him to do that.

â€”Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: I am responding directly to the assertion, just made by the opposition representative on transport in this chamber, that the opposition believed the east-west runway would not be taken out of operation when the third runway was constructed.

â€”Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: I support Senator Alston's point of order. Senator Collins introduced the subject of Charles Blunt by saying that he had heard something floating around the chamber about this issue that John Howard might have said. That, to me in my mind, proves that it is just entirely irrelevant and so far from the point of the question that it needs to be ruled irrelevant, like the minister himself.

â€”Madam Deputy President, can I just say that the clincher is that Senator Collins himself has just said that he was responding to something said to him by Senator Parer. In other words, he concedes that it has nothing to do with the original question.
â€”Senator Collins, I think you should devote yourself to answering the question and ignore interjections across the chamber.
â€”Madam Deputy President, I am doing precisely that. In response to my questioner in here today: what your frontbencher said when advocatingâ€”
â€”Senator Collins, would you direct your remarks through the chair.

talk.start.para:
â€”The
Hansard
will contain the answer to Senator Parer's question. The element of criminal irresponsibilityâ€”which I will be amazed if it is contained in Mr Carr's letterâ€”is that the so-called alternative Prime Minister of this country intends to use, if he can, the numbers of this parliament, and in particular this Senate, to impose this system of air traffic control against all of the advice of the safety experts at Sydney airport. That is criminally irresponsible.
â€”I refer to the document `Services for the Termination of Pregnancy in Australia'â€”a review by a panel appointed by the NHMRC. Why did the NHMRC appointâ€”
â€”Who is this to?

â€”It is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Why did the NHMRC appoint a panel of which all the members were pro-abortion and most had a vested interest in the abortion industry? What is the government's view, for example, on the panel's suggestion that all laws be repealed which may prevent abortion on demand, its recommendations that the role of abortion services `within a comprehensive fertility control strategy in Australia be accepted'â€”in other words, abortion to be used as a birth control methodâ€”and its support for the abortion drug RU486 and its enhanced testing in this particular region? Isn't it ironic that, rightly, we object to the French nuclear testing in the Pacific but the government supports trials in Australia of this French weapon of chemical warfare against the unborn?

â€”The draft report has been prepared by the NHMRC expert panel on termination of pregnancy. I have no advice about how that expert panel was constituted. If there is anything further I can find to that, I will certainly provide it to you. An advertisement calling for public comment on the draft report appeared in the press on 23 September 1995. The draft report reviews a range of issues relevant to termination, including the availability of information about services, clinical aspects of care, the experience of abortion, the question of unplanned and unwanted pregnancy and the impact of the legal framework on the quality and accessibility of services.

para.tab: In brief, the expert panel found a lack of coordination and acknowledged leadership among health care professionals in this area, significant variations in practical aspects of terminationâ€”for example, where and how abortions are performedâ€”ease of access to information, the availability of quality of counselling and some aspects of the quality of care. The report makes a total of 26 recommendations on a range of issues regarding termination, including a recommendation that RU486 and similar drugs be more readily available for further research and evaluation in Australia.

Copies of the draft report have been mailed directly to a range of interested individuals, groups, professional organisations, hospitals et cetera. Those interestedâ€”and I presume there would be a number of peopleâ€”will be able to make submissions for consideration by the expert panel. If anybody wants to, they can certainly obtain a copy of that report. The closing date for comments is 3 November.

It is following consideration of comments received through the public consultation process that the expert panel will frame its final recommendations for consideration by the NHMRC. So I think it is important to appreciate that this is but the first step in an extensive consultation process. These are not final recommendations; they are now out for public consultation and discussion.

talk.start.para: â€”I am sorry, but I do have to ask a supplementary question because the minister has not responded. I am sure the electors of Australia want to know the government's view on those three matters that I raised regarding the suggestion by the panel that there be abortion on demandâ€”in other words, that all of those laws which would prevent abortion on demand be repealedâ€”and that abortion be a birth control methodâ€”
â€”Did they say that?

â€”Yes. They suggested that abortion be a birth control methodâ€”that is to say, that the role of abortion services `within a comprehensive fertility control strategy in Australia be accepted'. In respect of the RU486 matter, I remind the minister that it is not only pro-life people that are objecting to that. The feminist groups are objecting to RU486. â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. â€”Yes, as Senator Faulkner says, what a surprise supplementary. â€”Don't you have a briefing note?

â€”It does usually take a day for these things. John Howard endorsed the first lot but has started to run away on the second lot.

â€”My question is directed to Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I ask the minister: has the level of cooperation from the states been satisfactory from the Commonwealth's perspective in relation to access to data for the deferred forests assessment process? If the level of access has not been adequate, what is the Commonwealth government doing to rectify this?

â€”Negotiations with all states have been complex and have involved a high level of technical work and interaction between Commonwealth and state officials. The deferred forest assessments, which will be publicly released tomorrow, represent the current position in relation to the officials' negotiations. In the case of Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales, Commonwealth officials have been working together with their state counterparts to satisfy themselves that the data and the methodologies used are appropriate and the results of the analyses are well based. Commonwealth officials are satisfied that the government's criteria for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system can be met. para.tab: As I said on Tuesday in answer to a question from Senator Chamarette, throughout the deferred forest area process Western Australia has consistently refused to undertake a joint assessment of values until the Commonwealth agrees to their conditions and their interpretation of reserve criteria. The process of technical examination will need to take place during the public consultation period. The Commonwealth simply does not accept Western Australia's claims that it has provided all necessary information or its claims that it has been dudded in the past when information was provided.

â€”I was asked a question by Senator Knowles on 26 September regarding health insurance agreements. The Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, has provided the following information:

para.tab: This question reveals a lack of understanding concerning legislation and the workings of the industry. The legislation is facilitative not coercive. talk.start.para: â€”Senator Abetz on 20 September 1995 asked me a question about hospital waiting lists. The number of people on waiting lists, as I said then and as, I recollect, you misrepresented me when you moved to take note of the answerâ€”
â€”I always do.
â€”That is right. The number of people on waiting lists is a crude indicator of hospital performance. The appropriate issue to target is the management of clinically appropriate waiting times.

para.tab: The Medicare agreements provide for the reporting of nationally comparable information for waiting lists. The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare was funded under the hospital access program to develop, collect and publish nationally consistent and comparable waiting list data. The first national report was released on 22 February 1995.

The inconsistencies and variations in the categorisation and supply of data classified by clinical urgency by the states and territories mean that any comparisons and associated conclusions need to be qualified. Nevertheless, states with coalition governments are slashing hospital funding, while the Commonwealth increases its share of funding.
You also asked about private health insurance.

talk.start.para: â€”What is the number of people on waiting lists?

â€”There is no reliable number. That is the point of the answer. If you want the answer you can check, as Senator Herron will tell you and as I have just said, there are inconsistencies between what is countedâ€”
â€”See if you can do better on health insurance.

â€”One of the most persuasive things is that you do not want to know the facts. It is significant to note that while the numbers are fallingâ€”and as I said to you, Victoria insists that it is dropping its numbers dramaticallyâ€”the states are slashing their funding and the Commonwealth is increasing it.
â€”If we do not have the numbers, how do we know they are falling?
â€”Exactly so. Read the report. The appropriation of the population covered by the basic table of private health insurance for the last few years, as at 30 June, is:

answer.para: The figures for the last two quarters are:

para.tab: The reforms enable health funds, through contracting with doctors and hospitals, to offer insurance products that eliminate or make known out-of-pocket costs and therefore provide members with financial certainty. talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woods this day, relating to cross runway operations at Kingsford Smith Airport.

speech.para: The question which this matter addresses is why was the third runway introduced in the first place. Was it introduced for the reasons which the government is now pretendingâ€”that is, it was unsafe? The answer is: no, it was not. It was introduced because we wanted to increase the efficiency and decrease the noise by increasing the number of take-offs and landings which went over the ocean.

para.tab: There was never any question. Indeed in 1991 you yourself said it can be run with perfect safety. You have repeated that today. You said at that time there was no parallel runway, therefore it can be operated withâ€”let me quote youâ€”`perfect safety'. There was never any question of that. Simops in that time can be used with `perfect safety', to quote your own words. It has been used for something like 40 years with perfect safety. There have been no accidents. There have been a couple of near misses but, if you look at the parallel runways around the world, how many near misses have there been? How many reports have we had of aircraft landing on and approaching the wrong runway?

The minister seemed to ignore completely most of the question which was addressed to him. That is why airports like La Guardia in New York, O'Hare in Chicago, Logan in Boston, LA, Frankfurt and Schiphol in Amsterdam are able to operate crossing runways. I would guess those six airports would be in the top 10 busiest airports around the world. Is he indicating that it is not possible? Is he indicating that those airports are running with `criminal negligence', to use his own words? Of course he is not.

The excuse that the minister used was that there are parallel runways and cross-runways and the problem with Sydney is that we have two parallel runways and a cross-runway. Let me point out that in 1991 there was a cross-runway crossing only one of the runways. There was only one runway there. Now we have two runways parallel, but it still crosses only one runway. The crossing problem is exactly the same.

You said yourself that the main problem was the parallel runway. But of the airports I have just mentioned, Frankfurt has a parallel runway and a cross-runway and Los Angeles has a parallel runway and a cross-runway. That is very interesting.

You have reported on a number of people who, you claim, say it is not possible to operate cross-runways. Let me point out that there are a number of experts who take a different view. For example, the President of the Australian International Pilots Association said that using three runways is `done in other parts of the world' and, `I cannot see any reason why they could not do it here.

He also mentions, as a comment on your system, that a lot of other systems in the world do have extensive parallel runway systems but they are nothing like the toy system we have hereâ€”one real runway and one partial runway. We do not have a third runwayâ€”let's be realisticâ€”we have one and a half runways here.

talk.start.para: â€”One and a half?

â€”You mean two and a half.

â€”They do not use one of the runways, Senator Kernot; that is the problem. Let's be realistic: the reason we have a non-usable runway is because of where it is, because the planes would fly straight over Laurie Brereton's house and Garry Punch's electorate. It has nothing to do with efficiency, safety or noise. It is simply a question of the noise over your marginal seats, the noise over Laurie Brereton's house; that is the only important thing.

para.tab: Unfortunately, of course, the noise goes over Lowe. How interesting it was yesterday to see Mary Easson, the member for Lowe, supporting the government on this position, derelict in her duty to her constituents in Lowe who have been besotted with noise since the change in government policy. I am interested to see the vindictiveness of the people of Lowe in reminding Mary Easson, when the election comes around, how she has failed, as she has on so many issues, to represent them.

We have another expert on our sideâ€”Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales. It is not very often I find myself in agreement with Bob Carr. You cannot trust him because of the promises he breaks, rather like you lot over there. But he is out there supporting the reopening of the third runwayâ€”the east-west runway, the cross-runway, the one you say cannot be operated safely.

Would you say the same thing about him that you say about John Howard, that he is criminally irresponsible? No, you would not do that. He is a mate of yours. You have known him for `years and years and years'â€”I think that was the expression you used. Why is it any less irresponsible of Bob Carr to say such a thing than John Howard? Is there really any substance to the accusation? Clearly, there is none at all. You do not care about safety, you only care about justifying the reduction of noise over some of your marginal seats.
