para.tab: Unfortunately, the senator who just spoke, Senator Bob Woods, indicated once again how appalling is the knowledge on which the opposition's position is based. I said in question time todayâ€”I did not expect to get such quick confirmation of itâ€”that there were two ridiculous lines that the opposition were running, and I canvassed one. The second is the one you have just advanced, and that is that there is no problem with the second parallel runway at Sydney airport because it does not cross the east-west runway.

talk.start.para: â€”That is the argument you used yourself.

â€”It is in the
Hansard
. You are in cuckoo land, Senator. In 1991 there were only two runways. There are now three runways. I cannot believe the extent of the ignorance on this subject, which is so important in terms of air safety.

para.tab: It is not relevant that the second parallel runway does not cross the east-west runway. The fact is that almost all aircraft that taxi, take off or land at Sydney airport have to cross 07, which is the east-west runway. I cannot believe you are so ignorant of that. I will tell you what that means in real terms.

talk.start.para: â€”Why is it different now to 1991?
â€”There were only two runways then, you dill. The same number of movementsâ€”

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
â€”Order! Senator Collins, that is unparliamentary. You should withdraw it.

talk.start.para: â€”I will withdraw it, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I love these interjections because the senator is just digging himself deeper and deeper. The same number of movements now as in 1991 at Sydney airportâ€”what utter nonsense! There is no such thing in travel as absolute safety, whether that is by train or by car or by aircraft. There is no such thing as absolute safety.
â€”Or by bicycle.

â€”Or by bicycle, indeed, Senator. The minute you step out of your house, you run that risk. But it is no good you even staying in your house because, statistically, that is where almost all people die.
â€”You could get hit by lightning.

â€”Indeed. In fact, statistically being in bed is dangerous, because a lot of people die in bed. There is no absolute safety. Senator, could I just point out to you that a single-engine aircraft can operate safely, but a twin-engine aircraft is inherently safer than a single-engine aircraft.
â€”So you are going to ban single-engine aircraft?

â€”No. Talk to Dick Smith about this some time. Dick Smith might actually be able to give you a few lessons. An aircraft with three engines is inherently safer than one with two, and an aircraft with four engines is safer than one with three.

para.tab: Simultaneous operations can operate, as I said, but, according to every international expert on air traffic control, parallel runway operations are inherently safer than cross-runway operations. I will tell you why, Senator. Have a listen. It is nonsense to suggest that because the second parallel runway does not actually cross the east-west runway, as you have said, it does not impact on operating those three runways simultaneously. It is a nonsense. The aircraft at some point have to cross 07, Senator.

The facts are that it is estimatedâ€”and this is straight from the statistics at Sydney airportâ€”that, with the kinds of operations you are proposing, aircraft would be expected to cross the east-west runway every 45 seconds or less. The statistics go on to state that the reason it should not happen is as follows:

speech.para: .more complex three runway configuration operations would increaseâ€”
and they doâ€”
workload and complexity for air traffic controllers and pilots
.a large number of aircraft would need to cross the active east-west runway to position for take-off on the parallel runways, or taxiing to the terminals after landing
.with the use of the intersecting east-west runway, the required safety corridors to accommodate aircraft carrying out missed approaches could not be readily provided.

Yes, Senator, that is one of the common features of all major air disasters. Go and talk to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation about simultaneous operations, Senator. There is always a sequence of events that go wrong simultaneously. That is the common factor in all major aircraft disasters. What these operations do is cut down the margin for safety if things go wrong. Operating two parallel runways is inherently safer than simultaneous operations.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Forshaw Sen M.G.

talk.start.para: â€”One of the things that disturbs me about the opposition's approach to this issue is that it has pre-empted its own inquiry established by the Senate some time ago to look at issues surrounding the construction of the third runway at Sydney airport and its subsequent operation. What, of course, has occurred is that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has nobbled the inquiry. How that has come about is that, when the inquiry commenced taking its evidence, much of the material that was being presented to the inquiry related to the construction of the runway and the surrounding issues, including the environmental impact statement.

para.tab: But since then there has been a call for the re-opening of the east-west runway from particularly resident groups who are living under the flight path of the north-south runway. As has been correctly identified, many of those groups are in the Bennelong electorate. What has occurred is that John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, has decided that this is an opportunity to hopefully win a few votes from some residents affected by aircraft noise and has pre-empted the findings of Senator Parer's own inquiryâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”It's a Senate inquiry. Get it right.

â€”It is a Senate inquiry, chaired by Senator Parer. The Leader of the Opposition has said, `Let's re-open this runway.' In fact, he has taken steps within the other place to bring about that by his attempts to hold up other legislation.

para.tab: This inquiry, which has been going for some timeâ€”we have received over 6,000 submissions and are looking at very important issues; namely, safety of air travelâ€”has been hijacked. The Leader of the Opposition has said: let's re-open the east-west runway. He has furthermore said: there is no need for an environmental impact statement into making that decision; let's just do it. Let us go back to what John Howard said in 1989, when he was supporting the construction of the third runway. He said:

speech.para: In the interests of safety, airport facilities should be upgraded immediately, including the construction of the third runway. The current congestion at the airport is causing increased noise pollution and becoming a serious threat, both to travellers and to local residents. The government is playing carelessly with a situation that could too easily result in a major tragedy. The risk must be averted.

That is what John Howard said in 1989. The problem then was twofold. Firstly, we had a lack of runway capacity at Sydney airport, given the fact that we were using cross-runway operations. Secondly, we had increasing demand for air traffic to get in and out of Sydney causing congestion and then in turn causing backlogs right through the system around Australia, and we all remember the delays that used to occur. That was then in turn causing great risk in terms of safety at Sydney.

para.tab: What do we have now? We have two parallel runways in operation and the movement capacity at Sydney airport is as high as it was at that time and will increase. We have had a reduction in the risk factorâ€”one of the major reasons for the construction of the third runway. In other words, the risk has been avertedâ€”just what John Howard asked for then. The risk of an on-ground collision involving simultaneous operations has been averted.

How has that been averted and achieved? By moving from what everybody has acknowledged was a safe operation, if all things went well, using simultaneous cross-runway operations to an even safer operation with parallel runways. I find it incredible that people, simply for base political motives, are prepared to stand up in public and say that, having improved air traffic safety, having improved the safety of air passengers in this country operating in and out of Mascot, they now want to reduce that safety. I think that is an atrocious approach to take to this issue.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Abetz Sen E.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Denman this day, relating to a Lyons Forum report on families.

speech.para: Senator Crowley seems to take great delight in trying to demonise anything that is good and wholesome, such as the Lyons Forum. I indicate to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and the Senate that the Lyons Forum is named after Prime Minister Joseph Lyons and Dame Enid Lyons. Of course, Joseph Lyons saw the light and he deserted the Labor Party. I dare say that is why they do not like him.

para.tab: By the vote of their fellow citizens, Joe Lyons reached the pinnacle of public life for men and Enid Lyons reached what so far had been the pinnacle for women in public life. Dame Enid Lyons, in her maiden speech to the parliament, said:

speech.para: The foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people.

That is the motivation of all of us, including me, who are involved in the Lyons Forum. Indeed, the Lyons Forum, because of its concern for the family unit, engaged in a public inquiry right around Australia, canvassing evidence from all sorts of groups within the community. It heard from such luminaries as the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association of Victoria. Guess who represented that organisation? The newest mother in this Senate, Ms Jacinta Collins, as she was thenâ€”now Senator Jacinta Collins from the Labor Party. She thought it was good enough to appear in front of the Lyons Forum inquiry to give evidence on behalf of her membership. So the trade union movement thought it was okay.

para.tab: Undoubtedly, the minister did not read the report as she said she had. If she did read the report, she grossly misrepresented it. As my colleague Senator Campbell suggested to me, Senator Crowley is not required to produce maps to allow men to find their way around supermarkets; she needs a map to find her way to the truth. I will give a stark example of that. Senator Crowley suggested in media today that the Lyons Forum had said:

speech.para: The welfare system itself encourages young women to have children as a means of providing themselves with income and somewhere to live.

That is a gross misrepresentation. It is untrue. There is no substance to that allegation. It is a quote in the document and it is footnoted as belonging to F. Walker, who wrote an article in the
Sun-Herald
on 21 August 1994. They are not the views of the Lyons Forum but an expression of some of the views within the community. A very harsh view was expressed in the
Sun-Herald
, but what did the Lyons Forum say? It said:
Clearly, the needs of single mothersâ€”emotionally, socially, educationally, physically and spirituallyâ€”are often very great, and significant community support is required.

Why did she not tell the people of Australia that the Lyons Forum believes in providing significant community support for single mothers rather than quote somebody's assertions, which the Lyons Forum had put into its report simply to give a flavour of the different views within society.

para.tab:
Indeed, the views as expressed in this report are shown in the executive summary. Indeed, the minister would have needed to turn only two pages to find out what we were recommending. As I understand it, Senator Herron will be reading those into the
Hansard
, so I will not bother the Senate with that at the moment. Allow me to read a few views that have been expressed. One states:

speech.para: In the last couple of years the Government has boasted about the increasing number of women in the work force. Rather than something to be proud of I feel that this is something of which we should be ashamed.

Do you agree with that line, Senator McMullan? Do you agree with that line, Senator Ray? Does Senator Crowley agree with that line? Guess who said it? None other than the current Prime Minister, the member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), in his maiden speech. That quote can be found at page 515 of the
Hansard
of 17 March 1970. So don't come hereâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I believe the term accepted now is `first speech'.

â€”At the time it was maiden speech. Bad luck. Whether you like it or not, Senator Margetts, he did deliver a maiden speech. I accept that I delivered a first speech because the thought police have got to that.

â€”The point of order is that we have accepted a change of terminology and the reason is for a non-sexist terminology. That is the reason that terminology has been accepted and I ask that the correct terminology be used.
â€”On the point of order: I think Senator Abetz was referring to history. If that highlights what was once sexist and not politically correct, it should advance your cause, Senator Margetts.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
â€”I think in the context in which you were using it the term was acceptable. But your time has expired.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to be allowed to continue my remarks for two minutes.

para.tab: Leave not granted.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para:
â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I think the facts of the matter in relation to
Empowering Australian Families
, the Lyons Forum's
National Inquiry into Families and the Economy
, should be put on the record. I ask: what has Senator Crowley to show for the International Year of the Family that she was in charge of? I can tell you: nothing. But the Lyons Forum, on its own behalf, went around Australia during that year questioning people. Today, incorrectly reported in the newspaper was the heading `MPs want women to stay home'. But when you read the text, it says, `to allow women to stay at home'. There is a big difference.
â€”Choice.

â€”We were talking about choice. A 1991 study of family matters suggests that 69 per cent of women would prefer to look after their children at home full timeâ€”and it is even higher with women with preschool children.

para.tab:
I will read into the
Hansard
the executive summary, because this is the truth and the factsâ€”and not a distortion of them, as has appeared both in the media today and in Senator Crowley's remarks. The executive summary states:

speech.para: Empowering Australian Families represents the culmination of two years work by the Lyons Forum in consulting the Australian people about their views on the role and importance of the family as an institution in community life.
The submissions and presentations raised many concerns.
It then lists the concerns which people would understand without me having to read them. It continues:
To address these concerns, changes including the following are required . . .
It then states, firstly:
.Overt political, community, social and spiritual leadership nationally to promote the importance of family values.
Secondly:
.Policy changes in the area of family law, taxation, employment and education.
Thirdly:
.Empowering of families to give them real financial choice.
And finally:
.Empowerment of parents against the continual encroachment of an all powerful State over the lives of their children.

Surely those on the other side of the chamber would agree with those sentiments. I do not think there would be anybody who would disagree with them. But to have that occur, a certain number of changes are required. The executive summary states:
7.1 Microeconomic Changes Required
.Family-friendly workplace policy, including child care, family-leave, re-organising of working hours;
7.2 Macroeconomic Changes Required
Macroeconomic changes are required to restore choice to families.
That is what this document is all aboutâ€”to restore choice. Choice does not exist today.
It continues:
Family life should be facilitated by the economic system, not discouraged. These macroeconomic changes were recommended:
.A taxation system which recognises family commitments, for example, income splitting or family unit taxation;
.Taxation rebates for necessary family expenditure such as child care and mortgages;
.A tightening of the social welfare system to remove disincentive to family life and recognise home-makers' contributions to the family;
.Management of unemployment levels so that the family is under as little financial strain as possible;
.Recognition of the economic value of unpaid work done in the home, in the GDP figures.
7.3 Non-economic Changes Required

Non-economic policies can also be anti-choice for families. The Inquiry heard many suggestions of policy alterations which would remove disincentives to family stability and instead encourage family life:

.Attention to family-specific policy, giving families more consideration in the making of policy than they now receive, undertaking `Family Impact Statements', to address the effect of other policies on the family.
.A re-examination of the role of Family Law in supporting marriage and family life.
.Education of parents, children and the media as to the importance of families, family values, and the work done in the home.
.Provision of preventative support services, rather than concentration on post-separation services.
.Review of child care policy, including any empirical data that raises concern about the effect of non-parental child care.

I do not think anybody in this chamber would believe that we can go on in the way we have. We have one-third of marriages ending in divorce, we have an enormous crime rate, an abrogation of responsibility of parents for children and children living in poverty. About one million people are now living in poverty in this country. There has to be a directional change. I believe it will come about only when senators on both sides of the chamber support the objectives that are being brought forward from the Year of the Family by the Lyons Forum in their booklet,
Empowering Australian families
. I request all senators to read it.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney this day, relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's pay television venture.

speech.para: The outcome that has resulted from the government's bungling of quality pay TV in this country is a great pity. We had the opportunity given to us by the fact that there was to be established a high quality news broadcast channel to be broadcast by the ABC. We were very confident that would be a very good outcome, compared with what is likely to be on the 500 possible channels, as this pay TV system develops in this country.

para.tab: One wonders where the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee)â€”whom I called earlier today the Rip Van Winkle of communicationsâ€”was when all this development in the ABC was going on. It is not a government department, it is true. It is also not privatised. It is a corporation, and a minister has a duty of care, even though he is not controlling the decision-making in that corporation, to at least keep an eye on what it is doing and perhaps ask a few relevant questions every now and again.

When they started to spend the $12.5 million on facilities, where was he? Was he asking any questions about that? For example, did he ask the questions, `Do you people have a guaranteed carrier? Have you actually signed contracts so you can deliver the signal?' We have had one person in the commercial sector liken what the ABC has done to building the train before they had the track to run on. We have the incredible situation where they have got through to the point where they are ready to go. They have the studios, they have 100 staff employed and they have no agreement to run the signal. One wonders whether anyone has any commercial experience in this organisation. Where was the minister asking questions on this particular matter?

The other thing that happened in relation to this is that they do not have a proper regulatory regime to control this matter. It is another bungle by the ABC and one which they should correct as quickly as possible.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)
â€”Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate, having regard to the abduction of Australian citizen, Mr James Peng, and the peculiar nature of his case, and concerned at his ill health, requests the Government of the People's Republic of China on compassionate grounds to grant the immediate repatriation of Mr Peng to Australia.

speech.para: I do not wish to speak long on this matter, as it has been agreed that it should be disposed of quickly. Today we heard that Mr Peng was sentenced to an 18-year gaol sentence in the People's Republic of China on charges of embezzlement. Mr Peng was abducted from Macao over two years ago and was held in detention without charge for some 13 months. He has since been held in detention for about 11 months, during which time his case went to the court three times. The court, on none of those three prior occasions, was willing to convict Mr Peng, although an order was made that he be held in detention until investigations could reveal an offence of which he could be convicted.

para.tab: Today I was telephoned by Mr Peng's lawyers, who advised me that they understand that Mr Peng will have to serve 16 yearsâ€”which is the 18 years less the two years already servedâ€”before he will be deported from the People's Republic of China. This motion is an extraordinary motion. I am aware of that. I thank honourable senators in the chamber for their indications of support for it. It is certainly a very peculiar motion, but it is based on the very peculiar case in questionâ€”the abduction and all of the circumstances surrounding the case. I think everyone is deeply disturbed at the severity of the sentence made against Mr Peng, especially after Mr Peng was abducted from Macao and given the prolonged time he spent in prison.

I would like to take the opportunity to thank Senator McMullan and other ministers of the government for the concern that they have shown for Mr Peng's wellbeing. I thank Minister McMullan for his several attempts to raise the matter with Chinese authorities. I can assure him that I appreciate this, as does Mr Peng's family. I also thank him for his courtesy today. I must say that Senator McMullan has been first-class in regard to this matter today.

Mr Peng has suffered health problems which are of concern to his family and to others. There are of concern to the Australian ambassador and to the Australian High Commission in Hong Kong. What concerns me in the whole context of this case is that a 16-year sentence not only would appear disproportionate but also could well amount to a life sentence in the circumstances. I believe that it is important that this motion pass. I would just say that the People's Republic of China can only go up in the estimation of the world if they show compassion for Mr Peng and if they agree to his immediate repatriation to Australia.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”This is not the sort of motion that the Senate should carry as a matter of courseâ€”not because the Senate should not have serious concern about the circumstances of Australian citizens wherever they may be but because there are many Australians in circumstances which have some of the same characteristics as that of Mr Peng. It is not possible or appropriate for the Senate to carry a motion about all of them.

para.tab: While I shared Senator O'Chee's continuing concern for Mr James Peng, I did have to give some serious consideration to whether it was appropriate to have such a motion. I think there are sufficient special circumstances that have developed over the two years of this case and in terms of the manner in which it has been handled both publicly and privately by the Australian government and otherwise that indicate that perhaps on this occasion we should make an exception. I know this is cause of concern to at least one of my colleagues, and I respect his concern and his continuing active interest in this issue of Australians who are imprisoned overseas. It is properly a very important issue of human concern for all senators.

The terms of the motion have been negotiated to recognise that this motion is a product of exceptional circumstances. We recognise that Australians, wherever they live or wherever they are being active in business or otherwise, are subject to the laws of the country in which they find themselves. Sometimes that leads to legal action which is not consistent with the standards which Australia would apply, but that is the circumstance which we all confront in participating in international activity. So there needs to be recognition of that.

Our concern is that Mr Peng, an Australian citizen, appears on all the evidence to have been seized illegally in Macao and taken to China against his will. He has been held for a long time without trial. He has been held in circumstances that have caused us concern on many occasions. His health causes us concern. The circumstances of his wife and young children are a source of serious concern to those of us who know his wife and to those of us who are concerned about the circumstances in which she finds herself.

For all those reasons and for some others to do with the nature of this case that are difficult for me to speak on in public, I am prepared in these circumstances to support the motion. But I was never in any doubt about the appropriateness of the purpose of the motion, which is to seek the immediate repatriation of Mr Peng to Australia. This is a matter which I have already raised with the Chinese authorities in China last week and which I will raise with them again. As soon as I finish speaking in this chamber, I will be speaking to the ambassador about it.

I thank Senator O'Chee for his kind remarks. It has been a bipartisan issue, as it should be, and as the more general issue for concern for the welfare of Australians overseas is and should be. While recognising the very genuine and sincerely held alternative views of my colleague about the general principle, on this occasion it is a motion the subject of which merits all our support, but the procedure with which we are proceeding today should in these circumstances also warrant our support, although it is not something we should do lightly or repeat regularly.

talk.start.para: â€”I have some concerns about this motion. I do not have any concerns about the sentiment of the motion; in fact, I have great sympathy for Mr Peng and his family. From what I have heard, if he was guilty of an offence, the sentence which has been given to him is out of all proportion. I realise that that is not uncommon in countries other than ours, because I am aware of some of the sentences that have been handed down to other Australians who are overseas. I stress that I do not have any concern about the general sentiments of the motion. What concerns me is that we are singling out one Australian who was incarcerated overseas to receive the support of the Senate.

para.tab: Some honourable senators may know that I have a great interest in the welfare of Australians held in prisons overseas. It is not something that I speak of publicly very often because I think the work that I do is work between me and the individual prisoner, and it is certainly not done for public recognition.

I was recently successful in having a prisoner released from a prison in Bangkok, where she had been for 10 years. When I say that I was successful, there were a lot of other people involved as well. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) gave a great deal of support and so did the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That particular constituent inquiry, if one might call it that, took eight years to conclude. It is probably the longest constituent inquiry I have ever had, but probably the inquiry with the most pleasing result in that the lady was released from prison and she is now back in Australia. Although it took me eight years, it never occurred to me to bring the matter to the Senate for its support. I worked with officials overseas, as I am sure the Australian government is working with officials overseas and the relevant people in the Chinese government as well.

At present we have well over 100 Australians held in prisons overseas. Many of those could really come back to Australia on compassionate grounds. Earlier this year I visited two mens prisons in Bangkok and I spoke to two Australians there who are HIV positive. They were concerned that they were not even going to be considered for release or be sent back to Australia until they had AIDS. By that time, of course, they would really be coming back to Australia to die.

These two men were brothers whose mother lives in Australia and has asked me to give what assistance I can. As I suggested, the earlier case took eight years and I did not think there was anything that could be done in the short term. This lady, who is getting on in years and looking after the son of one of the boys who is in prison, and other parents and friends who have sons, daughters or loved ones in prisons overseas could, if this motion is passed, as I presume it will be, probably think that they should petition the Senate to see whether they could have the same done for their loved ones. In the case of the prisoners I know, not only in Bangkok but in Indonesia and the United States, I do not think such a resolution would be the proper way in which to proceed.

Australia is one of the few countries in the world which does not have legislation in place for the international transfer of prisoners. There is probably a historical reason for this. The Commonwealth of Australia can make treaties with overseas countries but the Commonwealth of Australia does not have any prisons in which to place people who might be brought back to Australia under an international transfer system. The states have all the prisons. It is probably because of this that we have not moved prior to this time for an international transfer process. But the international transfer process is the real answer.

I am pleased to say that a great deal of progress has been made on this in Australia. The Commonwealth has agreed with all the states bar the Northern Territoryâ€”I am not sure about the Northern Territoryâ€”on legislation to be brought before this parliament and complementary legislation to be brought before the state parliaments so that we can have an international transfer system. There are a number of types of systems around the world, so I do not want to canvass what might be in the one that comes before this parliament.

This is the real answer for many of the prisoners I have met overseas, so that they can spend some of their prison term in the jurisdiction in which they were convicted and then spend the rest of their prison term back in Australia. There are probably good compassionate reasons for this. It means their friends and families can visit them more often, they are closer to them and, if there is any rehabilitation in the Australian prison system, they would be rehabilitated to come back into Australian society, where they would be sent after they finished their prison term overseas.

It is my hope that legislation along these lines will be introduced before we rise for the summer recess. I am having negotiations with the relevant minister on this. It is not quite ready yet because there is still something that has to be done at the next meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to make sure that all the processes are in place. I am looking forward to the legislation's introduction.

I return to the motion that is before us. I have great sympathy for Mr Peng, his family, his health, the way in which he was brought to trial in China and the sentence that he was given. But for the reasons that I have outlined, I do have concerns with the motion. It is not a motion that one could vote against so I do not intend to do that. But I do find I cannot vote for it for the reasons I have outlined and I will be asking, after the vote is taken, for my abstention to be recorded in the
Journals of the Senate
.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not wish to speak for long on this subject. I agree with what Senator O'Chee said. I think he has put the case very sensitively. I certainly do not wish to make anything more difficult for Mr Peng, so I will be sensitive in what I say.

para.tab: I believe the fact that an Australian citizen was abducted from Macau must be of concern to all Australians. The fact that an Australian citizen was held without charge for so long in a Chinese gaol must be of concern to all Australians, and the fact that an Australian citizen's case should have to be considered so many times before any conviction could be found must also be of great concern to all Australians.

I have been to China twice on delegations which both looked into the legal system in China. I believe that, under the Chinese legal system, abduction is not legal, particularly in a foreign country. Although it appears that no conviction was found because the procuracy was not able to procure the correct evidence to find a conviction many times before this happened today, I would be very interested to see what evidence the procuracy found which led to a conviction, even under Chinese law. I agree with Senator O'Chee's motion and the sentiment of it and I will be voting for it.

talk.start.para: â€”I am just rising to say that coming into the chamber was the first time I had seen this motion.
â€”Your office was told.
â€”As I say, coming into the chamber was the first time I had seen this motion.
â€”Read your mail.
â€”It had not been circulated to our office.
â€”It has been in the chamber for two hours.

â€”As I am saying, I have not seen this circulated. I have not had a chance to look at its implications. Therefore, it would be very difficult for me to make a decision which I would comfortably feel is the right decision. I totally understand the concern of the family of Mr Peng and the horror they must be feeling. I also am horrified that an arrest can be obtained by abduction. What I do not know is the fine legalities of this and whether or not we would be doing the right thing by sending this message with the passing of this motion. Because of that, because I do not have the background and because I have not had a chance to look at the implications in this instance, I will need to abstain from voting.

â€”in replyâ€”In closing the debate, I acknowledge the very real and genuine concerns that Senator Colston has had and also Senator Colston's consistent actions over a long period of time for the benefit of very many people. In relation to what Senator Margetts just said, I should point out that persistent efforts were made to contact Senator Margetts's office during lunch. The motion was circulated in the chamber during question time, but nobody from the Greens was present during question time to receive the motion. It was circulated at about half past one. All efforts were made to contact Senator Margetts. All other parties and the Independent in the chamber were contacted. I conclude by reiterating my remarksâ€”this is a very peculiar case and I urge support for the motion from all honourable senators.

debate.sub1.title: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Europe on French Nuclear Testing

speech.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator ROBERT RAY
talker.role: Minister for Defence)

talk.start.para:
â€”I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a statement relating to the visit of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Europe between 2 and 17 September 1995 on French nuclear testing.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The statement read as follows
â€”

Madame Acting President, I welcome this opportunity to report to honourable Senators on the multi-party parliamentary delegation which the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs led to Europe in the first half of September. Senators will recall that the delegation comprised the Member for Chifley, the Member for Mayo, the Member for Moreton, the Right Honourable Member for New England, Senator Bourne and the Minister. The delegation visited eight countries in quick succession: Germany, Belgium, the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark and Austria. As you know, the Minister had to leave the delegation after the first week in order to attend the South Pacific Forum in PNG, and the Member for Chifley, the Hon Roger Price, who is chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade, led the delegation in his absence.

speech.para: This visit was a result of the upswelling of outrage among Australians at France's decision to resume nuclear testing in the Pacific. All Australians are appalled at the decision of President Chirac to ignore world opinion and to break the moratorium on testing introduced by his predecessor. This decision shows complete disregard for the feelings of those living in this region who are deeply concerned about the environmental impacts over the long term. Australians do not accept that these tests are either defensible or necessary. And in all sorts of ways the Australian people has given expression to its anger on this issue. We have sent delegations to France, we have sent protests, we have taken action in international forums and we have given the French government no comfort whatsoever on this issue.

What did this delegation set out to do? Its main goal was to convey to the parliaments, governments and peoples of europe our determined opposition to nuclear testing. It wanted to encourage a more forthright stance on the part of France's European neighbours, as we know that the only way we will end nuclear testing is by building a unanimous international chorus of opposition to itâ€”and the countries of Europe are particularly important in this regard. It wanted to lobby for a resolution in the United Nations condemning all nuclear testing. It also wanted to urge support for a truly comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty which would ban all testing in all environments for all time. And finally, it wanted to explain the reasons for Australia's position, to make clear that our disagreement with France was confined to the single issue of nuclear testing.

para.tab: Here let me say that it is quite surprising to see some of the misinformation which has crept into the public mind in Europe on this issue. For example, the minister was asked by one interviewer why the Australian government was funding Greenpeace's activities! It is a curious but unfortunate fact that from the distant vantage point of Europe it is easy to depict the Australian government as responsible for a variety of protest actions, some of which are illegal. The delegation was in Paris at the time of the riots in Papeete and it is certain that in the eyes of some there was the idea that the Australian government was somehow involved. Of course the government does not condone illegal protest activity.

I am pleased to report, Madame Acting President, that the delegation achieved its principal objectives to a very substantial degree. The delegation had some 37 meetings with government ministers, parliamentary committees, other parliamentarians and relevant figures in bodies such as the European Union and International Atomic Energy Agency. The delegation held press conferences and gave media interviews in each country, to pursue our goal of raising public awareness of Australia's position. In addition the delegation took part in a video conference from Stockholm with the foreign relations committee of the Finnish parliament. The delegation also attended part of the opening of oral pleadings in New Zealand's action against French testing in the International Court of Justice.

speech.para: The countries visited were very deliberately selected and in all but three countries, the delegation's interlocutors were very receptive to their representations, and discussions focused on ways in which we could work together to advance our shared objectives. In two countriesâ€”Germany and the United Kingdomâ€”public opinion is running strongly against renewed testing, but for various reasons the response of governments has been disappointingly quiet. In these places the delegation was given a polite and attentive hearing but it was clear that there was a reluctance to take on board Australia's views, or for that matter the views of their own constituencies, on this issue. Nevertheless, it was pleasing to notice that after the delegations visits there, when the first test was held, both the German Foreign Minister and the leader of the British opposition issued statements which advanced their public positions on the issue: and for that reason, and as a result of our continuing pressure, I believe the chance of further movement by these countries is considerable.

The visit to France of course fell into a category of its own. But even there the delegation was very pleased at the access it was to senior ministers. The delegation met the Minister of Defence, the Minister for Overseas Territories and the Minister for Aid. A meeting with the French Foreign Minister was scheduled but had to be cancelled because of an urgent international meeting on Bosnia which he had to attend.

The delegation's discussions were forthright and robust yet were held in a calm atmosphere. The French ministers explained the reasons for their government's decision. Delegation members for their part put to the French very clearly Australia's position on the issue. They went through one by one the reasons advanced by the French side, pointing out that the arguments in favour of testing were based on false premises. That is to say, arguments about reliability would make sense to a mathematician or a defence scientist, but in the real world no potential aggressor would stake his chances on the possibility that French nuclear missiles would not work. Given that 200 odd French tests so far have been successful, the chance that a first weapon used in anger would not go off is not one an aggressor would be likely to take. And if not the first, what about the second, or third?

Delegation members also attempted to explore further the possibility that france might obtain the data to construct computer simulation programs which it is looking for from other nuclear powers such as the united states. This is a matter mr bilney had raised on several occasions before, including before president chirac's election. I regret to say that the French authorities do not seem interested in the ideaâ€”for one reason or another it has not appealed to france.

The delegation took particular pains to explain to the French ministers that Australia was not attempting to deprive France of its nuclear capability. They reiterated Australia's opposition to testing being carried out by china as well as France. They took issue time and again with the view that Australia was opposed to France's place in the pacific or that the government was encouraging economic boycotts of French goods: neither is the case.

I have to say that these discussions did not yield the results the delegation might have wished. On the need for France to continue testing, it did not persuade its interlocutors to accept Australia's point of view. But I am sure that they now understand our position much better, even if they do not agree with it.

It is clear that an important part of the overall success of the delegation was the broad participation in it of all major parties represented in the parliament. I would like to pay tribute to the contributions of all delegation members, from the government, the opposition and the Australian democrats. The fact that all the major political parties in the parliament were represented helped reinforce the impact it made, by underlining the fact that opposition to nuclear testing is shared across the political spectrum in this country. It was particularly useful when meeting ministers and mps from the conservative side of politics, for example in the uk, that they should hear our messages conveyed by people who, on other issues, would normally be expected to share similar views.

Where do we go from here? The campaign is by no means over. Another delegation from this parliament, led by the president of the senate, is currently in europe on a visit to the european parliament, spain and the oecd. This delegation will be raising the same issues as part of its agenda.

Australia is continuing to make its voice heard in international forums. Australia is actively involved in negotiations on a draft resolution for debate in the united nations general assembly which we hope will gain the widest possible support. This will be an important way of giving expression to the international community's condemnation of nuclear testing.

It now seems inevitable, though I say it with reluctance, that more tests will occur, but certainly not as many as we first thought. Nor is it clear to the government that any further bilateral action that Australia could take would make president chirac change his mind. I do believe, however, that the storm of opposition which has been aroused over this issueâ€”and of which this delegation was partâ€”has had a measurable impact in France. One has only to look at France's welcome acceptance of a zero-yield CTBTâ€”as promoted by Australiaâ€”as well as the statement by President Chirac which clearly leaves open the possibility that the number of tests may be reduced. There are also indications that the duration of the test series will be shortened. I am optimistic that a sustained campaign of public opposition will reinforce this trend and that we will soon see a definitive end to nuclear testing in this part of the world.

On behalf of the delegation I conclude by expressing thanks to the officers of the Parliamentary Relations Office and officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra and overseas who, in their unfailingly helpful and efficient way, put together the arrangements for this visit and made an important contribution to its success.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: â€”I was a member of this delegation to Europe. I was the only member of the Senate who was on this delegation. I would just like to make a few brief remarks about it.

para.tab: It was a fascinating delegation to be on, not least because there was agreement between the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney), Mr Roger Price, Mr Alexander Downer, Mr Ian Sinclair, Mr Garrie Gibson and myselfâ€”absolute, complete and utter agreementâ€”that nuclear testing should be banned absolutely and for all time. I suspect this may be the only topic on the face of the earth to which we all subscribe and agree, especially considering some of our conversations on trains and planes and at dinner. But we were absolutely in agreement on this topic.

Our main goal, as Mr Bilney says in the statement just tabled by Senator Ray, was to convey to parliaments, governments and peoples of Europe our determined opposition to nuclear testing. I think we did that very well. We were able with different governments of different persuasions and different members of parliament of different persuasions to put a point of view that came from somebody who agreed with them on almost everything else but who did not agree with them on the topic of nuclear testing, particularly in the cases of the United Kingdom and, of course, of France.

I was particularly disappointed by our visit to the United Kingdom. In almost every country we visited, including France, we were given very high level access to ministers and to foreign affairs committees, and very large numbers of the representatives of those committees turned up. In Belgium, I think 37 members of their committee turned up. In the Netherlands, most of the committee turned up. It was not as Senator Margetts mentioned to me before we leftâ€”and this does happen, I must admitâ€”`You might have a couple of people turn up from the committee and that will be that.' It was not like that at all. We did have a lot of people come to the meetings.

We had high level access, except in the United Kingdom. We were all very disappointed by our access in the United Kingdom and by the reaction of the minister, whom we did meet. I must say that he gave us nearly an hour of his time, but that hour of his time was taken up with putting the French point of view, sayingâ€”and I hope I am not being unfair to him here; I do not think I amâ€”that Britain's ultimate goal was for the French to sign the CTBTâ€”of course, that is everyone's ultimate goalâ€”and the way to do that would be to allow the French to carry out these tests and then that would be that.

None of us agreed with that. Mr Downer, I thought, was particularly good in his statements to Mr Davies, particularly since he is on the same side on most things, as he pointed out to Mr Davies. But on this, he was notâ€”none of us was.

In Britain we met the opposition; they were very good and put out a statement when we had left. In France, the ministers and the members of the conservative parties we met were not in favour of what we were sayingâ€”not surprisinglyâ€”but they were very polite about it and gave us a lot of time, gave us high access and were very decent about it. They did not agree with us. I do not think we convinced them, but then again they did not convince us at all either. Apart from those two places, everywhere else we went everybody we spoke to, except for perhaps a couple of people, absolutely agreed with us.

We found some very interesting statistics as we went around. In France, more than 60 per cent of the population does not agree with the nuclear testing. In Germany and Belgium, 93 per cent to 95 per cent of the population does not agree with nuclear testing, and I would imagine that the percentages would be about that size in the other countries we went to. A recent poll showed that in Australia and New Zealand it is about the sameâ€”95 per cent of people disagree. We encountered a lot of support.

Our goal was to put our point, our case, to try to get support and to try to make these people in Europe make known their support to the French. I think we did that to a large extent as well. We wanted to get support for our United Nations motion on this. I hope we did well in thatâ€”I think we did. We certainly appeared to when we were there. We wanted to put the points of view from our side which would counter what the French had been saying about us, particularly what Mr Chirac was saying about us in
Le Figaro
and what he was saying about us on television, which, as we all know, was just totally outrageous in many ways.

I think we countered that very well. In most countries we went to when we started trying to counter that we were told, `Don't bother. We don't believe it anyway. It's just silly.' So that was good. We were asked everywhere we went, `What is your main objection to this?' Our main objection to this is that it is a very bad signal for every other country on earth in regard to nuclear testing. That was our main objection. Mr Bilney put it a couple of timesâ€”and it is a good pointâ€”that there is absolutely no need for anybody to carry out one more test.

Who in their right mind, or even not in their right mind, is going to consider taking an action which will result in nuclear retaliation when the 200 tests that the French have carried out before now have been successful? Are they going to need another eight tests to worry about whether the next one will be successful? Of course they are not. If the next is not successful then the one after that or the one after that will be. The French obviously have a large enough stockpile for that not to worry them.

That point was put many times and I think was accepted many times. We were asked almost everywhere we went about the environmental aspects of this. We gave copies of the report to the South Pacific environment ministers, which had been commissioned by Senator Faulkner, to many people in Europe. That was very useful, I must say.

The basic point about that report is that it is not a matter of: will the environment be degraded or will the nuclear waste material get into the water? Of course it will. There is no question about that. The question is: when will this happen? The answer to that is: it could be as soon as 50 years or it could be further into the future. It is most certainly contributing to the pollution of a marine environment. A marine environment is incredibly delicate. Letting off nuclear bombs in a marine environment is incredibly stupid. I think everybody we spoke to agreed with us on that.

I would like to thank the people I went with. It is a very motley group, I must say. You would not think we would all get on. Even though we did disagree on many topics apart from nuclear testing, we did all get on, which was a great comfort. I think the delegation went to eight countries in 10 days or something like that, so we were in each other's company on planes, trains and things like that a great deal. None of us was ever late, which was another major plus for a delegation like this.

talk.start.para: â€”That was an unusual delegation!

â€”It was a wonderful delegation, yes. I do not think I will ever be on a delegation like this again. I was very pleased and very honoured to have been asked to go on it. I would like to thank, in particular, the parliamentary relations officer who did all our travel bookingsâ€”and very wellâ€”and also all our diplomatic staff that we came across in Europe. I know I say this every time, but it is true. Australia has some of the best diplomatic staff in the world and they are far too unsung. They do a wonderful job under very difficult circumstances sometimes. In this case they still did a wonderful job.

para.tab: We put our case very forcefully. We put our case in every possible forum we could think of, including the European Union and the International Atomic Energy Agency. I think we put it very strongly. I was not at the International Atomic Energy Agency but I understand from those who were that that was a very disappointing meeting.

I do not wish to bring up any dissension in this report but I must sayâ€”and I feel very strongly about thisâ€”that I find the explanations that have been given to us by those who know all about nuclear test ban treaties as to why we should not worry about Australian uranium being used in French bombs to be very inadequate. The explanation given to us is that uranium is a fungible material. What a wonderful word `fungible'. It means that any handful of yellow cake, which is a hideous concept in itself, is absolutely interchangeable with any other handful of yellow cake. Therefore, the yellow cake that Australia sends to France is absolutely interchangeable with France's own yellow cake. Therefore, of course, Australian uranium can end up in French bombs. I find that a thoroughly unsatisfactory way to carry out any safeguards treaty. I hope we have learned a lesson from this and that next time treaties of this kind are negotiated we keep it in mind and do not accept the concept of a fungible material.
I believe it was a very successful delegation. We did what we set out to do. And at the end of it all we are still friends, which is quite a remarkable thing in itself.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak briefly on the report of the parliamentary delegation to Europe relating to the French nuclear testing. I am glad that the delegation went to Europe but I would like to follow on from some of Senator Bourne's remarks about Britain.

para.tab:
The response of a number of people to nuclear powers such as Britain not making public comment about the French or Chinese nuclear testing is, `What's in it for them?' It may well be that a nuclear power does not want to be put in a glasshouse that other people can throw stones atâ€”which is understandableâ€”but the true answer could well that suggested by the
Guardian
and other news sources, that the link between Britain and France is financial support for the French nuclear testing program and data sharing. If so, that is despicable.

The official response from Britain is that this is an internal matter. That, coming from a country which is occupying Northern Ireland, is an appalling statement. We have to look squarely at countries like Britain and ask why they have not been called to account for not taking a stronger stand on this matter.

I remind honourable senators that on 24 August 1995 the Senate passed a motion that the Australian government should help to coordinate a high level regional representation to China to clearly express the strong regional opposition to its nuclear testing program. I would like to leave the Senate with these questions: when will that take place; how will it be organised; and, please, may we have details as soon as possible?
Question resolved in the affirmative.
