talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: â€”The government's response to this report is another chapter in the long saga of the marketing of this disability reform packageâ€”a saga which will not end with this government response. I first brought this matter to the Senate's attention in 1991, four years ago, when concern was first expressed to me that Commonwealth money was being wasted on a campaign to market the disability reform package.

para.tab: A $4.95 million contract was let to a company called Corporate Impacts Pty Ltd to market the disability reform package in August 1991. The departments involved in this project were DAASâ€”the Office of Government Information and Advertising, as it was then known; DEET; DHHS, as it was then known, the Department of Health and Human Services; and the Department of Social Security. It was also estimated that, over and above the $4.95 million contract, the department spent an additional $600,000 in administering the project.

Each stage of that project involved gross mismanagement from the beginning, from the letting of a contractâ€”a $5 million contractâ€”which was done by selective tendering. I have to say that it was almost impossible for other than the company that got the contract to get it because of the way it was structuredâ€”and that should still be examined and that still has a lot of question marks hanging over it. The chairman of the ministerial committee at the time still has a lot of questions to answer about that and about how that contract was let. But once that company was selected, did anybody bother to do a Dunn and Bradstreet check on the company? No. It was balance sheet insolvent at the time it got that contract worth nearly $5 million. It went from bad to worse.

I had to pursue each department. I had to go to the estimates committees and ask questions of DAS; I had to go to the estimates committees and ask questions of DEET; I had to go to the estimates committees and ask questions of Social Security; I had to go to the estimates committees and ask questions of Healthâ€”all because there was no single department responsible for that $5 million contract.

A staff member from OGIA at one point said to me, `Oh, Senator, we were just chairing the meeting. We didn't have a vote.' Two of the departments wanted to stop the contract, and one of them did notâ€”and there is a whole cloud hanging over why one of them did not want to stop the contract, but there is another story in that. When I asked, `Well, why didn't you stop it?', they said, `Oh, we needed consensus, Senator. One of the departments didn't want to stop the contract.' So on they went down the path of disaster. When we really could not get satisfactory answers and it looked like there needed to be some really serious questions asked about the letting of this contractâ€”about the contract itself, and about the fact that the company was given money before the contract was signedâ€”every time I asked a question in estimates, more information came up that just showed it was an absolute bungle and total mismanagement.

The Senate then agreed to an inquiry, so the Community Affairs References Committee actually had an inquiry and made 33 recommendations about the letting of contracts and about this particular contract. Today the government has responded, in a way. We get the committee's recommendations listed, the government's response and some comments. Let me say that in the majority of cases, not all of them, the government has agreed with the recommendations. I suppose it was very difficult for the government not to agree with most of them because it was a majority reportâ€”it was a report that was agreed to by all the members of the committee on both sides of the house and the Democrats.

I think we see here some rather inadequate responses, and we see some areas where the government has actually learnt from this. One of the things the government has agreed to is that, if there is a contract which is let across departments, there should be a lead department. We should not have had to have a Senate committee to recommend to a government that has been in office for 13 years that when you have a contract at this level, especially for $5 million, you have to have a lead department. You have to have someone responsible.

When I was asking questions, there was not one head of department who was totally responsible, and there was not one minister who was responsible. Everyone said, `Oh, that wasn't our responsibility, Minister.' Talk about passing the buck. It went on and on and on. Finally, after a committee inquiry into it, we have a recommendation that where there is a contract across departments we have a lead department. It does not take a genius to see that that is what is needed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.sub1.title: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

speech.speaker: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para:
â€”I present the government's response to the reports of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee inquiry into the development of open learning in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in
Hansard
and to move a motion in relation to the document.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
â€”

speech.para: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO "INQUIRY INTO THE DEVELOPMENT OF OPEN LEARNING IN AUSTRALIAâ€”PARTS 1 AND 2"

para.emphasis: OVERVIEW
Scope of the report

speech.para: Part 1 of the report was published in December 1994 and Part 2 was published in March 1995. The Government response is a consolidated response to both parts of the report.
Part 1 deals primarily with open learning in higher education and the roles of the Open Learning Agency of Australia (OLAA) and the Open Learning Technology Corporation (OLTC).

Part 2 addresses other issues which were raised in the course of the Inquiry. These include the role of Distance Education Centres in providing open learning, issues of credit transfer, use of flexible delivery in the vocational education and training (VET) sector, student support, the professional development of teachers, future broadband services and the potential advantages offered by an information superhighway, the use of the Tanami Network and access to communications technologies by the adult and community education sector and people with a disability.

para.emphasis: Overall response to Part 1 of the report

speech.para: The Government supports the Committee's overall positive response to the operation of the Open Learning Agency of Australia (OLAA), in particular, that the Committee considers that the OLA is making a valuable contribution to the provision of higher education in Australia by bringing increased flexibility to the higher education sector, promoting increased cooperation between institutions and stimulating critical evaluation of existing services to students.

The Government also supports the Committee's view that open learning is an approach, rather than a system or technique, which is based on the needs of individual learners which is moving the role of the teacher from a source of knowledge to a manager of learning and a facilitator. The Government agrees that this is an ideal that has yet to be realised.

Open learning is an approach which facilitates access to learning which meets the learner's needs in terms of content, learning style and access. However, in many of its recommendations, the Committee separates open learning from the more encompassing issue of learner centred education. For example, the Committee's concern that the quality of open learning courses delivered through the OLA cannot be maintained under the present cost structure does not fully appreciate the convergence of these approaches in the provision of high quality education delivery.

By way of explanation, the Government's Open Learning Initiative (OLI) seeks to capitalise on the Government's already significant funding for the provision of higher education by using existing courses and learning resources. Open learning course designers are expected to draw on the experience and knowledge gained from distance education and flexible delivery experiences to provide courses and materials that can be delivered as stand alone units, requiring minimal additional delivery support. Courses delivered through the OLA do not impose capital costs on provider universities as students do not attend lectures or tutorials as part of their study, nor do they impose costs on infrastructure support as students do not access many of the services and resources provided for on-campus and external students. Direct comparisons cannot be made between the costs of open learning provision and the costs of on-campus or off-campus study.

Second, the OLI seeks to widen access to tertiary education by ensuring that open learning students are not financially disadvantaged by choosing this approach. Open learning students make a contribution to their education similar to that of other students undertaking undergraduate studies through more traditional approaches who attract a liability under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS).

The Committee discussed the pilot implementation of the Open Learning Electronic Support Service (OLESS). The Minister publicly launched the full rollout of the service, now called Open Net, on 19 May 1995.

The Government supports the Committee's view that the service must be accessible to remote and rural students and that fees for use should be equitable. To achieve these objectives, the Government has required Open Net to provide national local call access to the service, to provide access for both IBM, IBM compatible and Macintosh computers and to develop a national network of local access points using existing community facilities to permit access for those subscribers who do not have a computer or the appropriate communications software.
Attention needs to be drawn to inaccuracies on the part of the Senate Committee concerning the trends in OLA enrolments, the costs of OLA courses and the obligations on members of the OLA consortium:

.
on page 66 of the report, the Committee expresses concern that the total number of registrants in OLA courses is falling when in fact they are increasing. The Committee has confused student registrations across all four study periods in 1993 with the student numbers for individual study periods in 1994. In the four study periods in 1993, 5125 students registered in 8906 study units. Over 9,000 students registered in over 22,200 study units in the four study periods in 1994. The pattern of registration has been similar in 1993 and 1994 with a gradual decline in student registrations for each study period as the year progresses. This is consistent with second semester enrolments of on-campus students;

.
on page 45 of the report, the comments regarding costs of OLA courses for a student are misleading. The student course costs of open learning units are broadly equivalent to the costs of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). An undergraduate OLA unit is equivalent in credit to one eighth of a full time load at the provider university. Therefore, the OLA student can gain a full year's credit for study for a cost of $2,440. The equivalent student contribution for on-campus or external study through HECS is $2,355;

.
on page 29, Mr Ken Widdowson, in evidence to the Committee, advised that OLA consortium members are not allowed to belong to PAGE. This is not correct. There is no prohibition on PAGE consortium members belonging to the OLA consortium or vice versa.

The Government also supports the Committee's positive view of the initial work of the OLTC, but notes the Committee's concern that the commercial orientation of the OLTC might place at risk the aspect of public benefit implicit in the OLTC's services. Specifically the Government notes the Committee's concerns that the OLTC's services of public benefit are presently funded almost entirely from the recurrent contributions of public moneys from the Commonwealth and State/Territory members which could cease at a later stage.

The purpose of the Commonwealth's funding of the OLTC has been to provide seed funding for the piloting of OLTC services which provide public benefit so that education and training sectors and State and Territory systems can experience these services and be informed of the costs and benefits of providing them. Examples include Commonwealth seed funding for the establishment of information services on open learning delivery and products and for the development of a framework for the implementation of broadband services for the education and training sectors.

The Commonwealth expects that MCEETYA Ministers will consider the funding of a range of OLTC services with community benefit and develop and establish guidelines. More immediately, the development of the OLTC's role as the Governing Body of Education Network Australia (EdNA), described below, will require a review of its commercial and public good responsibilities.
The Government's decision to develop EdNA is a significant consideration which underpins the Government's response to many of the Committee's recommendations.

EdNA will link all schools, TAFEs and universities and other education and training providers across the nation, as well as internationally through a service network and modern technology for interactive communication. EdNA will offer national coverage and provide full access to the Internet. It will offer secure communications and enable users such as schools to control access of individual users to particular categories of information. Initial services will include electronic mail, bulletin boards and real time chat sessions. Over time, the network will provide services such as interactive voice and video communication. The Government has approved funding of $1.5 million in 1995-96 and $500,000 each year in subsequent years to pilot the first stage of EdNA.

MCEETYA ministers agreed in principle at their May 1995 meeting that the Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments will collaborate in the establishment of a mechanism to manage and oversee, in broad terms, the use of EdNA and the provision of infrastructure necessary to receive EdNA services.

para.emphasis: Overall response to Part 2 of the report

speech.para: The Government welcomes the positive approach in Part 2 of the report in regard to the Committee's citation of successful open learning initiatives across all sectors of education and training and its enthusiastic support for the greater use of open learning approaches in education and training.

The report also highlights the need for further change within educational institutions to initiate learner centred learning and notes impediments to its development caused by the barriers between education and training sectors. This is reflected in the report's recommendations to use national education and training forums and agencies to develop deliberate and co-ordinated policy to ensure a national shift to open learning.

As with recommendations contained in Part 1 of the report, recommendations in Part 2 tend to separate open learning from the more encompassing issue of learner centred education. By way of contrast, the DEET submission to the Inquiry states that issues of good practice teaching and learner centred learning are inseparable. Consequently, the Government's response to many of the recommendations assumes that learner centred strategies should be intrinsic to sectoral education and training practices. The Government does not support the Committee's statement that "
nothing short of a major national effort to bring existing structures and policies into a coherent framework for open learning will enable us to manage the many dimensions of education and training which our social, cultural and economic aspirations logically require"
(page 74). This statement ignores the significant developments in open learning within and across sectors some of which are outlined below.

However, the Government does support cross sectoral collaboration on the use of communications infrastructure and research into learner centred pedagogy which uses appropriate educational technologies and delivery methods.

The Government's approach is exemplified by its support of a range of initiatives some of which were documented in the DEET submission to the Inquiry, and some of which constitute new policy in the 1995-96 Budget. These initiatives are referred to under the various recommendations. These include the Open Learning Initiative and the development of Open Net services as part of this initiative and the proposed establishment of Education Network Australia (EdNA).

On page 69, the report also discusses the need for collaboration and co-operation within and between systems in the development of curriculum and courseware. It notes that organisations can duplicate course development because of the lack of readily accessible information about what is being funded.

This need to avoid duplication of initiatives in open learning has been recognised and addressed to a significant extent by Commonwealth policy to date. In the higher education sector, for example, the assessment of proposals for the funding of development of resource materials, through programs such as the Committee for the Advancement of University Teaching and the National Priority (Reserve) Fund, seeks to ensure that projects do not duplicate work already being funded by the Department. The development of information services through EdNA should also serve to avoid duplication of initiatives including those supporting course development.

para.emphasis: RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS IN PART 1
The Open Learning Agency of Australia

speech.para: Recommendation No 1: The Committee recommends that DEET fund OLA students at a level equivalent to 50 per cent of EFTSU to ensure the viability of the OLA initiative, to give OLA-enrolled students better quality student support and to ensure that equity considerations are met.

The Government does not support this recommendation. The OLA is an independent organisation, outside the National Unified System, established by the Government to broker open learning services on a fee for service basis. To ensure that equity considerations are met, the fee paid by OLA students has been set at a level broadly equivalent to HECS. OLA uses existing university courses and facilities and contracts with provider institutions to deliver these to OLA students. Institutions are required to ensure that courses and materials are delivered as stand alone units, requiring minimal additional delivery support. Criticisms of the current funding arrangements do not take into account the considerable Commonwealth funding already provided towards the development of these courses and the existing expertise in distance education and flexible delivery methodologies. Notwithstanding criticisms about the costs of open learning, the Government notes that the number of institutions ready to provide open learning subjects has increased in 1995 to 24 (including four TAFE institutions) and the number of units offered will increase in 1995 to over 220.

The Committee's concern that the current funding arrangements could lead to open learning units becoming second rate is misplaced. Study units and courses available through the OLA are subject to an institution's quality assurance mechanisms to ensure that units have parity of esteem with on-campus and off-campus offerings of that institution. Institutions must offer full credit for units offered through the OLA. In addition, all consortium members must allow full credit transfer for OLA units and consortium members are also represented on an academic advisory board which assures the quality of units offered.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 2: The Committee recommends that OLA be funded to provide a year round educational advisory service to prospective students. Such a service would include assistance with

speech.para: selection of courses appropriate to each student's level of achievement, interest and need
understanding the requirements of universities with respect to their academic standards
determining the level of tutorial assistance likely to be required for successful completion of the units in which they are enrolled
proper utilisation of television programs as learning resources
planning an appropriate degree pathway.

The Government supports this recommendation and notes that it is already funding the OLA to provide this service. The OLA's Agreement with the Commonwealth states that the OLA will provide
advisory services to assist participants to plan a coherent study sequence where desired leading to an award, and to provide on going information and clarification on degree options, units available, registration requirements, cross-crediting, certification, progression, course requirements and eligibility for graduation
. In addition the Agreement provides for the OLA to stipulate service standards for university providers which include course and study skills advice to be readily available by phone. Under these arrangements, a student is able to contact the appropriate person in the institution and discuss problems as they arise, as the Committee recommends.
Optional tutorials are already available to students on a user-pays basis.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 3: The Committee recommends that the Open Learning Tutorial Assistance Program (OLTA) operate under the auspices of the OLA from 1996 and that, once the OLA has that responsibility, it ensures that tutors have appropriate qualifications, training and support for their roles.

speech.para: The Government supports this recommendation.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 4: The Committee recommends that the rules governing the Open Learning Deferred Payment Scheme (OLDPS) be changed so that it operates on the same basis as the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). In particular, there should be no discrimination in access to OLDPS on the basis of study load.

speech.para: The Open Learning Deferred Payment Scheme is currently being reviewed by DEET, in consultation with the OLA and the Australian Taxation Office, to assess whether the scheme is meeting its objectives. The review will also examine the eligibility rules and the efficiency of current administrative arrangements. The review is scheduled to be completed by the end of July 1995.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 5: The Committee recommends that a special allocation be made to the University National Staff Development Fund for the purposes of training in instructional and courseware design, with such allocation targeted at academics involved in course design for open learning.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation. The Commonwealth Staff Development Fund (SDF) was set up to assist higher education staff development in the context of award restructuring. The main focus of the SDF to date has been on upgrading the academic qualifications of former Advanced Education College staff. Therefore, it would not be an appropriate funding source for the training proposed in the recommendation. Training of staff and academics in course design for open learning should not be separated from training of staff in courseware design for on-campus and off-campus courses, as open learning courses are derived from existing courseware. The Government is currently undertaking a review of the Fund. The Fund was established to run for six years from 1990 and a decision about its future should be made by late 1995.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 6: The Committee recommends that the Government enter into negotiations with the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee (AVCC) and Monash University for the restructuring of the OLA as a company owned by the AVCC and under the direction of a board established by the AVCC. Such an arrangement must be based on a commitment to the maintenance and further development of the OLA both nationally and internationally.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation. The Commonwealth has a legally binding agreement with the OLA which is a private company. The company already functions as a consortium of universities and the current providers represent some 50% of institutions in the unified national system. Other organisations can negotiate consortium membership.

para.emphasis: The Open Learning Technology Corporation

speech.para: Recommendation No 7: Through MCEETYA, the Commonwealth and States jointly fund the OLTC to undertake a benchmarking study of technology use in schools for the purpose of informing policy decisions on the utilisation of broadband services by the education and training sectors.

The substance of this recommendation has already been met through initiatives supported by Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers. At the MCEETYA meeting in Alice Springs on November 4 1994, Ministers agreed that an investigation and analysis of education and training needs would be undertaken by the OLTC with regard to the future and proposed use of a broadband service network. It was also agreed that the OLTC would develop a collaborative framework for the implementation of broadband services for the education and training sectors for consideration by MCEETYA. DEET is funding this project. DEET has also funded the OLTC to survey all education and training sectors on their use of interactive multimedia and the Curriculum Corporation to survey the use of computing and communications equipment in schools as an initial step in the benchmarking exercise.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 8: The Committee recommends that MCEETYA establish guidelines for the OLTC regarding the public benefit dimension of its role and how this should relate to its commercial obligations to shareholders.

speech.para: The OLTC was set up as a small body to provide project management, information and brokerage services to the open learning community on a commercial fee-for-service basis and at discounted rates for Members, as part of membership subscription entitlements. Ministers agreed that core funding would cover services required by all members (ie Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers responsible for employment, education and training), as reflected in the feasibility study conducted in April 1991, and that services required by some users only would be provided on a user pays basis. The subscriptions were agreed at $795,000 a year at that time with the States/Territories contributing on the basis of the Australian Council on Educational Research formula (Commonwealth 50% and States/Territories proportional to populations). To some extent this reflects the limited knowledge of the roll-out and range of services to be offered by the OLTC at that time and the uncertain levels of client demand for services.

Since that decision the Commonwealth has provided funding to the OLTC to investigate and pilot services from which Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers can decide future levels of service required. All of these initiatives have potential public benefit. The initiatives funded by the Commonwealth were listed in the Commonwealth's submission to the Inquiry. Examples include consultancies and initiatives to investigate the potential for open learning services to assist people with a disability, to promote flexible delivery to small business, to facilitate change management in education and training systems in relation to the adoption of open learning technologies and to develop technical specifications to support education guidelines for interactive multi media for the use of education and training providers and industry.

MCEETYA Ministers can currently fund the OLTC to provide services of community benefit within and across States and Territories. The OLTC will be reporting to MCEETYA Ministers on cost-benefit implications of its existing services and will provide advice on priority projects providing community benefit. If they wish, MCEETYA Ministers can then establish guidelines for the OLTC regarding the public benefit dimension of its role and provide funding accordingly. More immediately, the response notes that the review of the OLTC being undertaken as part of its proposed function as the Governing Body of EdNA, might also reconsider its commercial and public good responsibilities.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 9: That MCEETYA appoint to the OLTC board at least one person with qualifications in communications engineering or a related discipline, and that the OLTC acquire the skills of a qualified communications engineer, either on staff or on a consultancy basis.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation. Ministers agreed in August 1991, at the 67th AEC meeting the composition of the OLTC board in relation to types of expertise required. Ministers can change these requirements if desired. All Ministers have the opportunity of nominating board members, the list of nominations being voted on by all members. In determining membership of the board Ministers have not been constrained by requirements for specific expertise.

Changes are being made to the OLTC board to achieve specific objectives of MCEETYA Ministers responding to the establishment of EdNA. In May 1995, Ministers agreed in principle, as part of the process of restructuring the OLTC to fulfil the role of the Governing Body of EdNA, that as a temporary measure, the board should be expanded to include additional experts from key sectors (two from the schools sector, two from the VET sector, two from the higher education sector and one from the Commonwealth), the schools and the VET experts being nominated by the Ministers responsible for those sectors and the higher education experts being nominated by the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee and approved by Ministers out of session.

Rather than including communications expertise on the board, Ministers agreed that, in relation to this exercise, a Network Business Requirement Reference Group be established composed of representatives nominated by the Ministers responsible for the relevant sectors to assist the Commonwealth to define the network business requirement with the business requirement to be submitted to the Reference Group for clearance and to Ministers for approval by September 1995.

In regard to the recommendation that the OLTC engage the services of a qualified communications engineer, the OLTC has limited funds and has to date employed expertise on a project basis in line with current business practice . The OLTC has permanent staff with expertise in the application of communications technology to the educational environment.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 10: The Committee recommends that in order to better inform policy making involving communications technologies, the Government requests the Australian Bureau of Statistics to provide data, through its national household survey, on the ownership by households of communications technology and the corresponding patterns of usage.

speech.para: The Government supports this recommendation. In January this year the ABS published information collected in February 1994 on Household Use of Information Technology and is considering re-running the survey. The Government recognises the significance of the data for education and training policy. DEET will be responding to this initiative and will be considering the need for the purchase of questions.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 11: The Committee recommends the appointment of a disabilities officer charged with ensuring that the needs and interests of people with disabilities are, from the outset, factored into all advisory, design, project management, evaluation and service brokerage activities of the corporation.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation as it stands. However, DEET supports the direction of the recommendation to ensure that open learning initiatives are inclusive of people with a disability. In 1994, DEET funded a research project to explore the current situation and potential of open learning to meet the needs of people with a disability.

DEET implemented the findings of the above research by funding the OLTC to engage a consultant to undertake, edit and disseminate across all education and training sectors and the disabilities field the report
An Enabling Vision
and to organise a conference in February 1995. This conference brought together representatives of the disabilities field and experts in open learning to advise the OLTC on the development of services to improve access to education and training for people with disabilities. The OLTC will be advising MCEETYA Ministers on the outcomes of the conference.

para.emphasis: RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS IN PART 2

Recommendation No 1: The Committee recommends that MCEETYA establish a forum which is representative of the key education and training interests to develop a national blueprint for the implementation of open learning across the schools, VET and higher education sectors.

speech.para: The Government supports this recommendation. In particular, the Government acknowledges the need for cross sectoral co-operation to support increased compatibility of delivery modes and to stimulate pedagogical debate. This includes the use of technology and common educational goals in regard to life long learning and learner centred approaches to education delivery.

As mentioned above, the Government sees open learning as inseparable from good learner centred practice. It believes, therefore, that learner centred strategies are intrinsic to good education and training practices within and between sectors.

A range of initiatives and forums are already supporting national collaborative activity in open learning, as indicated below. These activities can be developed to respond to cross sectoral consideration of common features of open learning delivery.

The Government's Open Learning Initiative is a catalyst for the implementation of open learning approaches in the higher education sector, with increasing influence on the TAFE sector as this area of its service provision expands. The approach taken by the Government in requiring the Open Learning Agency of Australia (OLAA) to function as a consortium of universities has encouraged wider use of open learning approaches across the university sector in the development of stand alone course materials and the development of innovative modes of delivery, including broadcast television and radio, audio tapes and computer aided learning.

In the VET sector, the National Flexible Delivery Project Final Report of March 1995 has recommended the establishment of a National Flexible Delivery Committee responsible to the ANTA Board to address current identified impediments to the development of flexible delivery nationally. The development of open learning in the VET sector will be guided by this Committee.
In the schools sector, open access approaches based largely on the use of information technologies will increasingly offer students greater curriculum choice and better quality learning.

The proposed establishment of EdNA will enable delivery of educational services and products across education and training sectors and across the nation, and contain the costs of accessing interactive information networks for education users. It could also act as a focal point for the accessing of information services and databases identifying good pedagogy and efficiencies in the delivery of education and training through open learning. More details are provided in response to Recommendation 2 below.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 2: The Committee recommends that MCEETYA develop a joint Commonwealth-State funding proposal to establish by the year 2000, on a national basis and to a standard commensurate with broadband services and the convergence of technologies, a base level of telecommunications and computing infrastructure in all schools. This must be supported by adequate training for teachers and educational support staff. It is suggested that OLTC be asked to develop the draft proposal.

speech.para: Agreement between MCEETYA Ministers to develop EdNA has to some extent met the intention of this recommendation.

Developments in information technology offer unprecedented opportunities to improve the delivery of educational services in Australia. Australian Governments are in the process of making significant investment in the establishment of the necessary infrastructure to take advantage of these opportunities. However, it needs to be acknowledged that currently communications links are limited largely to standard low speed telephone lines which allow transmission of text and static graphics. It is important, therefore, to have mechanisms to ensure co-ordination as the technology develops towards a fully broadband and interactive environment.

To this end, the Commonwealth Government and the States and Territories have agreed on a major initiative, the establishment of a comprehensive education network service, EdNA, which will deliver educational services and products across the nation and contain the costs of accessing interactive information networks. The EdNA initiative forms part of the overall national strategy announced by the Prime Minister on 6 April 1995 to ensure that Australia is well placed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the development of the so called `information super highway'.

At the meeting of MCEETYA held on 26 May 1995, Ministers agreed to a broad framework for the establishment of a national education network. In particular, Ministers agreed that such a network must offer Australia-wide coverage, avoiding discrimination on the basis of geographical location, and must be subject to an appropriate governance structure. Ministers also agreed to explore the advantages which could flow from a joint approach to the purchase of reception equipment (personal computers and associated infrastructure) necessary for educational institutions to take full advantage of information networking.

Specific mechanisms have been approved to carry forward work on the key issues of negotiating the delivery of network services, setting up a Governing Body for EdNA and exploring the potential for joint purchasing of reception infrastructure. In the area of network services, it was agreed that the Commonwealth should be authorised to negotiate with telecommunications providers and with computer network providers to establish a national delivery system for education services.

In order to undertake negotiations with potential suppliers, the Commonwealth needs to understand the needs and priorities of the users of a national education system. It has been agreed that, over the next three months, the Commonwealth should consult with all potential users of a national education network to determine as accurately as possible what products and services they need from an education network, including what kinds of functions they would want to see in a network service (for example, whether or not services such as control of individual access to particular subject matter groupings or secure communications between users are important to particular users).

There will also be a need to address issues such as the level of telecommunications access (including bandwidth) required and the kinds of pricing structures considered necessary to make usage of an educational network feasible and attractive. At the same time, the Commonwealth will continue its investigation of the technical environment which will condition any response to the needs of potential users. The objective of the consultation process would be to develop a full definition of the overall `business requirement' of a national education network. This business requirement would form the basis for a public tender process which would invite the communications and computer service industry to indicate how it could deliver the services required by the users of a national education network.

In order to ensure that this business requirement properly reflects the needs of educational systems, a reference group is to be established with representatives from the schools and VET sectors in all States and Territories and from the higher education sector. This reference group will be responsible for certifying that the description of the network business requirement developed by the Commonwealth properly reflects user needs. Ministers will also have an opportunity to examine the business requirement before a tender is developed.
A number of principles have been set out to guide the process of establishing a national network service. Key principles include the following:
The network must offer national coverage.
The network must, over time, provide a vehicle for convergence of current networking initiatives, including Open Net, AARNet and the Internet.
The network should service all sectors, school, vocational education and training (VET), further education and higher education.
The network should be fully accessible
â€”individuals and institutional users should be able to access the network at affordable rates regardless of location.
â€”all mainstream reception infrastructure should be able to access the network.

It is expected that the process of developing the definition of a network business requirement will be completed by September 1995. The process of tendering for network services and evaluating tenders received would take place during the remainder of 1995.
On the issue of governance of EdNA, it has been agreed that a Governing Body should be established with the functions of:
managing the development of educational and technical standards for the delivery of services on EdNA by
â€”setting guidelines on the kinds of material which could be carried on the network (for example, prohibition of pornography and setting general quality standards)
â€”establishing rules on carriage of commercial material;
â€”establishing guidelines for access by product providers;

encouraging the development of product and services, taking into account the above standards (product and services will include Commonwealth sponsored product, product from all education and training providers and systems and private sector product which meets technical and educational standards established);
ensuring that the services provided constitute a comprehensive package which can be moved to an alternative platform, if required, without inconvenience to clients;
defining, in consultation with the education sector, their functional requirements from any on-line service to ensure that their requirements are being met; and
communicating these user needs to the provider or providers of network services.

The Governing Body of EdNA will be based on the OLTC. The Board of the OLTC will be commissioned to develop detailed proposals for changes to the structure and Articles of Association necessary to undertake the role of the Governing Body of EdNA.

The OLTC board will also undertake the task of drafting guidelines on issues such as access to the national education network, publication standards and carriage of commercial material. The OLTC will work with content providers to develop an initial suite of product and services to be offered on the network when it commences operation and will work on the development of an integrated directory structure. Initial services are expected to include a directory of education services and interactive message facilities. The processes of establishing governance arrangements for EdNA and developing content will take place over the next six months.

On the issue of purchase of reception infrastructure, it has been agreed that an additional joint Commonwealth/State and Territory working party should be established to develop specifications for a combined tender for purchase of reception infrastructure. The working party is expected to complete its work by September 1995. It is expected that formal commencement of services of EdNA will occur early in 1996.

The recommendation also emphasises the need for adequate training of teachers to support the use of communications technology in schools. The Commonwealth does not determine the content of teacher training curricula. However, it anticipates that the EdNA will be used to support training for teachers and educational support staff and that current pre-service and in-service teacher training will take account of teacher needs associated with use of educational technology and multi media products. Currently DEET is funding the OLTC to develop a kit to support teacher training by demonstrating information and communications technology products and to provide case studies and examples of good practice and information on product applications and issues concerning compatibility of communications platforms.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 3: The Committee recommends that the Government adopt the national strategy for broadband services proposed in the report, Networking Australia's Future, and endorses the recommendations of the Expert Group contained therein.

speech.para:
The Government supports the broad policy direction of the Broadband Services Expert Group final report
Networking Australia's Future
. The importance of community access to the benefits of communications technology to support open learning is evidenced by the Government's commitment to initiatives such as Open Net, the Community Information Network and the proposed EdNA.

The Government will consider the specific recommendations contained in
Networking Australia's Future
during 1995 in the context of submissions from individual portfolios on information and communications services and technologies.

In setting out its national strategy for creating a communications environment that will achieve desirable public objectives, the Broadband Services Experts' Group placed a strong emphasis on education. The development of Open Net as part of the Government's Open Learning Initiative has an important role in this strategy. It provides a communications service to link students and tutors and enables students to access educational resources and world wide information through the Internet. However, in addition to extending connectivity it will play an increasing role in the development of new features and services, enhancing interactivity, multimedia applications and the development of course content for electronic use. The Open Net service will ultimately converge with EdNA.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 4: The Committee recommends that the Tanami Network be developed and extended, in consultation with its community, to increase the number of sites linked into the network at a rate of at least four sites per annum.

speech.para: The Committee recommends also that DEET continue funding of an on-site tutor for the tutorial support scheme at Yuendumu in the Northern Territory.

The Government supports the second part of this Recommendation relating to the continued funding of on-site tutors at Yuendumu in the Northern Territory. DEET will continue to provide three tutors in support of the Yuendumu project and intends to use that support model as the basis for tutorial assistance in other remote communities. However, for reasons given below, the Government does not support the first part of this Recommendation which relates to the extension of the Tanami Network as it stands.
Development and extension of the Tanami Network

The Government is looking at a wider range of available and effective educational technologies to enable a composite and more effective delivery structure rather than concentrating solely on the Tanami Network and the use of video conferencing in the manner recommended by the Committee. From the educational perspective, there is clearly much to be gained by matching delivery technology to educational requirements rather than trying to adapt only one technology to all circumstances. In this regard, contributions can be made by the Open Net service or through EdNA. The needs of remote communities and the capacity for education and training delivery through new technologies will be considered as part of the development of EdNA.
Education

The Government recognises that technology-based education and, in particular, interactive multi-media, constitutes a substantial tool in an integrated approach to development and delivery of teaching material and courseware to remote Aboriginal students and is well placed to add considerable value to the educative process in the near-to mid-term. However, technology is simply a vehicle through which appropriate and well-designed course materials are delivered to improve the learning environment.

As the Senate report identifies (pp 43-46), multi-media teaching methods provide positive educational outcomes only when a strong collaborative relationship exists between education technologists and planners, teachers, students and subject content specialists. By way of example, the effectiveness of technology-based teaching in the open learning trial at Yuendumu is, as the report identifies, limited by the absence of some of the collaborative support mechanisms mentioned above despite a substantial DEET commitment to Aboriginal education in the form of strategic and direct (tutorial) assistance funding.

The Tanami Network is an example of the usefulness of video-conferencing as one aspect of technology-based teaching applicable to delivery to remote areas. However, it is only one of many technological pathways to successful educational outcomes in remote classrooms. The various elements of the so-called "electronic classroom" and computer-based learning programs must be combined in an integrated way to allow effective education in remote schools. Importantly, integration also allows selection of the most cost-effective combination of available education systems which in turn can be better matched with, and able to support, a wider range of teaching materials.

In 1994, as part of their ongoing appraisal of initiatives put in place in support of access and participation goals (Goals 7 to 12 inclusive) of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy, the Northern Territory Department of Education evaluated the mixed-mode delivery of Years 8, 9 and 10 Mathematics and English in a number of remote schools using three different methods of communications technology delivery. These methods included two-way interactive video-conferencing using the Tanami Network, electronic classroom/bulletin board service/electronic mail (an interactive pc/modem-based audio-graphics system) and computer assisted learning packages.

The appraisal found in all three cases that technologies were easy to operate and that learning occurred at a faster rate than using traditional correspondence methods. However, there was universal agreement on the part of participating teachers that even the most effective delivery technology will not assist in obtaining positive educational outcomes where deficiencies exist in the teaching materials available.
Employment

The Tanami Network has been successful in delivering training for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders at the CES network level, specifically to remote clients. However, this limited use does not by itself justify further expansion of the Network.
Costs and Benefits

Cost effectiveness issues were also dealt with in the Northern Territory evaluation which found a significant on-cost differential between Tanami and electronic classroom operations. Given that similar increases in learning rates appear to be experienced by students in both systems in identical subjects, the matter of unit costs must be objectively assessed in order to maximise delivery of an effective service to as many remote students as possible.

In order to inform prospective users of the costs and benefits of the use of the Tanami Network, the Department of Employment, Education and Training commissioned two consultancies; the first one investigating the potential of interactive video-conferencing to improve the delivery of Government services to remote communities; and the second to investigate the potential for establishing a national remote area video conferencing network. The report of the first consultancy has been made available to Government Departments.

Key elements of the findings of the second consultancy were incorporated by the Tanami Network in its submission to Social Justice Commissioners and their proposal for a national network forms part of Recommendation 97 contained in
Recognition, Rights & Reform
, the ATSIC Report to Government of Native Title Social Justice Measures, presented in March this year. The Government is currently considering a response to this report.

At the request of MCEETYA, the OLTC is also currently undertaking an investigation and analysis of the education and training needs of both existing and proposed broadband services. As part of this project, the OLTC is developing a collaborative framework for the implementation of broadband services for the education and training sectors. The potential of the Tanami Network to deliver cost effective Government services will be considered in the wider context of this investigation.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 5: The Committee recommends that all ANTA agreements with the States and Territories require an explicit commitment to the development of flexible delivery systems in the TAFE and private training sector and that performance indicators for the training effort of States and Territories reflect that commitment.

speech.para:
The Government supports this recommendation. One of the themes of ANTA's
National
Strategy
document is greater responsiveness to client needs. It addresses the need for flexible training initiatives, with particular reference to supervisors, small business employees, people with literacy and numeracy needs, people who are geographically isolated and people requiring preparatory and pre-vocational courses in various settings. The report also sees flexible delivery as having the potential to address the needs of women and of people with a disability.

In addition, as mentioned in the response to Recommendation 1 above, The National Flexible Delivery Project Final Report of March 1995 has recommended the establishment of a National Flexible Delivery Committee responsible to the ANTA Board to address impediments to the development of flexible delivery nationally in the VET sector. The development of open learning in the VET sector will be guided by this Committee. In addition, the Government will be looking to ANTA to reflect a commitment to flexible delivery in the guidelines for the development of State Training Profiles and for States to report on the achievement of nationally agreed strategies.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 6: The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth undertake a review of the funding of student financial support with a view to equitably accommodating the wide range of study patterns now available to students.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation for reasons given below.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training monitors education delivery initiatives and examines the possible impact of such initiatives on students' access to assistance. The aim is to provide assistance to all eligible students on an equitable basis, regardless of how the education is delivered to them.

The report argues that traditional notions of determining students' eligibility for student assistance no longer apply with the expansion of the number of students accessing the open learning approach to study.

While recognising the flexibility available to students through `open learning', it is crucial to keep in mind that the primary purpose of the student assistance schemes is to provide income support to full-time students. Those who are essentially part-time students have greater opportunities to support their own education costs through employment, rather than having to depend on public support.

Practices are in place that recognise the flexible study patterns available to students who study under open learning-type arrangements. However, the need for students to study full-time remains. While students have the flexibility under open learning arrangements to structure their own study patterns, it is expected that institutions will continue to monitor the students' enrolment and academic progress. Given this, it has been accepted that institutions themselves are best placed to determine the workload that students undertake over a period.

In keeping with the primary aim of student assistance, the Government expects that students seeking income support will be formally enrolled full-time by their institution, and undertake a workload that is accepted by the institution as full-time (whether a term, semester or other period), taking account of the highs and lows of attendance patterns.

The Committee raised the issue of home-based secondary study, particularly for remote area students. Assistance is not denied home-based students simply because they study from home. On the contrary, it has been long standing policy to provide assistance to students studying by correspondence. For example, AUSTUDY allowances are available to correspondence students on the same basis as for students who attend a school or other institution.

A respondent put to the Committee a concern that secondary students wishing to study in an open learning mode risk losing their AUSTUDY payments. An example was given where barriers to receiving AUSTUDY were presented to students electing to attend Cyril Jackson Senior High School for reduced hours in a week ("less than the prescribed 16 hours").

Since the introduction of AUSTUDY, the determination of whether or not a secondary school student was studying full-time has been left to the school to decide. Where a school considers a student to be studying full-time, this is accepted by AUSTUDY. There is no additional legislative or administrative requirement for students to attend school for a minimum number of hours each week. This means that students attending a secondary school for reduced hours because the school allows for an open learning approach to study can continue to receive assistance as long as the school continues to view the student as full-time.

While the focus of this recommendation is on student financial support and student assistance programs, the report also discusses the need to address the funding implications of a change from traditional face to face teaching costs to the high up front costs of developing learning materials for open learning.

In the higher education sector, a recent study commissioned by the Higher Education Council examined issues, including the higher costs of developing materials for distance and open learning compared to on-campus course development. The study proposed that the distinction between traditional on-campus provision and distance or open learning provision was no longer useful. It suggested that all modes of education and training delivery now used resource based learning with consequent changes to the cost structures of course development not only for open learning but for all study patterns.

In addition to this fundamental change in teaching and learning towards resource based learning, there are cost-efficiencies to be gained from open learning approaches. For example, in the higher education sector, a number of universities have expressed interest in using open learning subjects and courses developed through the OLAA for on-campus students. The university would provide access to additional student resources, such as tutorial support and library. This proposed use of already developed materials would add cost efficiencies for both the OLAA and for the university. DEET has indicated in-principle agreement to this proposal.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 7: The Committee recommends that OLTC, in consultation with ACTRAC and other relevant agencies, provide advice to MCEETYA on the funding, co-ordination and marketing of courseware developed for use within the Australian vocational education and training sector.

speech.para: The Government does not support this recommendation. There are already a number of commercial operations marketing courseware in the VET sector, not only at State and Territory levels but at the national level through the establishment of ACTRAC Products Pty Ltd, a company limited by guarantee operating under the auspices of ANTA. At the 25 May 1995 Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) Ministerial Council (MINCO) meeting, it was agreed that a Memorandum of Understanding be entered into to link ACTRAC Products Pty Ltd operations with the policies of ANTA and the Ministerial Council and to confer on the company the broader function of marketing the new ANTA Standards and Curriculum Council. The MINCO agreed that the new Council will come into operation from 1 July 1995.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 8: The Committee recommends that OLTC develop guidelines for producers and designers of courseware and associated learning materials to ensure that their products, whatever the medium, can be reproduced on request in a range of formats appropriate to the needs of students with disabilities.

speech.para:
The Government supports this recommendation. The Commonwealth commissioned the OLTC to organise a national conference
Enabling Vision `95; Creating Equity in Education through Open Learning
in February 1995 to consider, among other things, the potential for open learning to improve education and training delivery to the disability sector.

The OLTC will be reporting to ministers for education and training on outcomes of the conference for open learning strategies to support the disability community. It is anticipated that an important element of the proposed strategy will be the development of guidelines for courseware design which take account of the needs of learners with a disability.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 9: The Committee recommends that the National Open Learning Policy Unit of DEET in consultation with the relevant unions and employer associations prepare a Discussion Paper for presentation to MCEETYA on the impact of open learning approaches on the terms and conditions of teachers.

speech.para: The Government supports this recommendation but recognises that the negotiation of terms and conditions of teachers is not the responsibility of the Commonwealth. However, the Government supports the intention that MCEETYA be informed of the opportunities for teachers in the use of open learning approaches and technologies.

Projects have been initiated to consider these issues. These include Commonwealth commissioned research and that undertaken by NBEET. The Commonwealth will establish a reference group to develop a draft paper on incorporating research findings, for consideration and comment by State and Territory systems, before presentation of a final report to MCEETYA for consideration and action.
Although this paper will focus on teachers in school systems, it will also refer to learner centred approaches in tertiary systems.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 10: The Committee recommends that MCEETYA develop community access guidelines and an associated code of practice for adoption by State and Territory education and training authorities which provide for:

para.tab:
(a)
the use, after hours, of school and TAFE facilities by bona fide not-for-profit adult and community education organisations; and

(b)
reasonable access by such groups to associated facilities such as libraries, computer rooms, etc.

speech.para: The Government supports this recommendation, noting the potential for the use by adult and community education organisations of existing public resources, including technology and venues, in accordance with the National Policy on Adult and Community Education (ACE). Such use would most likely be on a user pays basis, because schools budgets are unlikely to be able to subsidise additional use of school buildings.

The Government also recognises that primary responsibility for the School, Vocational Education and ACE sectors rests with State and Territory governments. However, the Government will propose to MCEETYA that it reconsider the need for the development of community access guidelines (and associated code of practice) for State and Territory schools and VET institutions as part of its National Policy on ACE, in light of the potential for wider community access offered by EdNA.

para.emphasis: Recommendation No 11: The Committee recommends that ANTA, in consultation with the State training authorities, develop guidelines for the registration of private training providers requiring them, as part of their compliance with regulations concerning the standards of facilities, to provide their students with access to infrastructure resources commensurate with the level of training undertaken.

speech.para: Application form templates for the Registration of Training Providers have been developed by State and Territory recognition authorities and agreed by MINCO. These incorporate details of facilities of private training providers. However, consideration of additional requirements/guidelines covering the standards of facilities provided by private training providers could be addressed by the new ANTA Standards and Curriculum Council referred to in the response to Recommendation 7 above.

With the move to learner centred and resource based learning, it is increasingly important that providers are able to demonstrate access to relevant communications infrastructure and student support systems.

This is particularly apparent in the consideration of tenders for the delivery of formal training based labour market programs (LMPs) which are delivered by public, private and community organisations, all of which have different infrastructures and varying capacities to offer flexible delivery methods including open learning. Consideration of access to infrastructure resources can be indicative of capacity to ensure good support to, and outcomes for, program participants.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senateâ€”
(a)notes:

tab.tab: (i)the enormous contribution that the cattle industry has made to Australia, and
(ii)that many parts of the industry are now suffering what has been described as the worst crisis in the industry in 10 years; and

para.tab: (b)condemns the Government for its failure, after 13 years in office, to address the underlying problems facing the cattle industry.

speech.para: It is important and relevant during this week, when the Cattle Council of Australia has issued a major industry statement, for us to look at the beef cattle industry and the enormous contribution that industry has made to Australia and its economy ever since Australia was first settled by Europeans. As my motion says, the Senate should take note of that contribution.

para.tab: We should also acknowledge that at present this industry, after such a major contribution to Australia, is in its worst crisis in 10 years. It is also relevant in this debate to look at the inaction of the current government in addressing some of the problems which confront the beef cattle industry and perhaps the reasons why, after 13 years in office, these problems have not been addressed.

A great number of speakers want to participate in this debate. There are nine listed on the speakers list. I hope all speakers would be able to restrict themselves to around 10 minutes to give everybody the opportunity of speaking on this very important matter. I would hope that the Labor Party does not do what it has done in the last three or four general business sessions; that is, get Senator Sherry up to filibuster for a full half-hour of absolute rubbishâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”No agreement.
â€”You are going to filibuster again, are you, Senator Sherry?
â€”No, I will be adhering to the agreement.
â€”What is the agreement?
â€”It is eight minutes, as I understand.

â€”Well, I take that back. If you are going to keep your contribution to eight minutes, that is tremendous because I do think this is the sort of issue which requires debate by as many people as possible. As I say, I have been disturbed that in the last three or four general business sessions the Labor Party has filibustered for a full half-hour simply to prevent people on our side addressing the very important questions that have been raised in general business sessions.

para.tab: The beef cattle industry is a very significant industry, particularly in my part of Australia, in Queensland. The industry remains the engine room for much of the growth in rural Australia with a total value of farm output of $4.4 billion in 1993-94, which makes it easily the largest single rural contributor. It accounts for 19 per cent of the value of rural output in Australia. The total value to the economy of the beef industry, including the off-farm sectors, is estimated to be $7.7 billion. It provides employment for an estimated 120,000 workers directly, and 600,000 workers indirectly; that is, counting those off-farm. So it is a major employer of labour within our country.

The beef industry generates sales and employment for the myriad import suppliersâ€”from banking services to fertilisers, fences, machinery, chemical companies and the likeâ€”located in every Australian rural town. The industry is a major and growing contributor to Australia's export earnings with a $3.3 billion return from 1993-94, or 17 per cent of the total agricultural export value. This makes the beef industry Australia's second largest rural export earner, only slightly behind wool.

The cattle industry is central to the viability of many rural towns, particularly in remote areas of Australia. Its decentralised nature provides national and social benefits even beyond its sheer size due to the impact on the utilisation of state and national infrastructure.

It is a major contributor to Australiaâ€”to the economy of Australia and to Australia's wealth over very many years. I hope the Senate will adopt my motion in noting that enormous contribution the industry has made. The industry, of course, consists of all of those people: graziers, pastoralists, the workers in the processing factories, the transport people, the exporters. All of those many people contribute to what is and has been for many years one of Australia's great industries.

We are now in a situation where the industry is in crisis. It is hit by drought. Of course, there is not much anyone can do about that except try to facilitate policies which will encourage graziers to droughtproof their properties in the good timesâ€”for example, taxation regimes which will allow graziers and pastoralists to put aside a little bit of money in the good years so they can carry on through the bad years.

There are other reasons the cattle industry is in crisis. Some of those are matters which can be addressed by the Australian government. We have had a series of questions this week on the crisis in the beef cattle industry and the government's possible solutions for that crisis and we have heard nothing from Senator Collins. The minister for primary industry has filibustered his way through his four minutes to answer questions.

Senator Collins keeps telling us that we have not read the Booz-Allen report, and no doubt we will get another serve on that. He keeps telling us that the meat processing costs in Australia include a transport component. That is what he was trying to tell us on Monday. That is how much he knows about it.

I suspectâ€”and it seems pretty obviousâ€”that the minister for primary industries himself has not read the Booz-Allen report, as I and many of my colleagues haveâ€”colleagues on this side who will be speaking in the debate and who are very interested in these industry reports.

Today I want to concentrate on those elements of the difficulties in which the beef cattle industry at the moment finds itself which can be addressed by government. As I say, I acknowledge that there are certain factors we cannot influence. But those that we can influence we should be influencing. I think the Senate should condemn the government for its lack of action in attacking those things that we are able to address.

The reasons for the difficulties and the poor returns being experienced by the industry lie in policies which have discouraged community saving and which have maintained high real interest rates. The reasons also include the high taxation rate which is applied to export industries, and the failure of other sectors of the Australian economyâ€”such as the processing, transport handling and government servicesâ€”to match the productivity which is evident on farm and in competing Pacific Basin countries.

Our industry depends critically on improving trade access and matching or exceeding productivity improvements overseas, particularly those productivity improvements which we have seen recently in New Zealand and in the United States. Whilst the productivity of those countries has increased, our productivity in Australia has gone backwards. While it can be clearly demonstrated that Australian producers have maintained the edge `on-farm', the rate of reform and efficiency progress in the processing, transport and handling, and service industries is very low when compared with world's best practice or to the continued improvements being made in those major competitor countries, particularly New Zealand.

Australia's meat processing sector is internationally uncompetitive. Part of the cost component in that sector is made up of the highly restricted and archaic industrial practices and the high labour costs, in addition to the high costs of government inspection services and taxes.

Labour productivity, expressed as cattle processed per employee per day, was 1.4 in Australia compared with 2.9 in the USA and 3.4 in New Zealand's best. The award coverage and the tally system of payment has led to gross under-utilisation of physical capital resources within Australia. The Fellows Medlock and Associates review of progress in workplace reform in the export meat processing sector indicates that workplace reform in the meat processing sector over recent years has beenâ€”and I quote their wordâ€”`limited'. They are some of the issues that Australia must address to make the industry more competitive.

Road transport in Australia is relatively efficient. The beef cattle industry relies very heavily on road transport within Australia. However, although the transport industry itself is efficient, it is heavily burdened by taxes imposed by this governmentâ€”taxes which have increased dramatically over the Labor Party's term in charge of the treasury bench.

Also, efficiency on the waterfront and in shipping remains well short of international best practice. It is a regret that the current minister for primary industries is the same minister who was given the job of fixing up the waterfront. He promised that he would resign if he could not get productivity up, if he did not fix the problems in the waterfront industry. But we now find that the Bureau of Industry Economics has reported that stevedoring productivity has reverted to 1991 levelsâ€”levels which were in force prior to the costly Waterfront Industry Reform Authority process.

This leaves Australia's best performing container terminals equal to the worst in Europe. So the best in Australia is equal to the worst in Europe. Australian crane rates are 25 to 50 per cent behind the world's best practice. The Bureau of Industry Economics concluded that, in regard to container productivity, most overseas ports have moved ahead whilst in Australia we have gone backwards. Unfortunately, waterfront reform was the job the current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was given a couple of years back. He failed at that. It is now pretty obvious why he is failing at addressing the real problems affecting the beef cattle industry.

The taxation regime in Australia at the present time has beef production burdened by the existing emphasis on indirect taxation. Sales tax, excises, bank transaction taxes, payroll taxes, stamp duties, licensing charges and land rates all fall most heavily on business inputs and directly affect the wealth and health of the beef cattle industry. Indirect taxation costs the farming community $1 billion per annum. Beef producers, being reliant on export markets, are unable to pass these taxes on in their price to final consumers.

The excise on fuel used in road transportation of fodder, grain and other inputs and in the movement of livestock also has a major impact on the cattle industry. Much of the industry is in the northern areas of Australia, in fairly remote and far distant areas, and that fuel excise has a substantial impact on the industry's profitability and international competitiveness. Federal tax imposts through sales tax, tariffs and payroll tax also provide a major cost burden to the beef producers, both directly and indirectly, in the price of farm inputs.

So those are the things which should be addressed by the government. But this government, after 13 years in office, has failed miserably. That is why the cost of processing meat in Australia is 113c per kilo, in New Zealand it is 72c and in the United States it is about 40c per kilo. There can be only limited explanations as to why this government has not had the courage to confront those issues.

The policies adopted by government with regard to industrial relations, taxation and the provision of government services need to be looked at very closely. The policies of this government are acting to stifle the performance of the Australian beef industry. Industrial laws must be altered to allow employees to freely enter into agreements with their employers, without the intervention from outside bodies such as national and state based unions. Because Senator Sherry and most of the other Labor Party members here are straight out of the union movement, there will probably be a long period spent in this debate in defence of the role unions have played. But it is fairly obvious that in this industry in particular the unions have been a real impediment to its efficiency and productivity.

The Cattle Council has urged that all taxes on business inputsâ€”particularly those on fuel, payroll, sales tax and tariffsâ€”be addressed as a matter of urgency. The government must also look at meat inspection charges and it must seriously consider the funding for research and development in this particular industry.

In this week, in which the Cattle Council of Australia has released a major statement on the industry, it is important the Senate pauses to recognise the enormous contribution the industry has made to Australia over the years, to recognise that the industry is in real crisis at this particular time and to condemn the government for its lack of action after 13 years on anything which might assist the beef cattle industry to overcome its current competitive disadvantage.
