speech.speaker: Carr Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise in this debate to address some of the matters put forward by Senator Ian Macdonald and some of the questions that have been raised in the chamber this week. In terms of this industry, there is one fundamental question that I believe needs to be answered by the coalitionâ€”the Nationals and the Liberals. Senator Macdonald and Senator Boswell have raised issues in this regard this week. I ask this simple question: why is it that the coalition hates meatworkers so much? That is an answer that meatworkers in this country are entitled to get. The 50,000 meatworkers in this country are very interested in the answer to that question.
â€”Many of them are card-carrying National Party members.

â€”Senator Boswell says that many of them are National Party members, but the National Party does not serve their interests. You come in here and your main issue is to cut the wages and conditions of working people in this country. That is the essence of your policies which attempt to deal with the so-called rural crisis in this country. We get no indication that you understand the nature of the work in this industry; we get no indication of its heavy physical nature; we get no indication of the dangers involved in this industry; we get no indication that the meat industry is the second most dangerous in the whole economy.

para.tab: According to international standards, we are the second most dangerous country in terms of meatworker injury rates per 100 employees. In the Booz-Allen and Hamilton report there is a reference to that fact. It reports that Australia comes second to New Zealandâ€”the great workers' panacea that you constantly cite. The survey contained in the report indicates that in New Zealand there are some 210 injuries per 100 workers compared with some 130 injuries per 100 workers in Australia. They are both absolutely appalling statistics.

The community at large has to understand that there is a constant risk of injury. The payments in the industry are so unreliable. Work is performed at such a high speed and suits producers. It is seasonal in its nature and essentially it is founded upon gross insecurity. Obviously, within the industry itself there are very large numbers of awards and agreements which lead to different rates of pay and conditions for workers that are performing the same task. What do we hear from those opposite? All we hear is that the crisis that has occurred in the meat industry is because workers earn too much.

In Queensland a number of abattoirs have closed down. That is testament to the sorts of industrial policies that we are likely to see under a coalition government in many respects. The very large American producer that owns those meat works is essentially seeking to secure wage cuts and productivity increases. That is at the core of that industrial dispute in Queensland. Conagra, an American firm, is essentially trying to apply American conditions, American styles of work and American work practices to Australia. That is a situation which will inevitably lead to crisis within the industry. What we see is a proposition whereby there is a direct attack on workers' wages and there is an attempt to remove penalty rates, to produce a 10-hour day, to have continual working operations within any particular plant, to move to bigger production runs and to produce a set of circumstances whereby the company seeks to crush the union and crush workers within this industry.

From a union point of view, there is quite ample evidence to suggest a willingness to talk and to seek an enterprise agreement approach. Do we see a response from the employers in Queensland? That is at the core of the industrial dispute in Queensland. I understand that a number of meatworks have closed down because of a claimed shortage of stock. There may also be an element of a lock-out involved in that process.

It has to be understood that if we are looking at the question of the costs of production in this country, the Booz-Allen report has quite clearly indicated that workers' wages are only a very small component of production. I understand that it might be as little as only 10 or 12 per cent of production costs. The major cost of production in this country is the cost of the product itself: the cost of stock. This report says that there are a whole range of factors involved. As Senator Collins has clearly pointed out to the Senate, up to 60 to 70 per cent of the costs of production are related to matters that are directly outside the control of the industry itself in this country. Page 2 of the report states:

speech.para: We estimate that were the Australian "Best-in-Class" to be lifted intact (with existing equipment, management and workforce) and dropped in an Iowa cornfield, 60% to 70% of the performance gap would disappear.

If we look at the issues relating to the costs of production, we see that there are a whole range of factors which we never hear anything about from the coalition. We do not hear anything about the fact that Australia produces smaller, leaner animals. We do not hear anything about the less reliable animal supply. We do not hear anything about the distance from markets. We do not hear anything about the whole range of other factors involved in terms of overheads and in terms of the packaging and fabrication that is involved in this industry. When we talk about inefficiencies in this industry, we have to make sure that we get a balanced approach, something that we do not see from the coalition. The reason is very simple: essentially, your hatred for workers comes shining through on every occasion.

para.tab: If we look at the issue of unit costs, we have to take into account a whole range of other factors. This report talks about matters such as the exchange rate. Since the preparation of this report, it says that exchange rates for the 1991-92 season have made a tremendous difference in cost position. The drop in the Australian dollar since the original study could have eliminated 10c per kilogram of the processing performance gap.

If we look at the situation in other parts of the countryâ€”which again we never hear anything about; all we hear anything about is how dreadful meatworkers areâ€”in Victoria, as I understand the situation, there are 26 enterprise agreements registered with the commission and there are 12 more ready to go. They cover the vast majority of meatworkers in Victoria; some 75 per cent of meatworkers are now covered by industry agreements. The smallgoods producers are now involved and enterprise agreements are moving right across the industry, including the major export works.

We are seeing a remarkable transformation of that industry without cuts in workers' wages. This is the core of the difference between Labor and Liberal on this issue. Our intention is to maintain living standards. Our intention is to ensure that workers have a proper place in this country and that they are treated as full citizens so that the whole gamut of social wage conditions are protected, as well as their take-home pay. If we look at Victoria, we see that many employers are quite prepared to acknowledge that there have been substantial changes. For instance, the Fellows Medlock report says:

speech.para: one company cites an 86 per cent improvement in output per employee over the period since their agreement was signed and gives the credit for this change almost solely to the impact of the agreement.
Another chief executive cites:

Our agreement provided the base to change our culture. This itself has led to a quantifiable 16-17% increase in productivity. The union has been no barrier to change and our next agreement will continue this processâ€”we want to look at expanding plant utilisation through flexibility in hours.

This will be achieved without cuts in wages. There has been a 25 per cent increase in wages in Victoria and a substantial improvement in productivity. That contrasts dramatically with your attitude, which essentially is geared to the proposition that you hate working people. You cannot possibly cope with the proposition that working people should get a fair say in the running of enterprises and a fair return for the production in enterprises. Your approach is flexibility, but flexibility downwards. Your intention is to undermine the conditions of working people in this country. In that way, of course, you quite sharply distinguish yourselves from us.

para.tab: It is just not good enough for you to come in here and say that the so-called crisis in the meat industry can be put down to the working people in this country. There are a whole range of factors that lead to the production of the meat. In that regard you have been exposed, your industrial relations policies have been exposed and the hypocrisy that you have shown on this matter should be evident to all workers in the meat industry.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Carr asked the rhetorical question: why do we on this side of the House hate workers? The very clear answer to that is, of course, that we do not hate workers.
â€”You love them!
â€”We do. We understand their contribution to all these industries.
â€”What is it?

â€”Their contribution is a very significant one. We certainly do not want to come into this place and say that their wages should be cut. What we are saying, though, is that there must be more flexibility in the industry.
â€”How?
â€”You know very well how, because you were there when Mr Wyld gave the Labor Party the greatest bucket they have ever had. Mr Wyld, the President of the Cattle Council, said:

speech.para: Australian meat processing remains uncompetitive and the government has a vital role to play in creating a climate for change and reform. Despite industry calls, the recommendations have not been carried out by the government.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) has had 13 years in government. He said on one occasion that he would resign if reforms to the waterfront were not carried out. He did get some minor reforms at the timeâ€”at a huge cost, I believe, of $400 millionâ€”which are only to be seen now to be slipping away.

para.tab: Senator Carr, I want to answer your points. You should go out and tell the Japanese that they have to buy our beef, because you want the workers to have a tally system, you want the workers to work for five or six hours a day and leave those huge monoliths of factories lying idle for 16 hours a day. You know very well, Senator Carr, that you wanted the economic reform. You wanted the farmers to lose every benefit they had. You took their tariffs. Fair enough; no-one on this side complained. You removed any benefits that rural Australia may have had. The farmers have suffered the pain. They pay high wharfage and other costs. But you cannot hide behind it now because it was your government that did it. It was the Left which sat back and let them do it. You sat down and let these guys run right over the top of you. Then you come in here and cry crocodile tears.

If there is one group of people who are at fault it is the left wing of the Labor Party. They have let everything be deregulated and every benefit fly away. We will have the ultimate laissez-faire economy. There have been Hilmer reports and everything else. And what did you guys do? You sat there and let them do it to you. Then you come in here and complain. It is the Left's fault. What has the Left ever done in the last two years other than provide a doormat for the Right to walk over? Then you cry foul because we are uncompetitive overseas.

Someone ought to tell you the days of featherbedding are over. I have been told often enough. Someone ought to tell you guys in the Left that you can't live in a global village; you can't trade the way we did 20 years ago. You cannot do it, because the Japanese, who are our major customers for beef, are not going to say, `Yes, we have to maintain the conditions that the meatworkers have had for the last 20 years. Of course we'll give them a bit of a premium. We've got to look after the Left.' Those days are over. You know it; we know it; the Right knows it; the Democrats know it, although they won't believe it; and the Greens know it. The only ones that don't know it are the Left.

The beef industry is a major export earner for Australiaâ€”$3 billion. There are many people out there at the moment in desperate situations. It is going to be tough for the next two or three years for the beef industry. Let us be fair about this matter; it is not only the exchange rate.

There is another matter that has escaped you, Senator Carr, and that may have escaped Senator Collins. The American beef industry is paying $80 to $120 for their feedlot grain. I think a lot of that grain would be subsidisedâ€”I am not sureâ€”by way of various benefits in America. We take that into consideration, and we understand that. It is not something that Australia, the meatworkers or the farmers and graziers can do much about. We have to live with that situation. I will tell you this now: we cannot live with any further antiquated ideas.

Before I go on, I want to declare my interest in this industry. I have a significant holding in the Kilcoy abattoir. I meant to do that at the start. I want to tell the Labor Party, particularly Senator Carr, that by holding on to the past you are not helping your union members. What you have done to them is put 2,000 people out of work. As I have said before, we have to be competitive. We live in a competitive market.

talk.start.para: â€”Do you want to sack them, Ron?

â€”Will you be quiet. You are like the little boy on the bickie tin; you are right on the outside of everything. No-one takes you particularly seriously. You hang on to Bob Collins's coat and hope one day he falls under a bus and you will be the minister for primary industry. It won't happen. It is not going to happen.
â€”John Anderson will be the next primary industries minister.
â€”John Anderson will be the next one, will he?

â€”I want to say to Senator Carr: he is doing his membership no favours at all. We cannot live in the past. In the past you turned up for work at 6 o'clock, you hit your tally, you went very quickly, the chain was put on and everyone worked. At 11 o'clock the workers were out of the abattoirs and away. No-one on this side wants to see wages demolished. We would like to see that everyone in the whole beef industry gets a more equitable and a fairer share. We are not going to be able to achieve that by remaining with this antiquated and out-of-date tally system where millions and millions of dollars worth of equipment and buildings are left idle for 16 hours a day.
(Time expired)

para.tab: Senator Panizza has said by way of interjection that, should a coalition government win the next election, John Anderson will be the next minister for primary industries. I tell you what: if you win government, he will have to perform a bit better than he is currently doing.

How can you take this motion seriously when the shadow minister himself has paid scant regard to the issue. I have to say it is news to me that he has made any statement about it, but I will accept Senator Boswell's word that it was made yesterday. Isn't it terrific that after a fortnight of parliament sitting, somewhere or other he made a statement about this major crisis yesterdayâ€”John Anderson! We have a so-called crisis in the beef industry and not a word has been said about it in parliament by the relevant frontbench member of the opposition. I will give credit to Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Boswell for at least raising the issue here in the Senate.

The current serious problem in respect of beef abattoirs in Queensland is something that we do regard very seriously indeed. As I have told the parliament, there is a great deal of room to improve in terms of the work practices that are being conducted in some meatworks around Australia, but a great deal of work is being done to improve it. Opposition senators, who are fond of quoting the Booz-Allen report into why there is lack of competition in the Australian beef industry, should at least be honest enough to give all of the reasons that Booz-Allen determined were the reasons for that problem.

In respect of the Booz-Allen comments on problems in processing and better work practices, there is no question that they saw that as being a significant component of the 30 per cent of that non-competitive gap that can be addressed by the industry. But they rated as big a problem, in percentage terms, the type of cattle that are being bred in various parts of Australia for that premium market of Japan. The United States is a big consumer of Australian beef, but most of it is hamburger beef, as Senator MacGibbon knows full well.

Just on that pointâ€”and I made that point here in the chamber two days agoâ€”I will read what today's edition of the
Stock and Land
says on this crisis. It talks about the closures and goes on to say:
The strong Australian dollar (against United States' and Japanese currency), and a glut of American beef in Japan, have been blamed by processors for the closures.

speech.para: That is what I told this parliament two days ago. The article continues:

para.tab: AMH general manager for abattoirs and industrial relations, John Hughes, said this week the company could not continue to run abattoirs which he called "uneconomical".

"The essential reasons why the works have been closed is due to the current beef market situation, together with livestock prices and processing costs which are uneconomic when compared to the rest of the world," Mr Hughes said.

speech.para: There is a whole range of issues. The article continues:

para.tab: Marketing manager for one of Victoria's largest export works, Owen Robinson of G & K O'Connor, Pakenham, said before the closures, the Japanese grass-fed market had been swamped by northern cattle.

"Generally, there has been far too much product produced in the north over the past few months. Grass-fed product has been saturated into Japan, and they just can't digest the volumes the north has been pushing."

speech.para:
That is in today's
Stock and Land
that I picked up this morning. What it demonstrates is that there are a range of factors that are currently affecting what I and the government hopes will be the temporary closure of abattoirs in Queensland.

para.tab: Having said that, I am pleased to be able to tell the Senate that the outlook for the beef industry is a positive one. The ABARE September quarter Australian commodities paper identified, as I told the Senate, two key parameters for the beef industry in 1995-96â€”that is, following improved seasonal conditions, higher prices are expected for Australian beef producers, and record levels of beef production in the United States will restrict Australia's prospects for beef exports to that country.

ABARE forecasts that the Australian saleyard indicator price for cattle will rise by over four per cent to 218c a kilogram in 1995-96, an increase of 9c per kilo over 1994-95 and 16c per kilo over 1992-93. The rise will depend on a return to average seasonal conditions in northern Australia that will induce beef producers to rebuild their herds. It is a positive outlook. As Senator Boswell said, quite accurately, we are currently trading $3 billion worth of Australian beef on the world market. It is a positive outlook.

The demand for cattle for restocking is likely to pick up as warmer weather leads to increased pasture production. We are about to get into that phase now, providing we continue to get helpful rain. The dampening demand for Australian beef in the United States is beyond Australia's control and it is due to the cattle and pig production cycles peaking together in the United States. US cattle numbers have increased, as I told the Senate, by six per cent since 1990 to 114.3 million by July this year. It appears that this herd building, however, is now slowing, holding the prospect in the medium term of the US demand for Australian beef returning to normal.

The impact of the US cattle cycle and the prosperity of the Australian beef industry is very well known to Australian beef producersâ€”peak demand and returns and, of course the opposite way, troughs. But a very positive development for northern producers is the increasing demand for live cattle in South-East Asia that is forecast to increase by 20 per cent to around 475,000 in 1995-96. The live cattle trade has been an enormous boost for beef producers in the Northern Territory and Queenslandâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”A saviour.

â€”Absolutely, Senator Panizza. There is no question. I agree with you. It has in fact been a saviour for a lot of those beef producers. The industry has grown enormously over the last two to three years.
â€”It's peasant economy stuff; there is no value adding to it.

â€”I absolutely dispute your interjection that live cattle exports are not value adding. I am profoundly disturbed to hear you say that. You're wrong, Senator MacGibbon. Live cattle exports from Australia are a value added industry. Just have a look at the indirect income that those live cattle exports generate. They do add value to the product, Senator MacGibbon, despite your misconceptions. I suppose, to be fair, you may have a Queensland bias attached to those comments, so I forgive you for them. But you are not right. It is a value added industry.

para.tab: As a result of the droughtâ€”which has had a real impact, as Senator MacGibbon would know full well, being a Queensland producerâ€”and flat demand in the United States, the total beef exports from Australia are forecast to decline by five per cent to around 743,000 tonnes. This will be offset by expected increases in beef exports to Japan and Korea which are expected to grow by two per cent and 17 per cent respectively.

It is pertinent to note that beef exports to Japanâ€”our highest value and volume market, as Senator Boswell correctly saidâ€”have grown consistently each year, from 251 kilotons in 1992-93 to a forecast 327 kilotons in 1995-96. I think those few statistics indicate that there is a very high prospect that these current problems, which are regrettable and which are being experienced by Queensland abattoirs, will be short lived.

The South Korean market is also showing solid growth, from 69 kilotons in 1992-93 to a forecast 82 kilotons in 1995-96, and holds considerable promise for the future as its market liberalises towards the year 2000. Increased returns in Japan and Korea are likely to mean that the total value of Australian beef exports will increase in 1995-96. ABARE forecasts an increase in the overall value of beef exports to $2.9 billionâ€”Senator Boswell got it right; it is a $3 billion marketâ€”up from $2.8 billion in 1994-95. At the same time, our domestic beef consumption is forecast to increase by three per cent to 36 kilos per person in 1995-96.

I might also add that a number of other factors, such as the outcome of the Uruguay Round, have had very positive results, in particularâ€”I have commented on this beforeâ€”for our beef producers. That was recognised by the Cattle Council, which congratulated the government for its `tireless work and success'.

The Booz-Allen reportâ€”which has been mentioned on many occasions and on which I have previously commentedâ€”identified, as part of the 30 per cent of the problem that is in the hands of industry to fix, improved work practices in meatworks. As I told the Senate the other day, AMH is engaged right now in its abattoirs at Rockhampton in an exercise to do just that in cooperation with the unions and under the supervision of the Industry Commission.
But what the Booz-Allen report also said, and which no coalition senator is prepared to acknowledge, is that a problem equal in percentage terms to the work practice problem is the type of cattle being supplied to the export market. Small, grass-fed animals are not appropriate for that particular market. So, as well as improving work practices, beef producers also have to improve actual cattle types. Senator MacGibbon is shaking his head but I know many primary producers who are doing precisely that to improve their herds.

I conclude where I started: it must be a very strange crisis in the beef industry if, during two weeks of sitting, the coalition shadow minister for primary industry has said absolutely nothing about it in parliament.

talk.start.para: I rise to speak in this debate on the cattle industry to support most of what Senator Ian Macdonald has said in support of his motion. I must say that it bothers me that we get into these debates on an ideological basis and chuck accusations backwards and forwards across the chamber when the crisis, not only in the cattle industry but in many agricultural primary industries, is such that we all need to put our best minds to the problem. Rather than accusing one section or the other, we should try to work together for some solution.

para.tab: Tonight what I am going to do is not give solutions but perhaps pose some questions that have not been posed so far in this debate. I do this in terms of my conversations with a number of friends that I have who are cattle producers in Queensland, after talking to meatworkers in North Queensland about their problems with management in some of the meatworks there, having been rung by at least one rural commentator with his reflections on the problems in the industry, and having had a very interesting conversation yesterday with one person who is both a live cattle exporter as well as a processed meat product exporter and who had his own ideas about what was going on in the industry.

Just before the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) goes, I must say to him that I was puzzled by his abuse of Senator MacGibbon. I thought Senator MacGibbon was saying something that was quite accurateâ€”that live cattle and live sheep exports could hardly be called value added. Surely they are at the bottom of value adding. That is my understanding about what value adding is. I could not understand the minister's response to Senator MacGibbon at all, because I thought it was a fair comment. Live cattle and sheep exports, whatever they might be, surely are not value adding in that particular industry. I did not understand the minister's response at all. I think Senator MacGibbon was actually quite accurate.

However, let me raise the questions that have been raised with me on a number of occasions by the groups of people that I have just described. These for me are questions. I do not have the answers. They certainly were serious questions, and they were serious when they were raised with me yesterday by a personâ€”and I am not going to tell the person's name or the company of which he is the proprietorâ€”and he raised them with me because his family has been in meat production and processing for a number of generations in southern Queensland.

He asked questions not simply about work practices by workers in meatworks but about the ownership, for instance, of Australian meat holdingsâ€”overseas ownershipâ€”and whether or not some of these work practices are a deliberate ploy on the part of companies owned overseas who would rather see their overseas producersâ€”and I am talking about the United Statesâ€”operate in our markets. He said to me that some of the work practices by Australian meat holdings in southern Queenslandâ€”despite what the minister said about work practices in Rockhamptonâ€”have question marks over them. I would like answers to these questions.

He raised the issues of double shifts, reduced productivity on the part of management, lowered kills, minimum wages, and the attitudes to workers: all of which he claimed, as a meat processor, were deliberateâ€”at least that was his accusationâ€”attempts to reduce productivity in Australia so that American producers could sell their product into our markets, particularly in Japan. Certainly, press reports in recent days about a glut in the Japanese market because of the supply from America and Europe underline and reinforce at least the asking of that question.

I do not have an answer, but I believe that it must be asked. Where are the restrictive trade practices? Are they simply on the part of workers, as seems to be the accusation that is made often, or do they perhaps come from somewhere else? Certainly, if we are going to get answers for our primary industry, particularly our meat industry, we are going to have to sit down together and address all of the questions which are before us. I do not believe that ideological debates take us very far.

I was impressed with the breakfast put on by the Cattle Council yesterday that I attended and the document which they supplied to us. I hope the kind of spirit of cooperation that they projected ought to be in this industry can be followed through, although they also seemed to be laying the blame at the feet of mainly work practices and the government.

Surely, it is an industry which all of us are committed to and one which we need to seek answers for. We need to take on board, therefore, all of the questions which are being asked. I make this contribution not as offering solutions but as wanting to put on the record questions which are being asked that perhaps we have not altogether faced up to.

talk.start.para: â€”This afternoon the Senate is debating Senator Ian Macdonald's motion about the enormous contribution that the cattle industry has made to Australia, the crisis it is in at present and the failure of the government to alleviate the problems. At the outset, I make a declaration that I am a beef producer. I have been associated with the beef industry all my life. I certainly have a financial interest in what is going on at present.

para.tab: The cattle industry has made a huge contribution to Australia's welfare. It is the largest beef exporter in the world. It is an efficient industry. In the last 13 years, between 1980-81 and 1993-94, for a herd size of roughly 24 million head, beef production has increased by about 24 per cent. That is some indication of how efficient the industry is in itself.

I was interested to hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) reading, as if it was a holy writ from the
Bible
, some account from today's paper in which its author had claimed that the reason for the crisis in the industry at present was, amongst other reasons, the high cost of Australian beef. Cattle prices today are in the bottom of the trough. In actual fact, in 1994-95 we got half the price for our cattle that we got in 1990. There are very few industries that have taken a cut of 50 per cent in their product.

The cattle industry is the fourth largest export earner for Australia. It is about a $4.4 billion industry internally. Its total value to the Australian economy is estimated to be in excess of $7.7 billion. It employs over 120,000 directly and indirectly over half a millionâ€”600,000-oddâ€”Australians. But the industry is in crisis at present.

The minister bewailed the fact that no-one has raised that in the parliament. Given the government that we have and its total antipathy to rural interests, there is no point in raising things in this parliament because we will not get any response from a minister who makes the types of statements he did in his speech. All we can say about him is that he is trying, but he has no real understanding of the industry or he would not make statements such as live export trade was value adding or the problem with the beasts going into abattoirs, according to Booz-Allen, is that they are small and grass fed.

As someone in the industry, I can say to senators there is an acute interest in herd selection to meet the marketâ€”the Jap ox market, the Korean market and the rest of it. They all have a very high place within the consciousness of cattle producers, because there is an old dictum in the cattle business that you have to meet the market. You cannot go producing what you think is a product that the market wants, and certainly you cannot dictate the price for it. For an industry that is very much a price taker, we certainly do meet the market.

The problems that we have at present are compounded by a lot of things. The minister was correct when he said there are a lot of difficulties at present. We are in the fifth year of a huge drought in Queensland. No-one in the southern part of the continent, where there has been average or above average rainfalls roughly on a line from Sydney to Perth for the last four or five years, realises this. But Central Queensland is in a desperate position because of the drought.

As I say, we are now into the fifth year of it. The industry has been extremely badly hurt by that. The best you can hope for is to break even and a lot of people have gone very deeply into debt. But because of the strictures, the pasture improvements, the running repairs, the new equipment and even the herd improvements that would normally take place, have not been done because no-one has got the money to do that. It is really a matter of survival and it has been survival for the last four years.

Added to that, we have seenâ€”this is quite illogical; it does not fit in with any economic theoryâ€”given the strictures of the drought, this incredibly low price for cattle at the present time. The final straw that is breaking the camel's back is the closure of so many abattoirs in the Queensland area. Queensland is the centre of the cattle industry in Australia. It is certainly the heart of the export market. We are very much on the brink of a precipice at the present time, teetering on the edge.

I would like to move to the heart of this debate, which is the failures of the government to do something to alleviate the problems the industry suffers from. It is an industry that is of great value, as I said before, to the people of Australia. We are suffering from huge and avoidable oncosts that have been imposed on us by this government.

We do have archaic labour relations. That can be seen very clearly not only in the abattoir position but in relation to the wharves. The present minister for primary industries is the very same minister who resided over the WIRA reform, the reconstruction of the Australian wharves. He spent $400 million of taxpayers' money. All the analyses now show that productivity on the Australian wharves is even worse than it was before they spent that $400 million on it. In other words, we have gone back. As an export trader, we have to get product out. We in Australia pay three times what it costs in the United States and twice what it costs in New Zealand to have a beast slaughtered. They are our chief competitors.

We have the business that I do not have time to go into but which I think is very relevantâ€”Senator Woodley raised itâ€”about overseas ownership of abattoirs. The biggest competitor America faced in the Japanese market was Australia. When some of the principal Australian meatworks engaged in export trade are owned by the Americans now, you have to question the motives when they close down.

The abattoirs have great market power in the industry. They are the gateway through which everything passes. They are the price setters. They dictate the price the producer gets. They write the overseas contracts; they are all written by the individual abattoirs. They dictate in every sense what is happening in the export market.

We do need to reform our labour relations. We need new and many more modern abattoirs so that we can get our processing costs down. We need to do something about the inspection charges. We pay $60 million a year in inspection charges, which our competitors have funded out of the public interest.

One of the really key areas for us with long-term significance is the great cuts this government has made to CSIRO. CSIRO enabled the industry to be a world leader through all its research on pasture improvement, animal nutrition, animal health, breeding programs and the rest. That is all gone. In my own state of Queensland the DPI, which was an excellent department, has been cut right to the bone by the Labor government and is now almost ineffectual. When you talk to the DPI, they say, `The Labor government tells us there are no votes in it.'

We have difficulties with misguided environmental programs. All of us want to improve our land, but there is no movement made to restrict or buy back marginal lands for cattle grazing where there is great damage to the environment because it is unsuitable for cattle production. Ill-considered comments on land clearance, about trees, are having a great impact on future development.

talk.start.para: â€”I, too, must declare an interest in this debate because I have been involved in the cattle industry all my life, even though I do not talk about it every day. It is left to one of my partners to look after it.

para.tab: It is a pity that Senator Carr left the chamber because there are a few things I wanted to tell him. In his delivery he told us that this side of politics, the abattoir operators and the farmers are trying to reduce conditions and pay of abattoir workersâ€”and nothing could be further from the truth. But he will get a reply to that statement in due course.

The point I would like to make is: does anyone in this place know what price farmers at present are getting for their cattle; and how far back does the present price for cattle goâ€”for how long has the rate which is paid at present continued to be paid? I can tell the Senate that at present the prices for cattle on the hoof are exactly the same as they have been since 1976. There has been a certain amount of improvement on the per head situation; I believe that per head of cattle production is now 24 per cent more than it was in 1980.

So in real terms, the price cattle farmers and cattle producers receive at present is less than they were receiving in 1976. What is more, that same price was being paid in 1972. That price was being paid in 1970, 1971 and 1972. Then in 1973 there was a big crash in the cattle market. But it came back up somewhat to a level field in 1976. So per head it is around $600 to $700 for a 20-month-old steer delivered to the abattoir gate, which is exactly the same as it was in 1976 or 1972.
So can Senator Carr tell me where cattle producers in any way are ripping off any abattoir workers? He makes himself ridiculous by making such a statement.

Senator Carr then went on to criticise our use of the Booz-Allen figures to demonstrate the advantage that the Americans have over us when it comes to slaughtering costs. He said that, of course, the big problem with the Australian industry is the cost of the cattle themselves. But the prices that the farmers and producers are being paid for their cattle have returned to those of 1972. So in no way does that argument stand up.

I took the liberty of taking a page from the Booz-Allen report to do comparisons with the American market. The figure to land beef on the table in the United Statesâ€”perhaps not necessarily on the table, but probably in the butcher shopâ€”is $A4.34 a kilo. You then look at the prime animal cost. The prime animal cost in Australia is $A3.40 a kilo; in the United States it is $A4.65. That is what the farmers are getting in the United Statesâ€”$A4.65 a kilo.

When you take off the sort of revenue that comes from the by-products of the meat, the net cost of getting the animal into the abattoir in Australia is $A2.84 per kilo; in the United States it is $A3.83. So United States farmers have an advantage of approximately 99.5c per kilo over Australian farmers. That is the cost advantage they have. They pay that much more for the animal in America and yet end up with the same price.

I will go through the rest of the costs. We then come to the processing. This is where Australia, with its industrial relations and tally system, is behind. In Australiaâ€”even though Senator Collins said that he believed this figure was not rightâ€”it costs 112.7c per kilo to put through the abattoir; in the United States it costs 41.2c per kilo. So the United States has an advantage of 71.5c per kilo. That is the sort of advantage the Americans have.

Then when you land the meat in America, from America itself and from Australia, there is a big difference in the freight. So we will allow for that. It only costs Americans 9.7c per kilo for their transport and it costs them 37.7c a kilo from Australia. Of course that cost of 37c per kilo includes our inefficient waterfront, but let us get away from that issue.

Taking everything into considerationâ€”the freight to land it in America and their freight to get it to their tables or the butcher shopâ€”we are behind by 44c a kilo. That is what we are behind. So the farmers in America are able to get far more than our farmers can get and still land the product on the table over there at the same price. So the table from which I have been reading certainly points out the figures as to why Australian farmers are so disadvantaged within the workplace.

Let me move on to the issue of industrial relations. In Western Australia, Greens, which are well known for their abattoirs over there, have had industrial relations problems this week. They offered a 10 per cent increase over two years, with a guaranteed six per cent increase next year. But the union wanted more and they went out on strike all of last week. So Greens returned with a lockout on Monday until there is more commonsense.

The Kimberleys of Western Australia is a very important area for the cattle industry. The abattoirs have all had to close there because of the situation of industrial relations over the last 10 to 15 years. As a result there are none in the north. There is not one abattoir operating from Katherine, right around the west coast and down to Geraldton. There is not one abattoir there. What has that resulted in? The build-up of the live cattle industry. It is a good industry; but, unfortunately, with the live cattle industry going out, there is less work for Australian meatworkers or for anybody else. So that has been a very unfortunate result of the industrial relations up there.

Being a cattle grower and, like others, being in an area where I could grow something else, for what is in it, it is not really worthwhile to keep going at this rate. If it was up to me, we would probably out cattle and grow wheat, or run sheep or something like that. But there are a lot of farmers in Australia who, unfortunately, are in areas where they can grow only cattle, so they have to stay with it. But, as I have said before, I do not know why farmers in other situations bother to keep going at these prices. There is a lot of lot feeding now. I will give the lot feeders a bit of warning: the grain growers will not stand for importing subsidised grain every year as they did last year.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”One of the central points I want to make in this debate about the meat industry is that it is not that I disagree with everything the opposition says but there is a real lack of balance in their approach in analysing the problems the meat industry faces. Much of their contribution centred on industrial relations.
â€”I hardly mentioned it.

â€”You didn't, Senator Panizza; but a number of other speakers did. Before I go into that, I just want to pick up one of the issues that were raised on research and development. There was the allegation that there has been significant cutbacks by the Commonwealth in R&D. This is simply not true. There is the perpetuation or the creation of this myth in respect to agricultural research in Australia from the Commonwealth perspective.

para.tab: This government has a very impressive record of R&D contributions. We match dollar for dollar. It is this government that has established most of the rural research corporations. In 1985-86, when the Meat Research Corporation began, industry contribution was $5.54 million and Commonwealth contribution, dollar for dollar, was the same. If you look at the steady growth up until this year, 1994-95, you will see that the Meat Research Corporation levy was $22 million and the Commonwealth contributed $22 million. So we have seen total Commonwealth contributions of over $150 million in R&D since the R&D corporation began back in 1984-85 as an initiative of this government.

Certainly there have been some reductions in the CSIRO research funds, but that is more than offset by the moneys the Commonwealth pays through the research and development corporations. Senator MacGibbon referred to the cutbacks in Queensland at a state level. That may well be the case. However, there have been cutbacks in research in state departments under all state governments, regardless of who has been in powerâ€”Labor or Liberal. Go to Victoria. There has been a lot of ill feeling between the National Party and the Liberal government about the cutbacks in rural R&D in Victoria under the Kennett government.

It is regrettable that these cutbacks are occurring, but this Commonwealth commitment has been very solid and very substantial and it is increasing over timeâ€”not just in the meat industry but right across the rural sector. I have the other figures here, but I will not go into that this evening. But we have a very strong commitment in the R&D area.

The Booz-Allen and Hamilton report has received fairly significant comment in this debate. The critical issue here is the opposition's lack of balance. The input costs of labour certainly are a major factor with respect to the difference in the performance gap. There is no denying that. If you look at the table on page 55, you will see that 23 per cent of the gap was technology work practices; that is, labour costs. But that category is not just labour costs. I have been to a few meatworks in this country over the last couple of years and some of them are so antiquated and out of date. That does account for part of that 23 per cent performance gap.

There have been some other factors that are just as important. One that the minister referred to is the smaller, leaner animals that are supplied to the meatworks. But the most important issue with respect to this performance gap is that 34 per cent is distance from market. Regrettably, in Australia this problem is very hard to overcome because of the sheer distance associated with the transportation of animals to the coast and then beyond. We are a big country, unlike New Zealand which does not face that sort of distance from market.

I also want to touch on the industrial relations issue. There has been an adoption of new technologies. Individual works have been tackling key issues, such as enterprise agreements. They have been focusing on site productivity problems. Double shifting under the current award is being introduced in a number of operations. They have been seeking alternative market opportunities. The study identified that major opportunities lie in facility rationalisation and specialisation. That is just not an area of union or work force responsibility. Management has a lot to answer for in this area of the meat industry.

Some people in the press and in the opposition have alleged that there are very few enterprise agreements. The figure of six has been given, but there are now more than 34 enterprise agreements in the meat industry. In some instances, major meat processors have been working under enterprise agreements for three years. Employers speak of productivity improvements of around 10 to 15 per cent. In Victoria some companies are currently working on their second round of enterprise agreements.

Much of the responsibility for initiating and driving reform and for ensuring that employees understand and accept the need for and direction of reform rests with industries' individual employers. It does not just rest with the union movement or the work force. If you were fair and reasonable in a balanced debate about this issue of workplace reform, you would talk to some employers and middle management on a meat site and you would talk to some workers. I would have to say that it is the most intractable, dogmatic, determined, inflexible set of relationships that I have struck in any work site I have ever been to. The nature of the work at meatworks is not very pleasant. Many of the middle management and management people come from the shopfloor. Industrial relations is not easy at the meatworks or plant level.

Drought has been a significant factor; there is no doubt about that. I only have a small amount of time left, so I will not say too much about this issue, other than to say that drought has been a significant issue, particularly in Queensland.

There is one other issue I want to touch on. I had the opportunity to meet a Swedish delegation this week and voice my concern about Sweden's entry into the European Community and the effect of losing a $20 million a year meat market as a consequence. We are still arguing about compensation with the European Community. This also highlights one of the disadvantages we have in world markets. Despite that particular problem, generally the outcome of GATT benefits the meat industry, particularly in this country.

talk.start.para: â€”in replyâ€”In closing the debate, I thank my fellow senators on both sides of the House for the contributions they have made to what is obviously a very important subjectâ€”the motion acknowledging the enormous contribution made by the cattle industry to Australia, acknowledging the real crisis in which the industry finds itself at present and condemning the government for failing to address the underlying problems after 13 years in office.

para.tab: My colleagues who spoke from this sideâ€”Senator Boswell, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Panizzaâ€”have all had a great involvement with the industry over the years. Their contribution to the debate has been most valuable. They are people who have an understanding of the industry and an understanding of those problems. From the Labor Party we have the old tired, class warfare type arguments, typified by Senator Carr's speech. Senator Carr is a great mate of Wally Curran, who is acknowledged as single-handedly having practically destroyed the meat processing industry in Victoria. We had the old class warfare argument, which we on this side do not accept. We acknowledge the contribution that workers make to the industry, but we condemn the government for its failure to address the things that need to be addressed.

In all of the matters that we have been raising during this week, we have asked the government the question: why are meat processing charges in Australia 113c per kilogram when in New Zealand they are 72c and in America they are somewhere in the mid-40s? Not once have we been given a proper response.

I wanted to take this opportunity briefly to answer Senator Collins. Whenever he has nothing to say in the Senate, he attacks Mr John Anderson, the shadow minister for primary industries. Mr Anderson is in the other House. Of course, he cannot ask questions of Senator Collins, not that it would be of any use to him if he could because he would never get an answer. There is no-one in the other chamber in the Labor Party who has any interest in primary industry matters, so it is pointless Mr Anderson asking questions in the other place. Mr Anderson does ask questions through his representatives in this chamberâ€”the people who represent him on the coalition side. He gives information to Senator Boswell, myself, Senator Panizza and people interested in primary industries matters. We ask questions of Senator Collins.

Mr Anderson has a very close connection with the beef cattle industry. He has been around seeing those groups. He continuously does so. He understands their problems and he consults with them. In fact, he has a very close rapport with them. In government after the next election Mr Anderson will make a very fine contribution to Australia in the primary industries field and will certainly make his mark on putting in place the sorts of reforms that are necessary to get the cattle industry going.
