speech.speaker: Ellison Sen C.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I have tabled today the report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee which deals with the payment of a minister's costs; in particular, the government's decision to pay the legal costs of Dr Lawrence's challenge to the Marks royal commission. At the outset I would like to thank the members of the committee for their diligence and application in the short time we had in relation to this matter. Furthermore, I thank the secretariatâ€”in particular, Anne Twomey and Catherine Hawkinsâ€”for the work they did in compiling this report.

para.tab: In summary, the terms of reference dealt with the legal basis for the government's decision to fund Dr Lawrence's challenge; the sequence of events leading to the government's decision to do that; any advice obtained by the government as to Dr Lawrence's standing and any other person challenging the royal commission; what advice was received and consideration given to the likely costs involved; what role the government played in relation to any of the legal challenges to the Marks royal commission; and any other matters arising out of any of the terms of reference.

On 9 May this year, the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Richard Court, announced the Marks royal commission which inquired into the circumstances surrounding the tabling of a petition in the Legislative Council of Western Australia in 1992. At that time, Dr Carmen Lawrence was Premier of Western Australia.

Subsequent to the announcement of the royal commission, the government decided that it would fund Dr Lawrence's challenges to the royal commission. I say `challenges' because Dr Lawrence failed in two attempts before the Supreme Court to halt the royal commission and, furthermore, in another attempt before the High Court to do the same. In an article in the
Australian
dated 27 September 1995, Laura Tingle stated in relation to this report:

speech.para: Its findings not only have the capacity to reflect on the legality of Cabinet's decision, but on the extent to which the Senate and the Parliament can keep some control over how the executive government can spend money on itself . . .

That, I think, is a crucial question. Let us then turn to the question of the legal basis for the decision by the cabinet to fund Dr Lawrence in this matter. At the outset we have sections 81 and 83 of the constitution, which provide that there must be parliamentary approval for the appropriation of money; that is, in order for money to be taken from the consolidated revenue fund, parliament must firstly pass a bill. As well as that, we have section 48 of the constitution, which provides that parliament must specifically approve benefits to members and senators. It is with that in mind that we look at the legal basis for this decision.

para.tab: In evidence before the committee, the government stated that it had three courses of action available to it: firstly, the enactment of a single line appropriation; secondly, payment under section 34A of the Audit Act, which would constitute an act of grace; and, thirdly, payment out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, which was allegedly supported by legislative authority under the Parliamentary Entitlements Act.

The government decided on the latter course. Senator Gareth Evans gave evidence that the act of grace payment was a second option. In evidence before the committee, Dr Gavan Griffith, the Solicitor-General, said that may be a legal course of action. But it was obvious that the government's preferred course of action was to make this payment from the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

The question that needs to be asked is: would such a payment meet the requirements set out in the legislation establishing the Advance to the Minister for Finance and, if so, would the requirement of section 48 of the constitution, which I mentioned earlierâ€”that allowances to members of parliament be determined by parliamentâ€”be satisfied by the Parliamentary Entitlements Act? That is really the nub of the question.

In the High Court decision of Brown and West, section 48 of the constitution was considered. The outcome of that case was that the government needed more specific legislative authority than simply the Advance to the Minister for Finance to support its decision to pay costs. This was, I believe, applicable to the situation we have before us. Indeed, Mr Lindell of the University of Melbourne stated that the Parliamentary Entitlements Act did not really vary the decision in Brown and West; it formulated it.

We have a problem there. But, as well as that, we have the question of the provisionsâ€”and I refer to division 864 of the Advance to the Minister for Financeâ€”which enable a minister to make advances during the financial year that will make money available for expenditure if the minister is satisfied that it is urgently required and that it was unforeseen. Of course, it must be for the purposes of the Commonwealth.

This is where the government also comes to grief because the government cannot establish that this was urgently required. This decision to pay Dr Lawrence's fees was made on 8 June. It is now 28 September and still we do not have any payments being made. There was a real cause of concern raised as to the question of urgency. There is also the question of `purposes of the Commonwealth'. Is it really only a purpose of the government? That is a question which needs to be asked.

Under the provisions dealing with advances to the Minister for Finance, we have those hurdles which I believe that the government has great difficulty in negotiating. I might also point out that section 4 (4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act provides for the payment of benefits to a minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a minister. I put to the Senate that there are real problems in this matter in that a challenge to the royal commission by Dr Lawrence is not really for the purpose of carrying out her functions as a minister, but more to preserving her as staying on as a minister.

During the course of the hearing the committee heard evidence that there was a distinction between the functions of a minister as opposed to continuing to remain as a minister. There are profound problems with the course of action which is proposed by the government. I submit that should the government embark on this course there will be real problems as far as any unlawful expenditure goes. I refer to the Auckland Harbour principle which allows for governments to recover monies which are unlawfully paid out. That would possibly entail recovery of money from people to whom it was paid.

Finally, I would say that the government really did not receive sufficient advice when it made this serious decision in cabinet. As Senator Gareth Evans stated, it really amounted to bits and pieces. That is just not sufficient for a government when it is making such an important decision and setting such an important precedent as this.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)
â€”I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate eight minutes speaking time to each of the eight committee members in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

talk.start.para: â€”I, too, want to speak on the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee inquiry into the payment of a minister's legal costs. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in the body of the report there is not only a dissenting report from me, Senator Neal and Senator Cooney, but there is also some additional comment that I, as a Western Australian representative here in Canberra, felt highly motivated to add to the report. I believe it certainly puts the report into context.

para.tab: Before I make comments on the contents of the report, I wish to pay tribute to the efforts of Senator Ellison in chairing this committee and the inquiry. As everyone would recognise, it is a highly charged political issue that the committee was asked to address by the Senate. Whilst the terms of reference dealt with the decision of the federal cabinet to indemnify the payment of legal costs to a minister in the Commonwealth government, that was not the only thing that we were addressing. There were other extraneous matters that led to the government making that decision.

It was in that environment that Senator Ellison had the unenviable task, from time to time, of controllingâ€”well, we didn't really become highly charged, but certainly from time to time some quite aggressive debate went on between the committee members. Senator Ellison has done a very good job and I commend him for that.

It is unfortunate that inquiries of this nature are referred to committees of this kind. I think you will get no better result out of a committee than what we have here tonightâ€”a majority report and a minority report. A committee will divide on issues that are as highly charged as the ones that we have here. We will divide along party lines, and I think we recognise that.

The Senate committee system, which has made such a contribution to parliamentary democracy in this country, is at risk if we continue to follow the course of action that the Senate has appeared to follow in recent times. Anyway, I will speak more about that in other debates. I also pay tribute to the secretariat of the committee, who not only had to work on this particular reference but also had toâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Six others.

â€”Well, there are six other references. We put in a report this morning on another controversial matter of great interest to the community and we put in another report yesterday. It had to be developed and prepared for presentation to the parliament. We have another hearing tomorrow on a different reference. I am concerned that we are overworking the staff in our secretariats. In saying that, we are also not paying them enough for the work they do.

para.tab: I have to spend some of my time commenting on the content of this report. Essentially, this is a political report. There is no getting away from that matter. I recognise the position my colleagues from the opposition were in. They not only had to oppose the Commonwealth government's actions to indemnify a minister but had to be publicly seen to be doing that. I wonder whether that would have been the case if we were not in such a highly charged political environment.

One of the great disappointments in this committee was the decision of the Western Australian governmentâ€”and one would hope it was their decisionâ€”not to attend the hearings. I commend, as I have done in my additional comment, the efforts of the Chairman, Senator Ellison, to get a representative from the Western Australian government here. It was not that the only situation we wanted was to have a representative here in a physical sense; we also made the opportunity available for a representative of the Western Australian government to give evidence by videoâ€”at some cost to the parliament.

Unfortunately, Senator Ellison's efforts were not able to be accommodated, despite the fact that I had offered on behalf of the government members of the committee to allow the Deputy Premier, Mr Hendy Cowan, or the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Colin Barnett, to appear. I did that on the record. Off the record, I suggested to Senator Ellison that it might be good experience for Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, the Western Australian Attorney-General, to appear before the committee. She probably will get some experience in the future.

There is some comment in the body of the report about the dates of the applications from the minister, Dr Lawrence, to the Premier of Western Australia for advice on what the Western Australian government was going to make available to her as a defendant. It is unfortunate that in royal commissions we now have defendants, prosecutors and so forth.

The application Dr Lawrence made to the Premier was by a letter dated 18 May. She did not get a formal response to that correspondence telling her how much money was going to be available, how many lawyers were going to be available and so on until the executive officer of the Ministry of the Premier and Cabinet responded by letter to her lawyers on 14 September. If the Commonwealth had not gone ahead and made the indemnification at the time it didâ€”which was on 9 Juneâ€”Dr Lawrence would have been proverbially up the creek without a paddle. She had to wait four months to be told that Mr Court was going to be mean spirited in what he was going to allow to be paid to her.

The announcement of this decision has come four months after the application was madeâ€”after Dr Lawrence physically appeared before the commission; after the commission itself had been given an extension of time; and after the commissioner made that extraordinary statement which he repeated when he presented an amended set of issues, when he set out for the public eye a list of issues which he considered could be grounds for possible adverse findings against Dr Lawrence. Mr Court and his government do themselves no justice by being as mean spirited as they have been.

I have in my minority report made some reference to the remarks made before the committee by Mr Tony Morris. I let the remarks stand. I would make the point that I am not seeking to attack Mr Morris here, just as I did not in the committee. Mr Morris does make contributions from time to time to the work of the Senate legal and constitutional committee which have been of use in the past. But he has perhaps coloured himself a little bit too politically on this occasion and perhaps has damaged his reputation for the future.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I want to speak tonight in support of the majority report on the government's decision to fund Dr Lawrence's legal fees. We understand now that the funding is for her private legal challenges to scuttle the Western Australian royal commission into the Easton affair and, additionally, to top up the legal expenses for appearances before the commission. I will come back to that detail at a later point.

para.tab: Members on the other side assert constantly in publicâ€”under the Goebbels principle that if you keep repeating it people believe itâ€”that the only reason this commission was called was that Dr Lawrence is a popular federal Labor minister and there was a perceived need to somehow get at her and diminish her standing. I do not accept that proposition. I think it is a laughable proposition that a state government would put itself at risk by making a decision to spend several millions of dollars on this. For what? To assist its federal party, now in opposition? To spend that much money for that purpose is laughable.

There is no benefit to the Western Australian government in pursuing this commission if the only purpose in pursuing it is to damage Dr Lawrence. Why would a government put itself so at riskâ€”when it would have to go back to its taxpayers and say, `We think we spent this money wisely'â€”if the only reason it could use to justify it was that Dr Lawrence in some way needed damaging. It is egocentric argument taken to the quintessential extremeâ€”as though Dr Lawrence is the centre of everything.

I do not accept the proposition at all that this commission was called only because Dr Lawrence eventually ended up a federal government minister. I say that the reason the commission was called and for her involvement in it is not that she is a federal government minister at the moment but that, at the relevant time of the matters being inquired into, she was the state's prime minister, otherwise known as the Premier. That is the reason she is involved in this. It has nothing to do with what she is doing now at all.

It is a very sad reflection on the way this government has chosen to handle this argument. It has chosen to politicise a commission that, in my view, was not politicised. It has dragged itâ€”a commission that cannot respond on its own behalf; at least the commissioners and staff of the commission cannotâ€”into the public arena and has sought to rubbish it up hill and down dale. We know that this government was determined to do that. We knew that when the announcement was made that a commission would be called.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Labor members have issued fair and clear warningsâ€”I say `fair' not in the sense that I think the warnings were fair but that it was perfectly clear what they were saying: `If you get involved in this commission, you do so at your own risk.' No member of the judiciary, no former member of the judiciary and no member of the profession with any self-respect would get involved. The attacks started before we even knew what the terms of reference were. They continued when the terms of reference were released and they continued to shift to attacks on the commissioner and counsel assisting. It has been a relentless attack by this government on this commission.

Of course, the reason for that attack is quite clearâ€”because they have a perceived need to protect one of their own. They will do anything in order to do that, including attacking a properly constituted commission, former members of the judiciary and members of the legal profession who are simply doing their job. This is the old-time Labor philosophy: if you can't run it, wreck it.

Nonetheless, the purpose of the Senate committee inquiry was to establish whether the government's decision was a legal one. It may come as some surprise to members opposite to understand that, when you are elected to government and form a cabinet, that is not a ticket to go around playing with the taxpayers' money in some sort of unsupervised way like kids in a sandpit when the parents have goneâ€”`Now we have won, we can do what we like with taxpayers' money.' It may come as a shocking surprise to members opposite to understand that there are limits on what the Commonwealth government can do. It cannot spend at will. It has to spend in accordance with the constitution and in accordance with acts of parliament.

That was the purpose of the inquiry of the Senate committee. It was not anything, in a sense, to do with politics, although all of us here are; it was a question of whether the government is acting legally. That is the opposition's job. I think it is a perfectly fair case to say that it is not. If money is paid out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, it is an illegal payment and could probably be collected back from those who made the decision and those who received the money, but that is a moot point. All I am concerned about is whether it is a legal payment, whether the Commonwealth is acting legally.

What a shocking surprise to taxpayers to find that the Commonwealth had no written legal advice on the legality of its decision to pay at the time it made the decision. It was only when some journalists, perhaps acting independently from the coalition, raised the question of the legality that it thought it had better get a bit of advice. It got that advice from the Solicitor-General, and that advice is not 100 per cent clear. It does not say, `It is without a shadow of a doubt possible and perfectly legal for the Commonwealth to pay under the bills it is suggesting it can.' It says `the Commonwealth may reasonably'.

Anyone who went to law school understands why they spent a couple of weeks explaining the difference between `may' and `shall'. `Shall' is a definite. That is what the Solicitor-General's opinion should have said if he wanted to make it unequivocally clear that the Commonwealth was entitled to so spend this money. His opinion then would have said, `It is without doubt within the Commonwealth's power to spend the money according to these acts.' But his opinion is not like that; it is laden with doubt. The reason it is laden with doubt is that he himself can see the concern we have.

The Commonwealth must spend for a Commonwealth purpose. It is not in the constitution that it is a Commonwealth purpose to pay the minister's legal fees. So who else can define what a Commonwealth purpose is? This parliament can. There can be a single-line appropriation. If this government is so convinced that this is a proper use of taxpayers' money, it should put it to the test and ask parliament if it wants to spend the money this way. Don't just assume because you are the executive that you can do it out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

Members on the other side, as you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President McKiernan, say this is okay because this is to allow her to continue to carry out her duties as a minister according to the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. But, of course, the Parliamentary Entitlements Act does not refer to continuing to be a minister; it refers to carrying out the functions of a minister. And if that were the case, Dr Lawrence's proceedings would be in the name of the minister for health, not in her own personal name.

This is an outrageous misuse of Commonwealth money. It is an incorrect spending of the taxpayers' money, and I invite the government to put it to the test. Ask parliament as a whole if they think this a proper use of taxpayers' money.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)
â€”Order! Before calling Senator Spindler, I recognise in the gallery the presence of a former distinguished senator for Victoria and Deputy President of the Senate, Mr David Hamer. We notice even from this distance, Mr Hamer, that you are looking fit and well, and trust you are enjoying your retirement.

Honourable senators
â€”Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: â€”There are two key issues in this matter. One is the cabinet decision to make a commitment to pay Dr Lawrence's legal fees. Clearly, that decision was made on the basis of a mixture of political and legal considerations. The second one is whether the timing, extent and method of payment that the government wishes to undertake has a sound legal basis.

para.tab: I make a distinction between those two matters and note that other speakers so far have not made that distinction. But I am making that distinction because cabinet made that decision and it now has to demonstrate the reasons for that decision. However, at this stage no payment has been made. The government, therefore, has a range of options before it actually proceeds to meet its commitment and make those payments.

I will even now put my conclusion on the second point on the table. That is, while cabinet has certainly the right to make an executive decision in its execution in this matter of expending public funds, it must seek parliamentary approval before it can do so. There may be some ways in which it can avoid that, but I believe that they are fraught with difficulty.

In seeking to determine the legal basis for the cabinet decision, I believe that we must have regard to the state of knowledge cabinet had at the time when it was making it. Thus, it is not relevant that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said at a later date that the outcome would not affect Dr Lawrence's position as a minister, or that commissioner Marks himself expressed doubts about the effect the commission's work might have.

Cabinet made the decision in ignorance of these developments but also, apparently, without obtaining a comprehensive legal opinion on the basis for its proposed course of action except, according to Senator Gareth Evans, in bits and pieces.

Cabinet did not request or receive a statement from Dr Lawrence on the legal strategy she intended to pursue, including the challenge to the validity of the commission. While I believe that challenge is certainly within customary legal practiceâ€”and there is plenty of precedent for that before royal commissions to challenge the jurisdiction, the validity and constitutionality of a royal commission, so I have no objection to that being included in the consideration, although objections were raised by the opposition speakers on that pointâ€”I believe there are implications for the quantum of costs that would be affected by the strategy that Dr Lawrence would propose. And it is strange that cabinet made that decision without consultation on the strategy she decided to pursue.

Further, no attempt was made, on the basis of the evidence before the committee, to put in place a monitoring system, a consulting system on her future intentions on her strategy and, therefore, on the level of cost that could be expected. The cost implications of a strategy are quite different from the `fair and reasonable' quantum measure that would be applied by the Attorney-General's Department in determining whether a particular bill should be paid or not.

I believe that these matters are somewhat poor management but do not of themselves negate the basis for the cabinet decision. That decision clearly rests on the proposition that the WA royal commission is a politically motivated attempt to damage or oust a Commonwealth minister and that it is directly and necessarily related to her capacity to function as a minister. I believe that, in general terms, this proposition has merit. It is highly improbable that the WA commission would have been initiated if Dr Lawrence were in private practice.

A search of previous royal commissions involving politicians did not disclose any royal commission that was not in some way related to criminal behaviour. Even the WA Premier is not alleging that Dr Lawrence could be guilty of that. Further, the behaviour complained of, misleading the parliament of WA, in summary is, by analogy, relevant to the minister's capacity to function in the Commonwealth parliamentâ€”a major part of her ministerial duties and the circumstance which distinguishes the allegation from purely personal misdemeanours where government provision of defence costs would certainly not be justified.

On the basis of these considerations, it is arguable that the decision by cabinet can, on balance, be brought within the provision of section 81 of the constitution, which requires expenditure to be `for the purposes of the Commonwealth'. However, the proposed payment must also be brought within section 83 of the constitution, which requires payments to be made as a result of an appropriation of parliament.

Since no payment has yet been made, the federal government, as I said, is now able to consider three options. The first two are: an act of grace payment under section 34(a) of the Audit Act, which would be considered an avenue of last resort; and the enactment of a single-line appropriation in an appropriation bill, which would satisfy both the requirement of section 83 of the constitution, because it would be an appropriation made by law, and also section 48, because parliament would specifically enact a provision giving this pecuniary benefit to a member of parliament.

Payment under the Advance to the Minister for Finance supported by the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990 is the third option. This would certainly enable payment of the legal bills as they fell due but I believe presents certain difficulties. I wonder whether the requirement for such payment to be urgent is met by the fact that people wanted to pay legal bills quickly. I believe that in legal practice practitioners often accept a considerable delay before their bills are paid.

The requirement that the need to make moneys available must be unforeseen is more easily satisfied since the amount required was not known until now. The requirement that the expenditure must be for the purposes of the Commonwealth is satisfied as detailed in my previous examination of the cabinet decision.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”This matter is a matter of great importance. It is a matter of great principle. Basically, this case boils down to one simple question: should ministers of the Crown be above the law which is set out in the constitution and which applies in this country? I believe the answer is that they should not. What has happened in relation to Dr Lawrence's legal expenses is that Dr Lawrence's colleagues in the cabinet have voted to meet legal expenses on her behalf to which she is not entitled.

para.tab: It is a basic issue of law. It is a very basic principle that a cabinet which takes unto itself powers it should not have is as injurious to democracy as a dictator who takes unto himself or herself powers that they should not have. Let me elaborate for honourable senators why I believe it is the case that cabinet here has voted legal benefits to Dr Lawrence to which she is not entitled.

It is a basic factâ€”and it is set out in sections 81 and 83 of the constitutionâ€”that money cannot be expended except by appropriation. What we have here is a decision to vote moneys to Dr Lawrence other than by appropriation. It is clearly a case that the moneys could not be paid out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for the simple reason that the matters are not urgent. Moreover, the payments cannot fall into the category of payments which could be made to a minister of the Crown lawfully as payments made in relation to that minister are benefits forwarded by the government to a minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a minister. I shall turn to the second matter very briefly.

In relation to the first question of whether this payment is urgent, the answer is quite simply not. The reason put before the committee at the hearings was that the payment was urgent as there was a bill on hand. But the bill on hand still has not been paid. So the matter was quite clearly not urgent. It was not a matter of whether payment had to be made before parliament returned; it was quite within the competence of the government to arrange for a single-line appropriation to be brought before the House and then brought before the Senate in the first sitting day. But that did not happen. Instead, an ad hoc decision was made which had the effect of unlawfully giving a benefit to Dr Lawrence. That payment cannot be characterised as a payment to a minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a minister. Let me explain why.

There are two alternative interpretations of what that section means. The first interpretation is a very loose interpretation, and it goes to the question of whether a minister could continue to function as a minister of the Crown. I do not accept the first interpretation. The second and, I believe, more correct interpretation is that this section was meant to authorise payments to a minister for the purposes of the exercising of his or authority and powers as a minister of the Crown and the execution of his or her responsibilities as a minister of the Crown. Quite clearly, to pay Dr Lawrence's legal expenses to appear before a royal commissionâ€”which is not inquiring into her position now or the exercise of her position now as a minister of the Crown which she currently holdsâ€”does not fit within that definition. So, on the test which I believe to be the more correct test, these payments do not qualify.

However, there is the possibility that the former test may be the more appropriate test. If that is so, I again say that these payments do not fit within that category. If one says that we should apply the broad test, and the broad test means anything which is necessary to ensure that a minister continues to function as a ministerâ€”in other words, he or she is not disqualifiedâ€”then this payment is not of that nature. Why is this payment not of that nature? This payment is not of that nature because this royal commission is incapable of disqualifying Dr Lawrence as a minister of the Crown in the federal parliament. It is a simple matter of fact.

Irrespective of what the royal commissioner finds, he does not have the power to disqualify Dr Lawrence from her position as federal health minister. Even if one accepted the broad test of what constitutes a payment for the purposes of meeting his or her functions as a minister of the Crown, and if one says that it also means continuing to function as a minister of the Crown, it does not matter what the royal commission says because it cannot disqualify Dr Lawrence. The payment does not fall within that category. Moreover, if that test were correct, there would be all sorts of undesirable results. Suppose, for example, that a minister of the Crown was facing bankruptcy proceedings that were brought by a creditor. Would it be competent for the cabinet colleagues of that minister to vote the money to that minister to defend the bankruptcy proceedings? On this basis it would, because a person who is an undischarged bankrupt is disqualified from being a member of parliament. After a period of three months, he or she would be disqualified from being a minister of the Crown. So, quite clearly, if one applies that test, a minister facing bankruptcy proceedings could have those costs borne by the Commonwealth. Worse still, if you apply that test, it might even be competent for that minister's cabinet colleagues to vote the money to meet the debts, because they are payments necessary for the minister to continue functioning as a minister of the Crown.

I believe very clearly on the evidence that these payments are unlawful. I also believe that the situation may arise where those payments may be recoverable from Dr Lawrenceâ€”for the simple reason that, although she may not receive the money herself, they have discharged a liability under a bill which was rendered to Dr Lawrence. Therefore, if those payments are unlawful and they have been applied for her benefit, then quite clearly the money may be recoverable from Dr Lawrence at some future point in time. I do very strongly believe that this is a matter of principle that must be enforced.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to join with the speakers so far in paying tribute to the secretaries involved in this inquiry. Catherine Hawkins, in my mind, has been a big find. I do not know where she came from but, wherever she has come from, she has done great work.
â€”She is in the gallery at the moment.

â€”Is she? I see. I would also like to thank Anne Twomey. I also pay tribute to the chair of the committee, because I think it was a fairly difficult committee to chair, and to Senator Abetz. Senator Abetz has some impulse within him to every now and then act like the Prophet Amos and come and preach to us and tell us where we go wrong. I thought that might happen during that time, but it did not. In fact, the most savage person in the committee on this occasion, Mr Acting Deputy President McKiernan, I am afraid to say, was you. I notice that you have put in a report that is very interesting, and you spoke very well.

para.tab: I thought Senator O'Chee made a very impressive contribution to this debate and, indeed, dealt with the law in a most impressive manner. I thought that his legal opinion, and his certainty in his legal opinion, ought be borne in mind. It is unfortunate that the government cannot rely on Senator O'Chee, because we have a Solicitor-General to whom they have to go to, in terms of the propriety of the situation, to get the advice that they act upon. It may be that Senator O'Chee should become Solicitor-General to this government; he could probably do it a lot of good. But until that happens, the government has to proceed along the lines that it does at present. Perhaps Senator O'Chee is a better lawyer than Mr Gavan Griffith QC, but Mr Gavan Griffith QC is the person who presently holds the position of Solicitor-General.

Another thing I want to say is this: Senator Vanstone came and gave a very impressive answer to the attack that you took upon the position adopted by the coalition, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I thought she dealt with it very well. She denied the sorts of allegations that have been made, the sorts of inferences that have been drawn, about the purposes of this committee, and I thought she did that well.

No doubt, Mr Acting Deputy President, you would have been pleased had somebody come before the committee and performed the same task because, as you remember, there were some very strong accusations made before our committee to the effect that this royal commission, constituted by Mr Marks QC, had been set up for political purposes. Indeed, in our dissenting opinion, we set out on page 4 a whole series of reasons why we drew that conclusion. We went on to say that Senator Gareth Evans had put, in this formal setting of the committee, allegations that he took to be true about the circumstances in which this royal commission was called.

I know, Mr Acting Deputy President that, between the times you were getting quite frenzied about this whole matter, you were attempting to get somebody from the Western Australian government to rebut, in the way that Senator Vanstone attempted to rebut, those allegations. Senator Vanstone was properly moved to come in here because the sorts of allegations that are being made in this matter are the sorts of allegations that need rebuttingâ€”and she has done that.

I wonder why that was not done by somebody who would know the answer to these issues and who would be able to tell us with assuredness that the sorts of things that were put were not true? Here is poor Senator Vanstone, for whom you and I have great regard, as does everybody else, who does not know the details of these matters, who is not from Western Australia, who goes about her duties over here of looking after the people of Australia, acting as the shadow Attorney-General, and who feels she has to come and defend the issues put before this committee.

Why wasn't that same impulse in the breast of people from the Western Australian government who know the sorts of things that Senator Vanstone has alleged, the people who could have saved Senator Vanstone the embarrassment of coming in here to try to rebut these inferences and statements by Senator Evans that are open on the evidence? Why didn't somebody come and do that? Are we entitled, as we have done, to draw from that fact the inference that what Senator Evans was saying and what the inferences were about these commissions were true?

We had doubt. We talked about these things, as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President. We believed implicitlyâ€”the open-minded people that we areâ€”that we should keep a doubt in our minds as to whether it was true. But after the reaction by the Western Australian government and after the speech tonight by Senator Vanstone, who knew that this sort of thing had to be rebutted, I suppose that you and I can only become absolutely confirmed in the opinion that this was a royal commission set up with aâ€”we are not saying `the'â€”central purpose of doing damage to the federal government.

There is some suggestion that the legislature should stand above the executive. You and I, Mr Acting Deputy President, agree that the parliament is the only body that can make money available for appropriations. But that does not mean to say that the executive is inferior to the parliament. The executive has got a duty to protect itself. May I read from William Blackstone; I know the Deputy Clerk will have read William Blackstone on very many occasions. In 1765, he said:

speech.para: It is highly necessary for preserving the balance of the constitution, that the executive power be a branch, though not the whole of the legislative. The total union of them, we have seen, would be productive of tyranny; the total disjunction of them, for the present, would in the end produce the same effects, by causing that union against which it seems to provide. The legislative would soon become tyrannical, by making continual encroachments, and gradually assuming to itself the rights of the executive power.
As Mr Justice Brooking said in a recent case, City of Collingwood v. State of Victoria, that there is the thought that the legislature can be a tyrant.

para.tab: I finish by saying that our humble opinion had to be typed. It was done by Marcia O'Hara who left at 5.30 before I got back. I may be in trouble, so could I put on record my indebtedness to her and my apology for not being back in time.

speech.speaker: Abetz Sen E.

talk.start.para:
â€”In commencing my remarks in this debate, I also add my compliments to the staff of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee and also to the chairmanship of Senator Ellison. I was somewhat insulted by Senator Cooney, who referred to me as the Prophet Amos because, as I read the
Bible
, I know Amos was only a minor prophet. Allow me to quote to Senator Cooney from Amos chapter 1:2:

speech.para: The Lord roars from Zion, and utters his voice from Jerusalem . . .

It goes on to say a little later `and the top of Carmen withers'. In fact, it is `Carmel withers', but I thought with a little bit of translation we could make `Carmel' into `Carmen'. That is possibly what this royal commission is all about: the top of Carmen is in fact withering.

para.tab: It is appropriate to quickly make a recap of the history of this reference. This reference arose because of community concern at the federal government's attitude in defending Dr Lawrence on the principle that this government acts under; namely, `We'll do whatever it takes.' The inquiry arose from a squalid exercise undertaken by the then Western Australian government in their attempt to torpedo Richard Court as Leader of the Opposition. Rather than being torpedoed, he of course was torpedoed into the premiership, and Dr Lawrence has now had her dirty little tactic backfire on her. She has been exposed for what she is, and people can make up their own minds.

I remind the Senate that Dr Lawrence's own Deputy Premier gave evidence and a gaggle of former Labor ministers and her former staff all gave a version of events that, I must say, cast some doubt on the integrity of the evidence provided by Dr Lawrence. Because of that dilemma faced by Dr Lawrence, the Labor government, or cabinet, decided to underwrite Dr Lawrence for an action against the royal commission and for her to appear before it.

The issue in question is whether the executive or the parliament has the power to make available those funds of our fellow Australians. Senator Ellison has already very ably set out the legal situation and the relevant legal authorities. Boiled down, the essence of the debate over payment of Dr Lawrence's legal costs is whether parliament or the executive is in control of the purse strings.

Section 48 of the constitution clearly says that there is a limit to be applied to the benefits payable to parliamentarians unless specifically provided for by the parliament in its own legislation. In other words, the executive should not be allowed to buy off parliamentarians. This parliament, in its wisdom, has passed the Remuneration Tribunal Act and also the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. Those two pieces of legislation indicate the types of allowances that are payable.

In this situation with Dr Lawrence, the government seeks to rely on the Parliamentary Entitlements Act and, in particular, paragraph 4(4)(b), which is set out at paragraph 3.71 of the report. It says:

speech.para: Benefits under this Act do not limit:
(b) benefits afforded by the Government to a Minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a Minister.

Clearly, one could hardly regard the prior history of Dr Lawrence as a former Premier and the action she undertook years ago in that capacity as somehow part of her function as a minister today, as a minister in the Commonwealth government. Clearly, there can be no relationship. If there is, we have a situation where basically anything goes.

para.tab: Mr Robertson QC, who gave evidence to our committee, basically said, `Yep, anything goes.' I happen to believe that that was not parliament's intention, and I happen to believe that it would be unlikely that the High Court would rule that it is within the function of Dr Lawrence, as health minister, to be defended in front of a royal commission in relation to something completely outside her role as a minister for health in this federal government. Indeed, I quote from 3.87 of the report, which relates to Mr Robertson's evidence:

speech.para: The executive, of course, would never make that payment nor would, I assume, an executive ever fund divorce proceedings but it is open to the executive to do so just as it is open to an employer to give a benefit to an employee such as the payment for dog food.

So basically what he is sayingâ€”and the full quote is thereâ€”is that if somehow it frees up Dr Lawrence or a minister of the crown to attend to her functions, then it is appropriate for the taxpayer of Australia to pay for somebody to feed her dog so it does not bark of a night. This is the person who was seeking to substantiate the proposed payment to Dr Lawrence. How that can relate to her functions as a minister is beyond me. That is why this committee by majority took the view as expressed by Mr Morris QC.

para.tab: Mr Acting Deputy President, I was concerned at the attack made by you in your additional comment on Mr Morris. It is regrettable that those comments were made. Some of the comments that were made were:

speech.para: I must say I was not impressed by Mr Tony Morrisâ€”

and then over the page, that he had `come very close to misleading parliament'. If we were to rely on that opinion, one has to ask, Mr Acting Deputy President, why the senator involved, Senator Mckiernan, also co-signed the minority report, which said in paragraph 4:
In our view all witnesses contributed to the committee hearing with integrity.

So we have on the one hand the accusation that he appeared with integrity but on the other hand it was nearly misleading the parliament. You cannot have it both ways. With respect, it was simply a cheap political attack, as we have witnessed by the Labor Party on Justice Marks and on senior counsel, Ms Vanstone QC.

para.tab: Senator McKiernan in his report also saidâ€”and he said it in his commentsâ€”that four months was required before the Western Australian government made moneys available to Dr Lawrence. Fifty-four days of that delay were occasioned by Dr Lawrence not responding to other letters that failed to be mentioned. Lots of matters are of concern in this affairâ€”Senator Evans telling us that he had armloads of evidence but then before the committee having to admit that it was really only bits and pieces. That is, with respect, getting very close to misleading the Senate, if we want to talk about that. The allegation that if Dr Lawrence was notâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order!
â€”I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

para.tab: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.sub1.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

para.tab:
Consideration resumed from 25 September, on motion by
Senator West
:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: â€”This report continues the long line of excellent reports we have had from the defence subcommittee over the years in this parliament. In the few minutes I have available to me tonight I want to comment on a few points in the report's final remarks. The first point I wish to comment on is the lack of air mobility in the army, especially given the recent withdrawal of the Nomad aircraft and the problems with the Black Hawk helicopters. The Black Hawk helicopter saga is one of the blackest in the Australian Defence Force's history. It is black because it is just gross mismanagement. From memory the purchase price of the helicopter fleet was around $600 million. The ancillary cost, training cost and the rest of it would have to run probably close to 60 per cent again. So the taxpayer would have probably around $800 million invested in this program. The program has been running for about 10 years now and we simply do not have any utilisation out of these aircraft. The army blames the air force and the air force blames the army for it. It is a divided administrative command with respect to maintenance and operation. Whatever the rights or wrongs of the issue, the bottom line position is that Australia just does not get the use of this asset that it made a very big investment in and an asset which is crucial for contemporary land operationsâ€”to have air mobility. I suppose out of the 36 or 38 helicopters we have in inventory we would be lucky to be able to put six on the line on any day. That is a very sad situation and absolutely inexcusable.

para.tab:
The next point I wish to comment on is the paying off of HMAS
Tobruk
. The most recent information the Senate legislation committee was given, at an estimates hearing, was that
Tobruk
would be sold. I am personally opposed to that because the Australian Defence Forces have very little sea lift capability. Since the estimates committee hearing, the proposal has changedâ€”I think to keep
Tobruk
.

Resignation rates are running very high at the moment. The minister admitted in answer to a question I asked last weekâ€”he gave the answer on Monday of this week because he did not know the answer at the timeâ€”that the current resignation rates from the RAN are running at around 14.7 per cent. When you are losing over 12 per cent of the members of the defence force, you are in a very difficult situation. At 14.7 per cent, you have a crisis. Navy has great difficulty now in manning its ships and getting anything to sea.
Tobruk
is apparently scheduled to be manned by reservists, but there are not the reservists around to man it.

One of the functions of the navy that has been overlooked by this government is the provision of a sea lift capability. The Second World War, and all the operations we have been involved in since the Second World War, do require a sea lift capability to support a land force if it is operating outside of Australia. You cannot support a serious operation purely by air.

Tobruk
is essential in our inventory given the fact that we have only two other shipsâ€”the newly acquired 20-year-old American LSTsâ€”for sea lift. The navy has to have the capability to support a land force in an area outside Australia, particularly if this government is to be believed in its frequent statements that it sees Australia in a role of supporting regional activities with nations in our region. I think that is quite a proper role, but there is a corollary to that. History teaches us that, if you are going to support other countries, in most cases you need a land force. That land force, as I say, has to be supported by sea. The crisis with
Tobruk
has to be solved. It has to be retained in the inventory at the present time and it has to be crewed.

The third point I wish to comment on is the importance of early acquisition of airborne early warning patrol aircraft. I have been in this parliament now for 17 years. My earliest statements go back to the crucial need for an airborne early warning capability for Australia. This is a huge country. There is no way we can know what is going on over our own sovereign land if we do not have a means of detecting what is happening. The way you detect air traffic and the way you detect sea traffic is by radar. It is quite impossible for Australia to put ground based radar stations around the northern half of the country. The cost would run into billions of dollars.

The solution to filling that gap is airborne early warning radar aircraft, which will not only provide surveillance of the air and sea space but with contemporary technology will give you information of land activities as well. Additionally, it will give you a command and control function. Command and control, the ability to relay information and intelligence, is as crucial as knowing what goes on. Every minister we have had in the time I have been in this parliament has preached the doctrine that there are new developments just around the corner and if we wait a little while we will get something much better and much cheaper.

The facts of the matter are that I think the first AEW aircraft flew in 1944. It might have been the early part of 1945, but it is over 50 years ago. It is true of any high technology that there are always new developments coming, but you have to get on the ladder somewhere. Australia has been grossly remiss because there is no way we can know who is coming into, leaving or approaching our country unless we have that capability. There is no other technology that can provide it for us.

It is not purely an air force requirement. It is as relevant to the navy and to the land force as it is to air force. It is a very great weakness. If you identified one weakness in our defence capability, it would be the lack of an airborne early warning capability.

I am rather concerned at a story that is being floated off in the press, a story which obviously comes from the government and Defence, that we might be considering adding to the order of the new 130J model Hercules that we are buying to provide several platforms for an AEW aircraft. The purchase of the 130J is an excellent choice and is long overdue for the transport and air refuelling needs of the Australian Defence Force.

However, to propose that aircraft as a platform for an AEW capability is to seek yesterday's solution to tomorrow's problems. It is an unqualified aircraft in that role. It would cost us probably $50 million to $80 million or maybe $100 million to qualify it in the role before we started putting any equipment into it. It is of reasonably short range for an AEW aircraft. It has a problem in that four propellers interfere with the electromagnetic signature.

The only platform that we could use for an AEW aircraft, bearing in mind that we want an investment that will have a 30-year life, is a contemporary jet aircraft. The only platform available is the Boeing 760 extended range aircraft that the Japanese defence force have purchased as a platform for their AEW aircraft. They have expended $80 million just qualifying that airframe as a military airframe without putting any electronics into it. That is a sunk cost that someone else has paid for later buyers.

It is not a matter of recoiling at the cost, as many people do, of having that Boeing 767 as a platform. In the near future, we will have to get rid of the Boeing 707s, which are now roughly 30 years old. They form the only airborne fuelling capability that the RAAF has. They are long-range strategic freighting and troop transport as well.

There will come a time in the near future when Boeing Aircraft Corporation will not support the civil version of the 707 any longer. We will then face a replacement. The intelligent thing for the government to do is to adopt a long-range plan to purchase the Boeing 767 extended range version with the military airframe. It should initially dedicate four of those airframes for an AEW capability and move progressively into acquiring a full squadron of those aircraft to provide the freight and airborne fuelling capabilities that we need. The 130J cannot be used to provide an airborne fuelling capability in an offensive environment.

The great advantage of using the 767 is that it can be supported. It fits in very well with the government's commercial support program. We can get competition between Ansett and Qantas, who both operate these aircraft at present and will for many years ahead. So they can be supported within the civil infrastructure in Australia.

The need for an AEW aircraft is absolutely crucial. You have to bear in mind that, if we decided tonight to move into this program, it would be probably 10 to 15 years before we had that capability. Our neighbours in the region have it. They have had it for years. It is a glaring defect and the greatest defect in Australia's defence capability. It is one that we must fill. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

speech.speaker: Ellison Sen C.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak in relation to the government's response to the findings and recommendations of the report by the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media. That report related to an inquiry into the sale of the Fairfax empire, as it was known, in 1991.

para.tab: I note that this report was tabled in June 1994, with a final oral report being given in March this year. It has taken the government 15 months to respond to the written report and six months to respond to the oral report. That is quite outstanding when you think that the normal requirement is for the government to respond within three months.

I just take this opportunity to express my disappointment that the government has taken so long to respond to a report by a Senate select committee, and one which did raise some very important matters indeed when it was looking into this matter. The reason for that committee being set up by the Senate related to a comment by Conrad Black in his book
A life in progress
. In his book he claimed that, at a meeting in November 1992, Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, had agreed that Black's company, the
Telegraph
, would be able to raise its stake in Fairfax to 25 per cent. He further claimed that the Prime Minister at the time also said that if he were re-electedâ€”that is, the Prime Ministerâ€”and Fairfax political coverage was balanced, he would entertain an application to go higher.
Subsequently in a radio interview in Seattle, on 18 November 1993, Mr Keating admitted that he had sought from Conrad Black a commitment that the paper would be balanced, and:

speech.para: . . . if there is any notion that, you know, of biasâ€”that is, you barrack for the coalition on the basis of your conservative proclivities in other places, then there is no way you would qualify as the kind of owner we would like.

That quite squarely gives rise to the inference that the Prime Minister at the time was giving Conrad Black a very clear message as to how he wanted Conrad Black to behave. But the Prime Minister also went on in that interview to say:

So therefore after the election I, on behalf of the government, made good a commitment to reconsider them and took them to 25 per cent. At the time Black only had 15 per cent in Fairfax and of course the increase of the decision to 25 per cent was crucial.

para.tab: So it was that, during the course of the inquiry by this committee, there were other aspects which came to light which proved to be totally unsatisfactory. I note that not only does the government quite arrogantly dismiss the committee's finding in relation to the statements made by the Prime Minister about the increase of Mr Black's holding, but it also ignores essentially the recommendation made by the committee in relation to the operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

One has to cast one's mind back to the situation that took place when Fairfax was finally taken over by a consortium involving Mr Black. At that stage, you had two foreign bidders who wanted to enter into the arena in Australia in a bid to take over Fairfax. You had a local bidâ€”Australian Independent Newspapersâ€”who did not have to go through the Foreign Investment Review Board. So they, without any foreign competition, would have had no problem whatsoever in acquiring Fairfax. We have to remember that there was a stake here of some $1.5 billion.

But what the Foreign Investment Review Board did was to allow in the challenge by Conrad Black. So it was that a foreign player was able to enter into the domestic market, to then compete with a domestic bidder and thereby take over the Fairfax empire.

During the course of the inquiry, it came to light that there was a Foreign Investment Review Board minute, dated 5 December 1991, which was quite derogatory of the local bidder. It was quite derogatory of AIN in that it said that that consortium did not have much financial backing and really did not have much experience in newspapers.

I put to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that was quite the reverse, and that what happened was that AIN was judged in its absence. So it was that the Foreign Investment Review Board deliberated, or caused the matter to be deliberated, on quite false foundations. Therefore, I am amazed to see that in the government response it says that the committee failed to recognise that, as an Australian entity, AIN was not an applicant for foreign investment approval. Well, of course it was not.

But what the Foreign Investment Review Board was doing, on this false basis and on the advice it gave to the Treasurer, was letting in a foreign player. The government said, `Accordingly, that information was not of any consequence in determining the "contrary to national interest" test in respect of the two foreign investment proposals.' It was relevant. It was put to the board and to the Treasurer in the absence of AIN having any chance to contest that. So I put to the Senate that there is indeed a major flaw in any process which allows that to happen and which resulted in one of the biggest foreign takeovers in this country's history. So the government has done really nothing to address that. That is the second point which has been overlooked.

We have the one finding which related to the committee's finding that Mr Willis, the Treasurer, acted contrary to the public interest in not assisting the parliamentary inquiry by directing his officials not to attend and not to provide evidence. The government says that this behaviour is consistent with established principles relating to the provision of confidential advice to the government. The government said that it was in the public interest for these officials not to give that evidence to the committee.

What this raised head on was the question: how much should a Senate committee be told? If one is to take any notice of the government response, not much. Senate committees go about very important tasks. Senate committees represent the Senate and the people of Australia. So when they conduct their inquiries, they do not expect to run up against stonewalls, especially not stonewalls from the government of the day. The Treasurer actively obstructed the proper inquiry of that committee. As a result of that committee's operations, there was careful consideration as to the whole question of how Senate committees should operate and how the government of the day should comply with their requests for information and evidence.

But the government here takes no note of that. Nothing has been done by the government to fix that problem either. We still have the unsatisfactory situation where the government of the day can thumb its nose at Senate committees, and indeed has done so since. That was another aspect of the print media report which the government simply failed to address. So when one looks at this response to the report by the committee, one finds that it is totally lacking in substance and does not do any justice at all to the report which was handed down by the committee. Finally, such a cavalier response by the government is an affront not only to the Senate committee system but also to the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
