The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)
â€”Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: â€”I want to raise a few matters in the few minutes I have available to me in the adjournment debate tonight. Firstly, I want to note that yesterday the first person was charged under the new laws relating to child sex tours, and that person appeared in court. This is in relation to an alleged offence of an act of indecency on a child in the Philippines.

para.tab: As I said, it is the first case under the child sex tourism act that was passed by this parliament last year under which Australians convicted of paedophile activities overseas could face up to 17 years in gaol. Obviously, there are some problems involved in this legislation relating to fairness and how effectively it could operate but it is a fact now that someone has been charged after something like 14 months. I think that all members of this parliament, who abhor this kind of paedophile activity, would be pleased to see that the legislation is being tested and that there is a charge under the legislation. This particular indecent act took place in the Philippines.

I noted there was another report this week that an Australian Federal Police investigation team has returned from Cambodia with evidence linking Australians with paedophile activities in that country. The investigation is at a highly sensitive stage and is expected to be finished before the end of the year. I noted in passing that Cambodian authorities were saying you cannot just blame foreigners, like Australians, for all this paedophile activity. I think he is quoted as saying, `Many Cambodians themselves, including high ranking officials, are involved in paedophilia as well.' It is heartening to see that action is being taken against those Australians who go overseas to abuse young children.

I am glad a matter is proceeding that I hope will resolve, one way or another, allegations that were made relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Allegations were made, I think it was by the member for Deakin (Mr Aldred), in the other place that either former or present members of the staff of the department of foreign affairs had been involved in paedophilia in South-East Asia. As I recall, the secretary to the department said he had found no evidence following an investigation but that there were contrary views expressed about that. I think some of the aid organisations were expressing grave concern about the rumours and reports that, in particular, former officials may have been involved.

The secretary to the department said a couple of months ago that he had asked the AFP to make a full, rigorous and comprehensive investigation. He called on anyone who had any information to reveal any involvement in paedophile activities within the department. There is no doubt that there is a great need to clear the department of any suggestions of improper behaviour of any kind in South-East Asia. I hope that this current investigation does exactly that.

On the other hand, it would be essential to ensure that there was no suggestion of favouritism or any other interference with the proper investigations of the AFP. Those Australians who are involved in paedophilia in Cambodia, as revealed by this present investigation, should feel the full consequences of the law.

While talking about the Department of Foreign Affairs and Tradeâ€”this is the only link it has with the next matter I want to raiseâ€”I must say that it is of major disappointment that Mr Peng has not been able to avoid an 18-year sentence despite the enormous efforts on his behalf particularly by Senator McMullan. It must be very galling for Senator McMullan, after all his hard work, to see that Mr Peng has received such a severe sentence. It is of concern that, despite the immense amount of high-level and determined activity by Senator McMullan and other government ministers and officials of the department, Mr Peng has received such a severe sentence.

It brings to mind the fact that there has been a much lower level of involvement in the problems that Dr V. J. Flynn is having in India. I am not seeking the same outcome, but I would seek the same level of governmental involvement in the Flynn matter as has taken place in the Peng matter. I wonder why there is such a striking difference between the intensity of governmental activity on behalf of Mr Peng as opposed to Dr Flynn.

I am very concerned that so far I have heard no governmental response to the fact that this week an Indian court refused to grant bail to Dr Flynn with one of the reasons being `the nationality of the petitioner'. In other words, one of the factors in the court's refusing to grant bail to Dr V. J. Flynn was the fact that he is not of Indian nationality; he is an Australian. That is the sort of racism that I find totally objectionable. I am particularly concerned that this government, on the face of it, has evinced no public concerns about this matter. I would think that is something the government should immediately respond to.

I understand that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not seek to intervene in judicial proceedings in another country unless there are specific reasons, particularly if an Australian is discriminated against on the basis of nationality in such proceedings. Here we have a clear instanceâ€”I have seen the judgment; I have a copy of the judgmentâ€”where it is shown that this court in India has discriminated against an Australian, in that it has not granted bail on the basis of `the nationality of the petitioner'.

I think this is no longer a matter where the gentlemanly approach, if you like, that has proceeded under the direction of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) is appropriate. When an Australian is denied proper human rights in another country on the basis of his nationality, it is a major disgrace. It is the sort of thing one would expect an ambassador to be called in to be lectured about.

I hope that the Australian government intervenes and expresses its serious concern about this kind of discrimination and does something positive to help Dr Flynn, who is 60, in bad health and has a strong case in defence of the allegations against him. I call on the government to take this matter as seriously as it took the Peng matter. I hope it can be more effective in getting a better result than it did in the Peng matter.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak about an issue that I have spoken about before. Given that the industry is about to become a very topical issue, I think it is important to talk about it at this time. It is also important because today ABARE brought out its quarterly product statistics for the June quarter 1995. We can see from those statistics that our imports of forest products have increased by 14 per cent, to $3 billion for the 1994-95 year. Our trade balance is in deficit to the tune of nearly $2 billion.

para.tab: The very important aspect of this issue is that the government has been working for some time on the development of a national forest policy statement. As part of that process, agreement has been reached with most states, if not all states, with regard to the deferred forest arrangements, which will see this government ultimately put in place the most comprehensive reserve system of forest types, probably in the world, for a country that has, and still maintains, a substantial amount of its tree cover.

That is a very good thing to do and something which we should do. At the same time, and as part of the national forest policy statement process, we are working on the industry development side of the issue. I read out those trade imbalance figures because they highlight how important to this country the forest industry really is. I am concerned that if we do not take the right decisions at this time we will not change those figures. In fact, we may well see them increase.

I have over a long period of time, some 14 years now, pursued the issue of industry restructuring. Not the restructuring where we see people lose their jobs, but rather the restructuring that turns the current industry into the better industryâ€”into an industry that utilises in a far better way the resources it has available to it. One of the major and most topical issues that we hear about every year, and have heard about for many years, is the export of woodchips and woodchip licences. It is for that reason that I think it is important to say something at this time about the issue of the 1996 export woodchip licences.

Utilisation of a forest resource is one of the most critical issues that we can be confronted with. If you take account of the import problem that this country has and look at the opportunity around the Asian Pacific region, even if you look at the 22 Pacific Rim nations, it is clearly identified, and has been for some time, that the demand for timber is growing at a significant rate and yet the capacity to meet that demand is declining.

A study by Economic Forestry Associates has identifiedâ€”and this has never been refuted; it is supported in most quartersâ€”that the requirement for timber and timber products of the 22 Pacific Rim nations will increase by 252 million cubic metres a year between now and the year 2001. That is a consumption rate by the year 2001 of 1.5 billion cubic metres of timber. The same author predicts that the deficit in supply over demand by 1996â€”which is just next yearâ€”will be 180 million cubic metres. By the year 2001 it will be 325 million cubic metres.

We all know that many of the countries in our region have a major problem with regard to their forest resource. Many of them are developing economies and many of them are poor countries. There is great pressure on them to actually utilise the natural resources that they have. It is my view that they are being exploited significantly. We have a responsibility to take action within our own industry to assist those countries. I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) supports that because he has spoken about it on a number of occasions.

I would like to quickly turn to my own state and address this question of utilisation. I have some photographs here of logs on railway carriages waiting to go to woodchip mills. They are logs that should never be going to a woodchip mill. There are a number of these photographs. These logs have been looked at by sawmills throughout the state and from interstate who have identified very clearly that those logs can be utilised. Indeed, many sawmillers in Tasmania have conducted trials that clearly show that the recovery of timber from many of these logs can be as high as 35 per cent. Much of that timber is of face grade quality and can be turned into very valuable timber product that we can not only utilise within our own nation but we can export to other countries. If we do not take the right decisions, as I said earlier, that will never happen.

If people had been reading the papers they would know that the minister responsible for issuing woodchip licences recently wrote to the woodchip licence holders and the applicants and potential applicants advising them that there would be new requirements or additional requirements on woodchip export licences this year. It has been quite interesting to see the plethora of would-be downstream processing proposals that have emerged from the woodwork since 8 September. In my state two of the key licence holdersâ€”one of them is the biggest exporter in this countryâ€”did not do anything with regard to downstream processing until just before 25 September. They came out with a range of proposals to demonstrate their commitment to downstream processing.

I was the secretary of the Timber Workers Union for some time; it later became the forest branch of the CFMEU. Over many years since 1983 I watched that company close down sawmills and totally remove its commitment to downstream processing. In fact, it fought against people who put up downstream processing proposals and used the advantage that it has through a woodchip licence to ensure that proposals for flitch recovery and recovery sawmills could not get off the ground. This has concerned me seriously. Moreover, just this year this company was found to be in breach of the terms and conditions that apply to licences. Contractors and other companies that work for it were found to be splitting sawlogs. This was ultimately recognised by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. It was also found to have taken wood from the National Estate.

This is a company that has been around for a long time, not a new player in the game. I wrote to the minister about that because I believe we have a responsibility to uphold the integrity of woodchip licences. I have urged the minister to take whatever action is necessary, because it is not appropriate that these companies be allowed to get away with thatâ€”particularly when there are other companies and sawmillers who will utilise that resource in a much better way.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to raise in the Senate tonight a saga which has been taking place for some time. It is in connection with an enterprise with which most members of parliament would be familiar: the King Island Dairy. I expect that most people who are familiar with this company and its products would think it is a desirable component of Australian commerce.

para.tab: I will start this story in the middle because it is quite a saga, as I said. Time does not permit me to do anything more than start in the middle and allow people to assess the situation as I continue. This concerns the Kirk family who were the owners of the King Island Dairy in 1986. On 25 November 1993, Mr Bill Kirk received a letter from the Australian Securities Commission asking him how did the new material that he had spoken of have any significance in the matter that he had raised with them.

On 8 December 1993, Mr Kirk wrote to the Australian Securities Commission and, essentially, this is where the story takes shape so far as what I am saying tonight. In his letter to the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Kirk questioned the dealings of a company called Liberty Trial and its relationship with another company called Transequity. Transequity bought the King Island Dairy from the Tasmanian government in September 1986. Liberty Trial bought some more shares in Transequity at the same time as Transequity was buying the King Island Dairy. The extra shares were sold to Agricorp when that company made a takeover bid in 1988-89.

Mr Kirk asks the Australian Securities Commission whether, given the coincidental timing of the share purchases with the sale of the diary, the ASC would as a matter of urgency audit the funds trail from the sales of those shares. On 9 December 1993, the day after Mr Kirk's letter, the regional commissioner of the ASC in Tasmania wrote back to Mr Kirk to say that they had considered the information and decided that no further inquiries were justified.

On 24 March 1994â€”and those who are following this will understand that there was other correspondence which took place between thenâ€”the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions wrote a letter in which he said that he could not direct the Australian Securities Commission to inquire or to direct resources. But the story continues. There are many members of parliament who have been involved in this matter. Many members of parliament have taken different approaches, tried different angles and conducted various levels of correspondence. I would like to read to the Senate tonight one letter from the Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch, to Mr Kirk on 24 November 1994. It states as follows:

speech.para: Dear Mr Kirk

para.tab: I refer to your letter of 16 August 1994 requesting Senator Zakharov's personal assistance through a Private Members's Bill to gain you the return of the King Island Dairy. I also refer to your correspondence of 25 August 1994 to the Office of the Minister for Justice, the Hon. Duncan Kerr MP, raising the same issue.
Senator Zakharov has forwarded to me your correspondence for reply. In view of my portfolio responsibility for the Corporations Law, I am also responding on behalf of the Minister for Justice.

In your correspondence to Senator Zakharov you raised the issue of the receiver's sale of the Dairy in 1986 at what you considered to be an undervaluation and also unspecified difficulties concerning share transactions by a shareholder of Transequity Ltd.

speech.para: You complain of inaction on the part of the Australian Securities Commission (the ASC) in relation to the share transaction.

para.tab: I am advised that the ASC has carefully considered all material presented by you on a number of occasions and has on each occasion concluded that there has been no breach of the Corporations Law to justify further investigation.

The ASC is an independent statutory authority charged with the responsibility for the investigation of complaints of corporate misconduct and I am precluded by law from giving directions to the ASC on a particular matter. As the ASC has investigated this matter and decided that no further action is justified, I regret that it would be inappropriate for any further action to be taken, by a Private Member's Bill or otherwise.
I have forwarded a copy of this letter to Senator Zakharov for her information.

speech.para: The letter is signed by Michael Lavarch. I notice that Minister Crowley is at the table. I continue this story by reading a letter that was addressed to Senator Crowley, also by Michael Lavarch as the Attorney-General. It is dated 20 December 1994 and it reads as follows:
Dear Senator

para.tab: Thank you for your letter of 5 October 1994 on behalf of Mr W J Kirk of Cheltenham, Victoria, regarding the appointment of a receiver and manager and subsequent sale of the King Island Dairy.

Mr Kirk has requested your personal assistance through a Private Member's Bill in gaining the return of the Dairy to him. I am advised that the King Island Dairy was in Mr Kirk's ownership in 1986, when the enterprise suffered financial difficulties and was placed in receivership. In his correspondence to you Mr Kirk alleges that the receivers and managers of the property sold it at a vast undervaluation to a company called Transequity Ltd and also raises unspecified allegations concerning share transactions by a shareholder of Transequity Ltd. Mr Kirk states that the Australian Securities Commission (the ASC) `did not want to know and would not investigate'.

There is a long history of representations by Mr Kirk to various parliamentary and administrative bodies concerning the King Island Dairy and the possibility of its return to him. Mr Kirk has raised the same issues in previous correspondence to myself. I am advised that the ASC has made extensive inquiries into Mr Kirk's allegations and carefully examined all additional material and issues raised by him. The ASC concluded that there was no reason to suspect a breach of the Corporations Law so as to justify action by the ASC.

speech.para: There is a concluding paragraph expressing similar things to those expressed in the previous letter. The point that I am raising tonightâ€”and I know there have been many other parliamentarians involved in thisâ€”is to ask: what is this family to do? Who can and will investigate Mr Kirk's problem? Apparently, it is not the responsibility of the ASC. I suppose we all have to accept that. But what if we allow for a moment that his assertions may be trueâ€”that the receivers and managers of the King Island Dairy sold it at a vast undervaluation to Transequity and that a shareholder of Transequity in some way gained an advantage? What if this family has been the subject of a sophisticated sting? Who is supposed to investigate and restitute damage in such situations?

para.tab: I believe this is an important question for this parliament. I intend to pursue it to a resolution. I do not know what to do next. I know that many people here tonight have been troubled by this situation and have been attempting to find a resolution to it. I suggest that this parliament should not let this matter rest just because it may be that the wrong institution has been approached or just because it may be that the paper trail peters out.

I ask the question: what happens if it is true? What happens if the confusion that is apparent in who was supposed to do what has been a deliberate course of action taken by some people who have gained great financial advantage at the expense of others? They are the questions that I think are extremely important for this parliament and they are the questions that I will pursue in the future.

talk.start.para: â€”The adjournment debate is frequently a time when people air grievances. I would like to take the opportunity to do something slightly different and that is to share with the Senate a story of great joy. It relates to an Australian citizen who has climbed to the very pinnacle of his art and his art is mantis kung-fu. The Australian citizen in question is Mr Henry Sue. Henry Sue is well known to me, as he is well known to many in the Chinese community in Brisbane. He has been practising kung-fu since, I believe, his teenage days. I shan't go into how long that is unless Henry gets embarrassed.

para.tab: However, Henry recently returned from Hong Kong. The reason he travelled to Hong Kong was simply this: Henry was admitted to the ninth degree of mantis kung-fu. There are only two other grandmasters anywhere in the world who have achieved that grade. They are both, I understand, in Hong Kong and one of those two is Henry Sue's grandmaster. Henry Sue is now the sole custodian of mantis kung-fu in Australia and one of only three ninth degree grandmasters in the world.

This is a great achievement not just for Henry Sue but also for Australia. It is really very pleasing that a man from this country can go to the traditional home of this form of kung-fu and excel and, in fact, complete what would normally be years of study in kung-fu, tai chi and chi kung in a matter of months. Such was Henry Sue's dedication. Now he has come back and Henry has recognised that he has a responsibility to pass on all that he has learnt to the people who study kung-fu in this country.

Henry said a couple of things to me at the dinner which welcomed him back in Brisbane which I believe are worth sharing. One of those things was that sometimes Australians are better at kung-fu than people who are born in China or in Hong Kong. He said to me, `It is very simple. We Chinese grow up with this. People who don't grow up with it have to work harder for it. What it does make them is very strong and it gives them the hunger, the desire, to succeed, and that is something very exciting.'
What Henry wants to do is to share that and to see more Australians become proficient at very high levels in kung-fu and to show that this country can do as well as Hong Kong or as well as China.

When I attended the welcome back ceremony for Henry Sue I must say that I have never seen such a warm welcome extended as I saw that night. Henry was met in the mallâ€”he did not know the celebration was going to take placeâ€”by two Chinese lions who proceeded to dance for him and then was led by the lions down through the mall to the restaurant, along a street lined on both sides of the pavement with other masters, instructors and disciples of his kung-fuâ€”all of them bowing as he went pastâ€”all the way up the stairs into the restaurant. It was a huge evening. Henry was absolutely ecstatic. He said he did not think anyone could surprise him. His wife had surprised him twice in two weeks and this was the second time. The first was when she flew over to congratulate him on having succeeded. I think that is a cause for great joy and great celebration.
I take the opportunity to congratulate Henry Sue on the wonderful achievement he has made for all of us because we are all the richer for what he has done. It has raised the profile of Australia.

I would like to continue this subject of good news by saying that I attended the 60th birthday party the other day of Mr Peter Yeoh, who is a Malaysian born Australian citizen. For those who do not know, in the Chinese community the 60th birthday is a very special year because the Chinese calendar is divided up into 12 years and five elements. So when you get to your 60th year, you have done a whole cycle of 12 years through each of the five elements. And it is traditionally a time of rebirth almost.

So Peter, who had been ill earlier on this year, celebrated his 60th birthday. Why is this a reason of great joy? I will explain why. Peter Yeoh is one of the most generous benefactors in Brisbane to all manner of charities. He received the Courvoisier award for public benevolence a couple of years ago and Peter demonstrated that at his birthday the other week by making three very large donations: one to the Chinese Fraternity Association to help construct an old people's homeâ€”he said he hopes he does not have to go into it!; another one to the Mater Hospital; and another one to the Chinese-Australian Medical Research Foundation. This continues a pattern of giving in which Peter has been involved for many years.

I just hasten to add that Peter is just one of many very generous benefactors in the Chinese community who give freely of their time and their money to not just the Chinese community but the Australian community generally. We are all the richer in both monetary terms and in a spiritual sense from their giving.

I would just like to say that the line-up of people for Peter Yeoh's birthday was truly impressive and was testimony to the great character of the fine upstanding man he is. Particularly impressive and a particular tribute is the fine family that he has produced, because all of them are wonderful people. And I thank his wife and his family very much for the opportunity to attend that birthday party.
I can see another honourable senator in this chamber who wishes to address the chamber, so I shall end my contribution there.

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you, Senator O'Chee. Could you pass my tribute along to the two people of whom you have spoken. I do not know them but, on the basis of your speech, I would like my tribute to be paid to Henry Sue and Peter Yeoh.

para.tab:
In the very short time available to me, I want to note what I consider a very important contribution made to our society by a judge of the High Court of Australia, Sir Daryl Dawson. I was delighted to see that the
Australian
newspaper gave headlines to an address he gave recently to the 28th Australian legal convention at Brisbane.

That article in the
Australian
says, perhaps a little ungenerously, that, `Sir Daryl Dawson said yesterday in an extraordinary attack on the federal government's competition policy for the industry', and talks about marketing forces in that industry. I want to refer to the phrase `extraordinary attack'. I did not think, on getting and reading his full speech, that it was an extraordinary attack. I thought it was a most proper way of putting the present situation of the legal profession in Australia.

The article goes on to say, `Sir Daryl, a noted conservative on the High Court bench said', and so on. It may be that Sir Daryl Dawson is a noted conservative; I suppose that is a matter for judgment. But if he is, may I say he is a conservative in the most proper sense of that word, in the way that the expression `conservative' is used to indicate people of high moral principle, people dedicated to the service of others and people with the sorts of values that this society should have and who want to preserve them.

I have the honour of knowing Sir Daryl Dawson. He is a person of the highest integrity and of great good sense. This paper he delivered, which I wish I had time to read to the Senate, sets out a very timely warning about where not only the legal profession but all professions and indeed our society are going.

Sir Daryl has stressed the great need that we have as a community to look to the service of others and to look to those true values that should motivate us as a people in striving for the sort of society we want. I am sorry my time is up; I would like to have said more. Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for giving me the extra few seconds.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)
â€”I am pleased to be able to do so, Senator.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 June 1995:

para.tab: (1) What has been the total revenue raised from capital gains tax from the date of its introduction until the present day.
(2) What have been the Treasury estimates for capital gains tax collections for each of these years.
(3) Why are capital gains tax figures not listed separately in the Budget papers.
(4) Does the Government intend to list capital gains tax separately in the Budget papers in future.

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: â€”The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) & (2) The following table shows the estimated and actual amount of revenue collected from capital gains tax since its date of introduction. Estimates were only provided up to the 1991-92 financial year.

answer.para: Financial year Estimated collections Actual collections
$ Million $ Million
1985-86 Nil Nil
1986-87 Nil Nil

para.tab: (3) Capital gains tax collections have not been published in the Budget papers since the introduction of May budgets in May 1994. This is because collections data are not available until after the end of the financial year. Collections data for capital gains tax are still published in the Commissioner of Taxation's Annual Report released after the end of the financial year.

Forecasts of capital gains tax collections have not been published since the 1991-92 Budget. Given the nature of the capital gains tax, the estimating process is complex, and the estimates are not particularly reliable. Estimating capital gains tax requires a combination of factors to be taken into account, eg. the holding period of assets, dispositions of realisations over time, real gains compared with nominal gains, and the distribution of pre and post 19 September 1985 holdings of assets. Given the unreliable nature and difficulty in obtaining such data it was decided to discontinue forecasting capital gains tax collections separately. Instead, capital gains tax collections are included in the estimates for company tax, superannuation funds tax and other individuals tax collections (the capital gains tax is formally inseparable from the income tax in any case).
(4) The Government does not intend to list capital gains tax figures separately in the Budget papers in future for the reasons outlined above.
